properties.text: 1. V. Saturday.  On looking out of my window this morning, I found the ground as far as I could see again covered with snow. A light snow continued to fall till nearly noon, about 8 inches deep and without drifting, the atmosphere being calm— I called at the Department of State, and saw the chief Clerk Vail. The Secretary Forsyth was not there— I found a voluminous correspondence respecting the Pirates and murderers of the Plattsburg; with Saabye, and Forbes successively Consuls of the United States in Denmark; and between Forbes and Count Dohna then Prussian Minister in Denmark— I examined also my correspondence with Bagot, Antrobus and Canning, in several cases of the demand for the delivery up of persons charged with crimes— Among the rest the case of the man tried at Charleston S.C. taken in the Almeida— I was there nearly an hour and a half; and yet had not time to examine thoroughly the papers in any one of the cases; but I saw that many of them are very important for the discussion of the question of the delivery up of persons charged with crimes—Slaves—and deserters— The opinion of the Attorney General Wirt, against the delivery up in one case was referred to by me; but the opinion itself was not in the Letter Book, and I had not time to wait for a search for it among the files— The subject swells upon me as I look into it— I told Vail that I should move a call for the correspondence in the late cases of demands for surrender, but he was shy of giving me any information what they are— I went next to the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions J. L. Edwards, and found him at his desk— I left with him a Letter from Seth Sprague junr. and an affidavit respecting the pension claim of Lucy, widow of Melzar Stoddard— A Letter from Lewis and Pierce of Brooklyn L.I. to the Commissioner Edwards, with a Certificate of the deputy Comptroller of New-York in support of the pension claim of widow Dinah Benson—and a Letter from the same Lewis and Pierce, with a Certificate from the Comptroller in support of the pension claim of Sibbel, widow of Craig Kelly.— Thence I went to the War Office and reminded the Secretary Poinsett of my recommendation of Mr Samuel A. Turner of Scituate for an Appointment of one of the annual Visitors at the West-Point Academy—of his answer that it was too late for that year, the appointment having been already made—but that Mr Turner would be remembered for the appointment of this year— He took down Mr Turner’s name, and said he should be remembered. I spoke to him also of the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia praying an Appropriation for magnetic observations; and said I supposed its proper reference would be to the Military Committee— He said he thought a select Committee would be preferable. I met at the Department of State Felix Grundy—late Attorney General—now again Senator from Tennesee— Afternoon visit from Mr Dawson of Georgia and Mr Jenifer of Maryland.

1. IV:45 Sunday  I walked to the Capitol, and heard Mr Cookman, the chaplain of the Senate. An English Methodist; settled here within the last two years, and celebrated for his eloquence. His text was from 1. Timothy 4.16.— First clause of the verse “Take Heed unto Thyself” which words he pronounced with a loud voice—a deep emphasis upon each of the underscored-words and a semicolon pause between each of them and the next. He then began by some general remarks upon the characteristic of the present age—which he said was excitement—association—movement in masses—the power of numbers—which he exemplified by alluding to the multitudes of Meetings, of Conventions of Societies for Political, Religious or benevolent purposes— But he was now about to address his auditory individually, in a solitary capacity; and in the words of the Apostle Paul, to say to each man, woman and child who heard him Take—Heed—unto Thyself.— What an easy, natural, beautiful introduction! He made no formal division of his subject; but it divided itself; and he had the skeleton always in his head— First guarding against any imagination that his object was to inculcate selfishness, but only the spirit of that self-love, which is implied in the precept to love thy neighbour as thyself—he successively repeated Take heed what thou thinkest—what thou sayest—what thou doest with obvious considerations of the relative importance of thoughts, words and actions—upon each of which he descanted at considerable extent— Then still repeating the Instruction take heed to thyself, applied it to the several relations with others, he finished with words of exhortation, particularly addressed the younger part of his hearers— Hast thou ever done a good action? I hope thou hast—many—what thinkest thou of them now? do they not afford thee an inexhaustible source of pleasure? Hast thou never sinned? I know thou hast—what thinkest thou of that sin now?— I will tell thee what thou thinkest—with regret—with regret! if not with remorse—thy habitual thought is—I wish I had not committed that sin— Oh think then that on thyself depends whether thy destiny after this life shall be an eternity of blessedness or of woe.— Then after a somewhat over-charged and hyperbolical declamation upon eternal punishment; he closed with saying Oh! think of that dying admonition of a pious father—think of that angel voice of a beloved sister, urging thee to virtue—and Take—Heed unto Thyself!— He closed, and the tears were streaming down my cheeks— I left a card at the lodgings of the Speaker Mr Hunter—and one next door for Mr T. H. Sumpter. I saw Mr John Campbell, and at Mrs Corcoran’s Jos. L. Tillinghast and Governor Lincoln— Met R. Peters, in the street; who promised to send me C. P. Van Ness’s argument before the US. Supreme Court in the Holmes case.— T. B. J. Frye dined with us— After dinner at the Presbyterian Church I heard Mr Wood, from Genesis 32.10. “And Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife, to slay his son.” The sacrifice of Abraham— The principle of obedience to the Will of God— I read the Article in the last December number of the Southern Literary Messenger, upon James Smithson— And part of the Instructions to the Antarctic expedition in the London and Edinburgh Philosophical Magazine, Septr. 1839—

1. V:30. Wednesday  Mr Lewis Johnson called on me this morning, and stated the present condition of the claim in behalf of the late William Otis’s estate upon the Government.— The final settlement is now before the President for his decision, which may be expected in two or three days. It makes allowance for the sale upon execution of the real Estate, but nothing for interest— The amount will be between ten and eleven thousand dollars, and pay all Otis’s debts leaving perhaps 2 or 4000 dollars for his heirs. Mr Lewis spoke in terms of high commendation of Mr Keys’s exertions and services in the case, both by influence and exertion. At the house, Mr Medill occupied three quarters of the morning hour in closing his speech on the New-Jersey election papers, which has become a mere question of trickery between the floating majority and minority of the Committee— Fillmore took the floor, not without a contest for the remaining quarter of an hour— Randolph attempted to correct one of Medill’s false statement of facts, but was not allowed to do it— Fillmore asked Campbell the Chairman of the Committee, whether the whole of a certain document had been read in Committee when they made their report? Campbell answered that as much of it had been read as had been called for— Fillmore repeated the question—had the whole of it been read? Campbell commenced a narrative of the proceedings in the Committee— Fillmore pressed his question again—was the whole document read—yea or nay? Campbell shuffled, without answering either yea or nay—when the orders of the day were called— Mr Bell resumed his Speech upon his bill, for securing the freedom of elections, and spoke about four hours, upon the abuses and corruptions of the present and last administrations—signalizing the organization of an electioneering system of Government, by the admission of the Postmaster General as a member of the Cabinet—by a sweeping system of removals from office upon political grounds—by the attempt to turn the Bank of the United States into an electioneering engine—and upon its failure, the destruction of that Bank, undertaken, and accomplished— He said he could prove if the House would give him a Committee that there was a great organized central association with the President of the United States at their head, and branching out to every State in the Union, and by whose command every officer not only in the Government of the United States, but in every separate State.— And he concluded with a story of a Vampire with which he compared Martin Van Buren;—but I did not hear this distinctly, and could not discern its point. Immediately after Bell closed, Watterson of Tennessee took the floor, and at the instigation of Weller moved an Adjournment which was carried and before 5 O’Clock— The members of the delegation from Massachusetts received this day six sets of Resolutions, adopted at their late Session, and we agreed to meet Friday Morning at 10. to confer upon what to do with them.

1. VI. Friday.  The Chevalier Friederichsthal, attached to the Austrian legation, is going on an excursion in the course of which he intends to visit Boston— I had yesterday written Letters of introduction for him to President Quincy and to Edward Everett which I had promised him, and also one to my Son, which I gave him this morning. In an hour’s conversation with me he told me that he had last Summer visited and traversed the Islands of St. Domingo, Jamaica and Cuba, with the purpose of observing attentively the relative condition of the population in the three different states of long continued freedom, of Slavery and of recent emancipation. It was apparent that the result of these observations was very unfavourable to African, for his great admiration was concentrated on the flourishing condition of Cuba, his anticipations quite unpromising to Jamaica—and his severest animadversions reserved for Saint Domingo. He promised to send me his comparative statistical tables for the three islands which he did this Evening— They fully confirmed my expectations.— His visit detained me so that I found the clerk reading the Journal of yesterday, when I entered the House— Briggs moved to go instanter into Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the appropriation Bill; which was done after postponing at the motion of John W. Jones, the report of the select Committee upon the brawl between Bynum and Rice Garland till next Monday— Casey took the Chair of the Committee— Stanly had the floor upon an amendment which he proposed to offer to the appropriations for the public buildings after the rejection of the amendments proposed by Petrikin, which he considered as certain— I could stand this no longer— I rose and asked if Jones, Chairman of the ways and means seriously intended to persist in opposing Petrikin’s amendment—to stop the work upon the public buildings, and to leave the workmen partly unpaid for the wages they had already earned? Jones with some faltering at first avowed that he did; but afterwards worked round to a consent that the appropriation should be increased to 60000 dollars on the Treasury building, to pay the workmen their wages already earned. I gave him a volley for resisting any part of Petrikin’s amendment— He attempted to divert the attention of the Committee to my overheated manner—talked of the shin-plasters of my favourite institutions, and said he supposed I wanted an entering wedge to increase the appropriation for the custom house at Boston— I replied to him with an abated vehemence of manner— Govr Lincoln, Waddy Thompson and Hunt aided me with argument— Stanly consented to withdraw his amendment if Jones would accept the two amendments of Petrikin, which Jones however refused—but upon taking the question by tellers there was a large majority for Petrikin’s amendments— In the course of the Evening Ogle made his second Speech on the furnishing of the President’s House; and replied with extreme severity to some animadversions of Governor Lincoln upon his former Speech— Lincoln now made an instantaneous highly spirited and triumphant defence of himself, and turned the tables and the laugh upon Ogle to universal admiration. But it was a very unprofitable controversy to the whigs. The debate continued again till near Midnight— I walked home.

1. V. Monday.  The biennial election day for Mayor, Aldermen and common Councilmen of the City of Washington— William W. Seaton was elected Mayor in the place of Peter Force, who has held the office four years.— I called this morning at the City Hall upon Mr Andrew Rothwell Treasurer of the Columbian College, to ask for payment of the years interest on their bond to me, this day payable. He said he had money; but was so much engaged in the city election that he could not attend to me this day; and I told him I would call again to-morrow.— At the House it was the day for offering regulations. But as soon as the Journal was read, C. Cushing rose to a priviledged Question, and before he could state what it was, Waddy Thompson, acting chairman of the Military Committee moved a suspension of the rules, to take up a Bill for raising 1600 men for the defence of Florida: and he sent to the Clerk’s table a very urgent Letter from the Secretary of War, and Advices from Florida of recent massacres by the Indians of our troops.— Downing, the delegate from the Territory, added his supplicating voice to that of Genl. Thompson; but the democracy would not hear a word of it— The motion to suspend the rules was lost 118 to 94— Thompson then moved the suspension of the rules for this day—lost. 116 to 85— Hunt moved a suspension for two hours—lost 111 to 98. Triplet moved a suspension of the rules to introduce his supplementary pre-emption bill. lost—72 to 121. Cushing finally moved his privileged question which was the reconsideration of the vote of Saturday, accepting Hillen’s report from the Committee of Commerce, which a majority of that Committee had reconsidered, and reversed— Cushing’s reason for moving the re-consideration was that he had found by the yeas and nays that it was a party vote— Clifford moved the previous question Grinnell, a call of the House— Proffit to lay the whole subject on the table—on each of which questions the yeas and nays were taken. The call of the house was refused—the motion to lay on the table rejected—the previous question carried; and the reconsideration refused 84 to 108. And now came the recess— I rode home, dined and returned to the house— At 5 minutes past 4 there were more than 200 members present and debating Atherton’s motion, now offered by Albert Smith— After a confused and riotous sitting this Resolution was carried and the reconsideration of it rejected— During the whole day, I was a silent, passive, humiliated, indignant, helpless, Spectator of the Scene.— I came home after voting for the last motion of reconsideration and while they were taking the yeas and nays— We had a small Evening party. Thomas B. Frothingham came in, just from Boston— High Summer heat.

1. IV:45— Wednesday  There was a corner of a thunder shower here last Evening, and this morning the thermometers were down as low as 74 and the feeling, cold— At the house Linn Banks moved a Resolution for the adjournment of Congress on the 20th. of this month. days before and after were proposed, and Petrikin who chuses to have every thing in his own way moved the 15th. and the previous question, both of which he carried—the previous question by 113 to 22. and the day, the 15th. by 105 to 95.— This was no sooner announced than Watterson moved a reconsideration—carried 108 to 84. Question again taken on the 15th. rejected 88 to 113. Then the question upon the 21st. was carried without a division— This is a pattern specimen of the consideration and reconsideration of this previous question house— I asked the general consent of the house to present a report from the select Committee on the Memorial from the American Philosophical Society at Philadelphia— Cooper of Georgia objected and my Report was not received. But Cooper came afterwards to my seat, and when I explained to him my reason for asking that the report might be received and printed, he said he would not persist in his objection.— The Report from the Secretary of the Treasury of the Commerce and Navigation of the year was received and after some altercation 10,000 extra copies were ordered to be printed.— The Bill from the Senate for continuing the Charters of the District Banks—all of which expire on the 4th. of this month—was taken upon by general consent out of its time— Petrikin and Mark A Cooper immediately started budgets of burdensome conditions, as amendments, which were sharply debated till the recess— I made a short speech to urge the indispensable necessity of passing the bill in some form before next Saturday. During the recess I went into the Senate where they were debating with much earnestness, the 9th. Section of my revenue bill. Before the recesshad moved to lay the Senate’s Bank Bill on the table, which had been rejected by yeas and naystoafter the recess Cooper’s batch of Amendments in superfetation of Petrikin’s batch was taken up, and divided into parcels, upon each of which yeas and nays were taken—some adopted, some rejected; until about Sunset, when at the motion of Petrikin, the house adjourned.— I came home immediately, and after a very light dinner and went to Mr Alexander Vattemare’s exhibition of Ventriloquism— My wife and granddaughter Mary-Louisa were also there— The sport began with sundry songs and duets by Mr and Miss Manvers, with accompaniment of the Piano—and the recitation of Collins’s Ode on the passions, by Mrs Manvers, very well— Alexandre’s drama is called the adventures of a Ventriloquist or the rogueries of Nicholas, in which he sustained seven parts, old and young, male and female, and imitated the planing of a table, the frying of eggs in a pan, and sundry other strange noises— The House was crowded—and well pleased. I sat between Mrs Paulding, and Mrs B. O. Tayloe— Home between 10 and 11.— Weary.

29. V. Wednesday.  We had fixed on to-morrow as the day of our departure upon our return to Quincy, but my wife was so unwell in the former part of this day that it was doubtful whether we should not be under the necessity of postponing our movement, one or more days— Towards evening however she so far recovered her strength and Spirits that she concluded to proceed in the morning— We were all intently occupied and none more so than Mrs. Adams, in packing up, settling accounts and bills, and getting ready to go at six O’Clock to-morrow. Mary has concluded to go, and take her daughter Mary-Louisa, with us. As the order of the Treasurer of the United States in favour of myself as Attorney to Ebenezer Lobdell, promised me by the Secretary of the Treasury, to be forthcoming yesterday was not yet in hand, I called this day noon at his Office and received it from him— It was drawn on the Collector of the Customs at Boston, instead of the new Receiver General Isaac Hill, as I had requested and he had promised— He now said that Mr Hill had not yet quite completed his arrangements for entering upon the execution of his office— I asked him what was the present condition of the Smithsonian funds invested in bonds of the State of Arkansaw.— He said the interest upon the bonds had been hitherto punctually paid, and he was just now receiving proposals for a new investment of the interest of the last half year—and he read to me several Letters containing these proposals.— They were of the States of New-York and others at 5. per Cent a year, and at about 90 per Cent, and of Kentucky and Arkansaw at 6 per Cent interest—the Kentucky bonds at 90 per Cent, and those of Arkansaw at 70. He said he should take the lowest bid. I expressed my strong disapprobation of the Sale by the Secretary of the Navy of Stocks of the States, at a much lower price than he had purchased them at— He said there had never been any sale of the Stocks of the States by the Department of the Treasury.— Besides the struggle to redeem the arrears of my Diary which accrued unavoidably in the last fortnight of the Session, I answered and declined the invitation of Mr A. J. Downing to visit his Botanical Garden, and Nursery at Newburgh opposite Mr de Wint’s— My wife visited this evening her brother Mr Thomas B. Johnson, who has been very sick, but is convalescent. Mrs W. S. Smith left us this day, and removed to Mr Frye’s. My neighbour Mr Parris, and Mr Cutts and his daughter visited us this Evening; and Mr John Bell of Tennessee, with whom I had a long conversation, upon the prospects of the Presidential Election— We agreed that the present appearances were favourable, though by no means certain for a change; but I asked Mr Bell, what were the expectations beyond the change, and found him quite unprepared to answer— He knew not who would compose the Cabinet of Genl. Harrison, and was not disposed to bestow much confidence in advance upon whoever it might be— I told him that at all Events he must be the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and he confessed that it would be the summit of his ambition— I was up packing till near midnight— Dismissed Thomas with a warm recommendation—

1. II:30 Saturday  Stonington— Providence. Boston— Quincy.  Heavy rain in the Night—but little wind, and a smooth Sea so that I slept nearly four hours, a rare fortune for me, in a Steamer— We landed at Stonington in the midst of the rain, a few minutes before 3.— There were upwards of 300 passengers, and of course a scramble for the seats in the Cars.— There is one which they call the Ladies Car, and when my Ladies had gone into it the conductor stoppd me and told me it was reserved for the Ladies— I said I was with Ladies; upon which he said the Car was already full.— With much difficulty I found a place in the foremost Car, and he turned Jerry in the Deck Car—that is a Car next to the Engine, and exclusively for the Deck or half price passengers— These are regulations not used in the Southern boats, and were new to me here— The scramble for places is a vexatious and unnecessary annoyance which would be removed by numbering the seats and furnishing the passengers with tickets correspondingly numbered— The rain continued and the cars flew till we reached the river, at Providence and snatched a cup of Coffee and a cracker while crossing the river in the Steamer. Then took seats again in the line of Cars, and at half past eight O’Clock landed at the railway depot in Boston— There we found a Hack-Stage belonging to the American House which we engaged and in which we were taken out to our residence at Quincy— Here we landed once more at half past nine in the morning—fifty two hours from our house in F. Street Washington and 16 1/2 hours from the wharf at New-York— My first movement is of grateful acknowledgment to a benign Providence which has preserved and protected us all safe and unhurt through the perils of a long journey though performed in a very short time, and to the melancholy catastrophe of one of which I was an afflicted eye-witness. And to the blessing of our own safe arrival is added that of finding all our family here in good health and comfortable tranquility— My Sons two elder sons John Quincy and Charles Francis were at our house when we alighted— He came over immediately after and then his wife with her daughter Louisa Catherine all with cordial greeting— The pangs inexpressible in words of the deep affliction in which we left this place last November, were too acute for the fortitude of a mother’s heart—my own feelings could be and were suppressed. John Kirke and his wife were here expecting us, and prepared to receive us— The rain continued with intervals through the day, and confined me almost entirely to the House I did however visit my garden and Nursery, which I found in no satisfactory condition; but I have lost almost all my interest in them— I unpacked my trunks, and began to write as I could, a Letter to Ebenezer Lobdell, and this Diary from the day before we left Washington.— This occupied the day; and I spent the Evening with my Son and his wife at their House; where I saw their youngest son Henry Brooks— All their children are thriving.— The Revd Joseph Angier, of Milton was a fellow passenger with us from New-York and gave me a pamphlet containing two Sermons, preached at Mobile, Alabama, on the 10th. and 17th of May last, by George F. Simmons—which I read this morning in the Cars—

2. V. Sunday  Communion day at Meeting— Mr Lunt preached his morning Sermon, from Acts 17.21. “For all the Athenians and Strangers which were there, spent their time in nothing else but either to tell or to hear some new thing”— It is the doom of the Christian church to be always distracted with controversy; and where religion is most in honour, there the perversity of the human heart breeds the sharpest conflicts of the brain— The Sentiment of Religion is at this time perhaps more potent and prevailing in New-England, than many other portion of the Christian world— For many years since the establishment of the theological school at Andover the Calvinists and Unitarians have been battling with each other upon the atonement, the divinity of Jesus Christ and the Trinity— This has now very much subsided—but other wandering of minds takes the place of that, and equally lets the wolf into the fold. A crack-brained young man named Ralph Waldo Emerson, son of my once loved friend, William Emerson, and a Classmate of my lamented son George, after failing in the every day avocations of a Unitarian preacher and school-master, and starts a new doctrine of transcendentalism, declares all the old revelations superannuated and worn out, and announces the approach of new Revelations and prophesies— Garrison and the Non-resistant abolitionists, Brownson and the Marat Democrats, Phrenology and Animal Magnetism all come in furnishing each some plausible rascality as an ingredient for the bubbling cauldron of religion and politics— Pearce Cranch ex-ephibis preached here last week, and gave out quite a stream of this transcendentalism, most unexpectedly— Mr Lunt’s discourse this morning was intended to counteract the effect of these wild and visionary phantasies, and he spoke with just severity of the application of this Spirit of hurly burly innovation to the most important and solemn duties of the Christian faith— He treated the subject but in part; and promised to discourse further upon it hereafter— Mr Lunt’s opinions favour a compromise between the past and the future; disapproving alike the obstinate and bigoted adherence to establishments and dogmas, merely because they are old; and the restless and reckless pursuit of mere innovation— Mr Peter Whitney was not in the pulpit and Mr Lunt administered the Communion alone. After dinner, Mr Lunt’s Sermon was from Matthew 28.19. “Go ye, therefore, and teach all Nations, baptizing them, in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.” This is also a deeply controversial text, and Mr Lunt admitted that it was one of those upon which the doctrine of the Trinity was built, and is advocated— But he thought that Doctrine so incompatible with the first principle of the unity of the supreme Creator of the universe, that it was not worth discussing, and that the Holy Ghost was but the emanation of the Spirit of God, pervading all time and all space but giving no countenance whatever to the Creed of a divine Trinity. I read part of a Sermon of Barrow, upon rash judgments— Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. paid us an Evening visit.

3. V. Monday  The Midshipman John Quincy Adams, and his Cousin Francis Foster were here this morning. The Midshipman has recently returned from a two years cruise in the Sloop of War John Adams Captain Wyman, in a Squadron under Commodore Read Captain of the Frigate Macedonian. They have been in the Chinese, Indian and South Seas and visited Brazil, Chili and Peru, the Islands of the South Sea, Canton, Macao, and Manilla— Foster is residing with his mother, who is passing the Summer with her Sister, my brother Thomas’s widow— After dinner two young men from Boston James Thomas Fields and E. Hobart came as a Committee from the Mercantile Library Association, to invite me to deliver an address before them at their anniversary meeting some time in the course of the next Month— Without positively declining, I prepared them to receive my excuses hereafter— My Son went to Boston, but returned home to dine and spent the Evening with us— How great a change in my way of life, from the perpetual action of fourteen hours a day at the Capitol in Washington, to the repose and meditation of this place, with no defined call to business of any kind— Yet my time is wholly absorbed here as well as there. And here as there the only labour of my life is writing— I have not yet retrieved the arrears of my Diary towards and at the conclusion of the Session of Congress; but as always happens, when I have any choice of my own occupation my attention is scattered upon a variety of subjects instead of being concentrated upon one— I would now prescribe for myself the following order of employment for the four months of interval till the next Session of Congress. 1. The Diary—two hours each day 2. Reading the Newspapers two hours. 3. Hearing my Granddaughter Mary-Louisa, read one Chapter in the French Bible of Silvestre de Saci— She began this morning, by reading the first chapter of the Book of Joshua—and I read in the English Bible after her—verse by verse. Breakfast half an hour. Dinner an hour and a half, including a visit to my garden, Nursery, Seminary and Orchard, writing one Letter two hours.— Wastage three hours— Miscellaneous reading two hours, exercise two hours— Writing out Speeches, Lectures, addresses, discourses, two hours—and lastly—Biography of my father— What time is there left for this; the most important of all— I have already looked into Buffon’s natural history of Man; Butler’s Hudibras—Plautus’s Mercator, and Charles brought me out this Evening from Boston, Brownson’s Boston Quarterly Reviewing for July 1840—containing an Article upon Transcendentalism, and one upon the laboring classes— Brownson is a broken Parson, who after losing his Capital of Atheism and Hypocrisy in the pulpit, has transferred the rags and tatters of his religion to the field of politics, and swindles for Van Buren, under the mask of democracy.

4. V. Tuesday  Weather still unsettled— Heavy showers of rain this morning and occasional light ones in the course of the day— Morning visit from Mr. Peter Whitney, who was unwell, and not able to attend at Meeting on Sunday— Afternoon visits from Mr Cranch, and Mr Lunt who returned the two Volumes of Winthrop’s Journal, and the old Manuscript Volume of the Braintree town records, which he had borrowed last Summer.— I despatched a Letter to Mr Anthony Collamore of Pembroke, enclosing a pension certificate for Lydia Stetson, and received one from Thomas P. Beal of Kingston, respecting the act for the relief of Ebenezer Lobdell.— I had forwarded the Treasurer’s draft in favour of Mr Lobdell to him yesterday; and this day began a reply to Mr Beal whose Letter burns with politicks— I have yet but partially visited my seedling trees, but enough to find, as I never fail to do; upon returning to them an abundance of disappointments, and here and there encouragement to hope and gratified expectation— No new seedlings of the last Autumns sowing. The cruel distress in which we passed the last six weeks, before our departure; the agonies of our separation from that adored child, the pang of which will go with me to my dying day, the anguish of her long protracted sufferings, and that frightful creeping upon her of Death, from hour to hour for weeks and months in succession disqualified me for all energetic action and extinguished almost all the interest I had so long taken in the cultivation of trees. There were two small plats in the seminary which I had specially given to her and in which she took delight— There were various seedlings upon them— One of them is now entirely overgrown with weeds, except one peach of the second year of stunted growth— On the other a black currant yet stands and bears its first berries, with an unthirsty apple seedling at its side— A self planted violet covered it with blossoms through the whole of last Summer, and there is a remnant of them there now. Oh! if I could describe the Sensations, which I feel on looking upon those two plats, it would be conceived how all the pleasure has vanished with which I was wont to look at the plats which I had given to each of my other grandchildren, as tokens to them of kind remembrance of me, when I shall sleep with their and my fathers. I have thought it would be to them a pleasing though perhaps a melancholy recollection— I did not think of the withered violet—the flower cut off in it bloom— Was not this trial fixed upon me as a warning? I spent part of the Evening in Charles’s porch; with him and Mr Lunt— Mrs Charles in the meantime came down here, and Charles came to return with her at the close of the Evening— In the intervals between my spells of writing, I attempted to read the atheist priest Brownson’s Article upon Transcendentalism which is as dull as it is impudent, hypocritical and provoking.— If his account of Cousins philosophy is correct, Cousin himself is no better.

5. IV. Wednesday—  I had from the age of sixteen when the beard first presented itself on my face, with a few exceptions in early years, always made the practice of shaving myself.— The Paralytic affection which in 1813 Dr. Galloway at St. Petersburg, told me, I must expect would grow upon me with age, had so far disabled my right arm, that on the 18th. of December I was obliged to send for a barber and he shaved me every third day, till last Thursday morning when we left Washington— On arriving here I found that a young man named William Shaw had been settled here about 3 months and he shaves me— Deacon Spear was here this morning, and gave me some particulars of the present condition of the town— Both branches of its business greatly declined— The waggons laden with granite passing daily in the road before my gates are certainly not one fifth part in number what they were last Summer, when they had already considerably fallen off—the Shoe and boot business fares still worse— The Curtis’s who kept at least thirty men constantly employed have dismissed them all.— Afternoon visit from Mrs Forbes, with her Son John— A Sister of Thomas H. Perkins, I had a slight acquaintance with her before her marriage, and do not remember to have seen her since— How changed! and through how many vicissitudes she has passed. She now resides on Milton Hill; in an elegant house built for her by her Son, when he had returned rich from China— But he has returned to China to get rich again, and now is involved in the troubles there and will probably be obliged to come home. Josiah Adams junr was here at Sunset— Much dissatisfied with the decision of H. L Ellsworth the Commissioner of Pensions that his barkcutter is not entitled to a patent, and yet afraid to incur the risk and expense of appealing from it— He asked my advice which I gave him but which he will not take— Mr Beale and his two daughters were here this Evening.— He is very earnestly pressing my Son’s wife to assume the presiding Station at the Pic-Nic projected by the Ladies of Quincy, and to which those of the whig party throughout the whole County are to be invited.— I brought up this day the recent arrears of my Diary, and have none left of the last thirteen Months— I waded through the Article upon Transcendentalism in Brownson’s Boston Quarterly Review— Hypocritic, perhaps self-delusive Atheism, into which every man irretrievably falls, who begins by setting aside the Bible, and betakes himself to the standard of reason to measure the infinite and the finite—spirit and matter—God and the Universe— All such speculations find no end, in wandering mazes lost— They are all words differently significant to different minds and understood by none— The Germans Schelling and Hegel and Schleiermacher, were novelties to me, as prodigious metaphysicians; and I read also an Article upon Beethoven of whom I had heard as a composer of sundry Symphonies, but whom I now recognize as a wonder of the world.

6. IV. Thursday  Having retrieved the recent arrears of my diary, I began this day the assortment of my Letters, received many, of which however I packed in my chest to follow me from Washington— This was the first clear morning since I reached home, and I went up to see the Sunrise from the corner of Charles’s house— I finished the reading of Brownson’s Articles on Transcendentalism, and on the labouring Classes— The disorganizing principles of politics, morals, and religion—which belonged to the most ferocious and bloody period of the French Revolution are returning upon us all their savage brutality, modified, by hypocritical professions of religion— Brownson has been successively a universalist minister, an avowed atheist, a Unitarian minister, a newspaper politician, and a democratic pamphleteer— Mr Van Buren has given him the place of Steward of the Marine Hospital at Chelsea, and he earns his stipend by undermining the foundations of civil Society. He is the Editor and almost only writer of a periodical pamphlet called the Boston Quarterly Review, the main objects of which are to unsettle all faith in religion, and to kindle inextinguishable War between the different classes of men— He assumes the mask of profound reverence for Christianity and its founder; but fills his sheets with furious invectives against Priests—and by Priests he means the whole body of the clergy of every denomination— His invective against them is in general terms, without specification and without exception—to expose them to public hatred and obloquy— Next he rails against all the employing class of the people, whom he arraigns as oppressors and tyrants over the labouring classes, whom he instigates to exterminating and indiscriminate butchery against them— He distinctly avows that Slavery is a much preferable condition to that of labourers at wages; and proclaims without hesitation or disguise that the only remedy to raise the labouring classes to his proper level is to abolish the relation between the employer and the workman, and to abolish all hereditary property— He then says that his party must not be held responsible for this particular doctrine, for it belongs exclusively to himself: but that he is sure it must ultimately prevail.— Robert Owen, Fanny Wright, Abner Kneeland, Garrison, Brownson and Emerson are all of one school, and all by different instruments are inflaming to fury the passions of mankind against one another— Is it not every man’s duty to take the field against them— I answered the Letter from Thomas Adams junr. which I had received at Washington respecting the proposed Pic Nic of the Ladies next Month— I read also the Mercator of Plautus, and the translation of it by George Coleman— A Translation itself from the Greek of Philemon— There is nothing of a Merchant in it except the purchase of a slave harlot for the possession of whom the father and son are rivals— The girl boasts of her expertness at weaving. The moral of the play is, that a beautiful girl is a very proper keepsake for a young man, but a very bad one for an old bell wether— The plot is simple and inartificial— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— Mary quite unwell.

7. V. Friday.  Alpheus Spear was here this morning and settled with me, for two quarters of the Mount Wollaston farm rent, ending the 31st. of March last— Nearly the whole of one Quarter’s rent is absorbed in Bills for repairs—and he told me crustily enough that he could not pay the third Quarter’s rent due the 30th. of June— He complained bitterly, that he could not get paid for any thing, and that the town have treated him with barbarous cruelty, by defeating him in a suit at law, which he in wanton obstinacy commenced against them, for denying to his children the right of attending one of the town Schools, upon a doubtful question, within which of two School districts, his dwelling house is situated— This is a hard working, industrious, ignorant obstinate, self-conceited man, ruined, body, mind and estate by the prevalence of the democracy.— Rival and competitor of Harvey Field, his mind was first unsettled by Harvey’s election two years successively as a representative of the Town in the Legislature of the Commonwealth— Alpheus’s quarrelsome disposition, and his Lawsuit with the town blasted all his hopes of election for himself, but he canvassed successfully for his brother Lemuel who was elected for the year 1839. and in attendance on the General Court caught his death— In the progress of political and religious excitement Alpheus became last Winter became raving distracted, till he was bled and blistered into comparative sobriety; but he is even now on the verge of fractious and fretful insanity. He grumbled about a want of much fencing upon the farm till I told him the lease had not much longer to run, and that when it should expire, I contemplated raising the rent— From the prospects of his present condition he will be no longer a trusty tenant—though I shall have much difficulty and no small hazard to supply his place— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, made a deposit there, and left my book to be balanced— I then rode with John Kirke, and my Grandson Charles Francis to the Mount Wollaston Beach and took a Seawater Bath, according to my ability with my crippled right arm— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine— Brought me a Letter from Dr Frothingham, which I answered this afternoon— I had also answered a Letter from Mr A. E. Silliman, President of the New-York, Mercantile Library Association, inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them next November— I declined— Harvey Field was here this afternoon; teeming with the whig Ladies Pic Nic, to which he wished me to invite the future Governor John Davis and his wife, and to dine with me— He wants also to sell me some clapboards to cover a barn, and to trade with me for some poor Lands for house lots. I saw the Sunset from Charles porch— He and his wife passed the Evening here— Visit from Doctor and Mrs Woodward.

8. V. Saturday  Showery day— Mary quite sick; confined to her chamber— I am dissatisfied with my waste of time without knowing how—seeming to myself day after day, exceedingly busy and finding the day gone, without leaving a trace of usefulness behind— I visited my grounds; garden, nursery, seminary, orchard, all overgrown with weeds—great numbers of my seedling trees perished; others suffering from drought—insects—worms, and causes unknown, for which I am unable to devise a remedy.— The seedling appletree, near my old hickory, and the seed of which was sown in October 1833. bears fruit this year; so that I have my own experience to prove that an apple-tree may bear fruit the seventh year from the seed; but why that tree more than all the rest has been of so rapid growth, and so precocious bearing is a mystery the secret of which I shall never discover.— The one Philadelphia Maple, of a row in the seminary, the seed of which I sowed on the 1st. of June 1835. is about fifteen feet high, and measuresinches round the stock at the surface of the ground. Most of the Medford Appletrees planted in October 1830 are in full bearing— The thrifty and fast growing trees, are the Buttonwood, Ash, English white Oak and Elm— Of these trees, if I were now 30 years of age, I would raise a forest covering many acres, with an intermixture of red and white Oaks, and of shagbark hickory, horse chesnut and white walnut— One of my Nettle trees ten years old bears berries for the first time.— The dwarf Apple-tree; barren last year bears abundantly now; but the fruit is stunted, blighted and worm eaten The look of all the apples, pears and peaches is very unpromising— Both parts of the divided blackjack oak are alive; but the stem of the one in the Nursery has died down within a foot of the ground, and there thrown out a shoot already five feet high—the one transplanted to the garden has died down to the ground, and thrown out shoots from the root— The two Medford Apple-tree stocks which had been girdled by field mice, and which Mr E. Price Greenleaf budded last summer have taken, and are growing, tolerably well— The Orchard Nursery is so totally overgrown with gigantic weeds, that I can only perceive that at least four fifths of the seedling fruit-trees have perished and the remaining fifth have made no growth— My interest in these plantations is a dream, passing away— I have found, and begun to read the 4th volume of Graham’s history of the United States which I had mislaid last Summer, while reading the third— I read also Edward Everett’s Address delivered before the Mercantile Library Association on the 13th. of September 1838. upon accumulation, property, capital and credit— An Admirable, eloquent, argumentative, and affecting discourse. There is with it an amusing poem by James T. Fields, one of the young men who recently visited me. At Sunset, I went to Charles’s house— He and his wife came afterwards down and spent the Evening here.

9. IV:45. Sunday— Sun-rose at 5. beclouded.  Heard Mr Lunt this morning, from 1. Corinthians 14.19. “Yet in the Church, I had rather speak five words with my understanding, that by my voice I might teach others also, than ten thousand words in an unknown tongue.” This was the second part of Mr Lunt’s discourse of last Sunday Morning, against the atheism now fermenting in this Country in the shape of what they call trancendentalism— He was very animated and eloquent; but there are grave difficulties in the subject which he discussed; and others in the text and in the Chapter which contains it upon which he did not touch— The preceding Chapter, in the small compass of 13 verses sets forth the supremacy of Charity as the first and greatest of the Christian virtues, and in which the Apostle seems to include the whole sum and substance of Christianity. That chapter alone gives the key to the purest and most perfect code of morals, ever promulgated to the race of Man— Let that chapter alone be impressed upon the heart, and carried out in the conduct of men, and this world would be a paradise regained— The 14th. Chapter is a comparative estimate of the faculties of speaking a variety of tongues, and of prophesy the latter of which is much preferred over the former— But Faith—Hope, Charity are all acquirable properties, attainable by human energy and exertion— The gifts of speaking tongues and of prophesy were preternatural, and the exercise of them seems to have been hardly a fit subject for exhortation— The argument in the chapter depreciates the gift of tongues, as if it was the practice of those who professed it, to speak in languages which the heares did not understand— The word unknown in the text, is an interpolation—not in the original greek— But when the miraculous gift of tongues was bestowed on the apostles on the day of Pentecost, it was not that they should speak to any one in an unknown tongue; but that the should speak to each in his own— Throughout this chapter, prophesy evidently means preaching and not prediction— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined, and spent the day and Evening with us.— Mr Lunt’s text after dinner was from 1. John: 2.15. “Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world— If any man love the world, the love of the Father is not in him.” A somewhat beaten subject, but Mr Lunt’s discourses are always interesting— At the close of the afternoon he requested all those who took an interest in the theological institution at Cambridge to remain and hear a communication which he had received relating thereto— It was a written statement shewing the condition of the school, and that unless 10,000 dollars can be raised and added to its funds it must be shut up and abandoned— Mr Lunt said that a collection would be taken up next Sunday afternoon, for the contribution of this Society towards, raising the sum required— President Quincy and his Son were here after Meeting— George W. Beale junr. and Mr Wales, who returned with Degrand to Boston— E. Price Greenleaf engaged to call on me to-morrow afternoon— Time for reading engrossed by company.

10. IV. Monday. Saw the Sun rise 5.1. Crystal clear  Mr Nathaniel Curtis, my Co-executor of the Will of Ward Nicholas Boylston, was here this morning with an account of Administration for the last three years which he has prepared to present to the judge of probate for the County of Norfolk, who is to hold his Court in this town to-morrow.— He and Mrs Boylston will come for that purpose to-morrow.— There is a small spot of Land in Corn Court Boston, belonging to the Estate, about the sale of which he has been in Treaty, first with the Suffolk and afterwards with the Massachusetts Bank. He had a Letter from a young lawyer, N. Bowditch, Counsel for the Bank, questioning the validity of Mr Boylston’s recorded title to the land.— The original deed he says, is dated in 1724. and he supposes there may be some claim in the right of Mr Boylston’s Aunt Mrs Gill, and also in Mrs Elmsley, and in the heirs of the late admiral Hallowell.— Mr Bowditch enquires also as to the right of the Executors to sell the Land, and proposes that they should insert the Deed a Warranty in their own names; but this we have heretofore agreed in no case to do.— The form of all our deeds expressly excludes it— The Will gives the Executors power to sell real Estate, with the restriction, that those portions of it which came from his ancestors shall be the last sold— Mr Curtis had proposed to grant a lease for 999 years; but Mr Bowditch thinks that this might by a late Statute of the Commonwealth be considered as a sale in fee-simple. (Revised Statutes of Massachusetts p. 411) I desired Mr Curtis to prepare a copy of the deed of 1724. and to look up the indentures between Mr Boylston and his brother and Sister, by which they conveyed to him all their rights in Estates coming from their common ancestors in this Country— A young shoemaker, named Horace Faxon, son of Benjamin Faxon came to enquire, if I could accomodate his father with a loan of 500 dollars for a year— No.— The new married couple from Fishkill landing, Mr Whittemore, and Louisa de Wint were here last afternoon— They were married last Tuesday— He is 21. She 18. and they look like two children eloped from school— Whittemore is the son of an inventor of a machine for making wool cards, of whom I have some recollections half a century old— It is said he made a large fortune by his invention, of which this youth inherits a part. Mr E. Price Greenleaf came and visited with me, my garden, Nursery and seminary. He examined several apple and pear trees which he budded for me last August, and most of which have succeeded— He engrafted also last Spring an old pear-stock with sundry slips of Bartlett pears, which had once or twice failed before, but now succeeded: we found on two trees nests of voracious worms.— Peter Turner was here this Evening, and persuaded me to lend him 50 dollars for a week— This succession of visitors, absorbed the day from Breakfast time. Charles spent the Evening here; and his wife with Mary who is yet confined to her chamber— I wrote a Letter of five lines to Mr Grattan the British Consul at Boston, and have read the first Chapter of the 4th volume of Grahame’s History.

11. IV. Tuesday  Saw the Sunrise— 5.2. Semi-clear.  Morning visit from Dr Holbrook. Mr Curtis, and Mrs Boylston came about 11—we signed the account as Executors of the will of Ward Nicholas Boylston—which had been prepared by Mr Curtis; and we then attended the probate Court, held at French’s tavern, by the judge Sherman Leland, who administered the oath to us all, but declined examining the vouchers produced by Mr Curtis, observing that all the interests in the Estate were represented by the Executors themselves— Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston dined with us, and also my Son and his wife— I went with Charles this Evening to Mr Quincy’s where Mrs Charles had already gone to take tea; and where we found Mrs Isaac P. Davis, and Miss Phelps, preceptress to Mrs Quincy’s children— I contracted a sort of engagement with Mr Curtis, to make a trip with him towards the close of this month to Halifax— There is a small property in that Province subject to the disposal of Mr Ward N. Boylston’s Executors, and upon which Mrs Elmsley has some claim— The agent there has not been punctual in the settlements of his accounts; and Mr Curtis thinks it expedient that we should look to him, in person— He left also with me a considerable budget of papers, concerning a deed of gift in October 1818 from Ward N. Boylston to the Inhabitants of the Town of Princeton, for the benefit of the Congregational Society of which the Revd Samuel Clarke was then the Pastor— The town and parish being then the same— And at the same time he gave 500 dollars, to be loaned out in small sums to industrious and frugal young men, each for three years, with interest to accumulate, till it should be sufficient, to build a Hall for Town-Meetings, on the land— With family vaults under it, as a cemetery for himself and his family— And by his Will there is a bequest of 1000 dollars for the same purposes; to be paid if the Executors think proper after the decease of Mrs Boylston.—18 June 1832. Mr Samuel Clarke was dismissed from his Office as Pastor of the Princeton Congregational Society.— 19. June 1833 John P Cowles was settled in his place— 23. Decr. 1833. The Parish organized itself as a corporation separate and distinct from the town— 30. Octr. 1834. Mr Cowles was dismissed from his pastoral office— 26. Octr. 1836. Elijah Demond was settled and 8 Novr. 1839. dismissed from the same Office; since which they have no settled Minister— The Inhabitants of Princeton have instituted a suit in Chancery to ascertain in whom the donation and bequest are now vested, and they have made the Executors of Mrs Boylston’s Will, parties to the suit— Mr Curtis on the 23d. of June last addressed a Letter to the Selectmen of Princeton, expostulating with them, against their being involved in the costs of a suit in which they have no interest, and there is a Letter from Mr Emory Washburn disclaiming all disposition to annoy them.

12. IV:20— Wednesday—  Bath in the mount Wollaston Creek, at half-tide and low water; but Mr Daniel Greenleafs wharf is in ruins, and the bottom of the creek is so deep with mud, that it is a very inconvenient place for bathing. The Creek itself is rapidly filling up— Afternoon visit from Mr and Mrs Cruft. They are leading a strolling life; by the indulgence of a propensity, which has swayed him many years, and which he has communicated to her.— With a numerous family of children, they find nothing that attaches them to home— Sweet home is unintelligible to them— Home to them is bitter, sour, vapid, any thing but sweet— And so it is to great multitudes of our People in this Country—perhaps to the wealthy throughout the world— The facilities and rapidity of modern travel, give great additional impulse to this propensity— Home is an English word for which there is in the French language no corresponding term— Perhaps there is no stronger indication of National character than in words of peculiar significancy in the language spoken by them— The compound association of ideas in the English word home consists of elements which form the choicest and purests enjoyments of human life.— The word home carries us back to the place of our birth, to the tenderness and anxious solicitude of a mother’s love; to the cares bestowed upon us in childhood, to the affectionate kindness of family relations, of friends and neighbours— It is the place of conjugal, parental, filial, and fraternal endearments— The place where alone we can possess and exercise the practical blessings of freedom— The French language has no word including all these Sentiments— They have a favourite popular song, expressing them all in its first line— “Ou peut-on être mieux qu’au sein de sa famille.”— All this is embraced in the single word “home.” It is a great but very common misfortune of the wealthy to lose the relish for these enjoyments; which may be the result of sickness—of family discord, of casualties incident to the condition of human existence, and perhaps more than all of ennui. The best prevention to this last locomotive is literature— One of the most useful properties of the love of reading is the ligament which it adds to the ties which attach us to home—profound study can be no where else pursued— The vulgar adage that a rolling stone gathers no moss is pre-eminently true of intellectual culture— Travellers may collect facts and accumulate observations.— But travellers to escape from ennui, essentially indolent cannot abide the labour of collecting arranging and committing to writing useful information— Mr and Mrs Cruft returned a few days since from a tour to New-Jersey; and are to depart to-morrow upon an excursion down East— I walked this Evening to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and found there her son John Quincy, and her sister Foster with her son Francis— Rode home with the Ladies.

13. IV:30. Thursday  Showery.  My Son Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine’s birth day—Nine years old; and she spent it here. A day of entire leisure, with no interruption, save of a way-faring man—who stop’d at the door to beg, and said he was of the Livingston family of New-York. A vagabond, but apparently a man of education— About Sunset I went up to Charles’s house, and he and his wife came down with me and spent the Evening here— I wrote nothing but the Diary of yesterday, and an answer to a Letter from A. D. Bache President of the Girard Collage, Philadelphia— My time is absorbed by three different classes of reading, which scatter into many others— 1. The Daily Newspapers— Most unprofitable— I apologize to myself for yielding so much precious time to them, by the plea of necessity to keep up with the course of Events— 2. Grahame’s History of the United States of North America—Volume 4. The title is a Misnomer. It should have been called the History of the English Colonies in North America, from their Settlement, till their Declaration of Independence— 3. Jean Jacques Rousseau’s letter to D. Alembert on his recommendation of the Establishment of a Theatre at Geneva. Of the Newspaper reading, there remains nothing useful upon the Memory. The attention is distracted by such a multitude and variety of subjects that it fixes upon none. They succeed one another day after day, and have not even the privilege of the Lord Mayors day in the Dunciad, to live in Settles’s numbers, one day more The Boston Papers, Courier, Daily Advertiser, and Atlas, are now filled with election returns from North-Carolina, Kentucky, Indiana, and Alabama— All for the State Governments and all hitherto more or less favourable to the whigs, as the opposition to the present Opposition Administration of the General Government call themselves. The imposture of Jackson and Van-Buren democracy, would seem to be drawing to its Catastrophe—and yet falsehood, injustice and wrong are permitted by divine Providence to have such sweeping sway over the affairs of men that I scarcely dare indulge the hope that the day of retribution will come even when it seems to approach— Twelve years I have submitted almost in silence to the foulest and basest aspersions upon myself, my administration and my father, of which Jackson took the lead by denouncing me, in his inaugural speech; while at the same time the remnants of the old Hamilton federalists assailed me with a furious onset here in my native Commonwealth. It would have been a waste of time and toil, to have attempted my defence, hitherto. The public ear was not open to me and I have lived slumbering under a cloud— Is the time arriving for me to speak? or must I go down to the grave and leave posterity to do Justice to my father and to me? In humble submission I prostrate myself before the footstool of God, and implore the act of his Spirit, to nerve my will and to prescribe my path

14. IV:15. Friday.  Morning rain storm— Sun set clear 7.4.  Call at Quincy stone Bank, where I took my balanced book and return checks— Just after noon I rode with Charles’s wife, her children Louisa Catherine Charles and Henry with his Nurse Catherine, and Mary Louisa, John Kirke and Jeremy Leary to the beach behind Mr Quincy’s house, where they have a bathing house— Kirke and Charles bathed with me on the open beach— Jerry kept the Carriage and horses, and the rest of the company bathed at the bathing house.— A drowsy weariness after dinner succeeded my bath— A short Letter to Mr Frye, and five lines to John Butterfield Lowell, declining to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum at that place next November, were all the writing that I could accomplish besides my diary day. Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine— I went up and saw the Sunset from his porch, at 7:4 by the American Almanac, but about ten minutes before, just a disk North of the apex of the sloping hill in front of the porch—the hill interposing between the Sun and the horizon— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us, and we had visits from Mr and Mrs Quincy and Miss Sophia Quincy.— My regular reading progress in two books at once is slow.— The 4th. Volume of Grahame’s History begins with the year 1757. and the 5th. chapter of the 10th. Book embraces three years of time.— The inglorious campaign of 1757. which is attributed in considerable degree to the incapacity of Lord Loudoun, yet one of the Counties of Virginia still bears his name— The controversy between him and the Colonial Legislature of Massachusetts Bay, about quartering troops involved the question of the enforcement in the Colonies of Acts of Parliament. The General Court in a remonstrance written by T. Hutchinson admitted the unlimited authority of Parliament to extend their Legislation over the Colonies when named; but not otherwise.— Loudoun was superseded by Abercrombie, of whom the historian speaks not less contemptuously. In 1758 the change of Ministry took place which brought William Pitt, afterwards Earl of Chatham to the head of Affairs, and with it a remarkable change from weakness, languor and discomfiture to active energy, vigorous action and success— The Conquest of Cape-Breton was effected in 1758—and the repulse at Ticonderoga was suffered; where Lord Howe was killed— The reduction of Forts Frontignac and Duquesne was of the same year, and the substitution as commander in Chief of the British forces, of Amherst instead of Abercrombie. The year 1759 is signalized by the campaign which terminated in the conquest of Quebec and the memorable battle on the plains of Abraham; where the commanders of the hostile armies—Wolfe and Montcalm were slain—as if Providence intended to foreshew the final event of the War to both Nations. The account of the death of Wolfe is deeply affecting.

15. IV:45 Saturday  Saw Sun rise at 5.6—and set 7.2— but behind the summit of the hill 6.55  Thomas Adams junr. came this morning, and speaking of the proposed Pic-Nic, whig Lady party to be held here on the 3d. of next Month, asked me, if I would write to Ogden Hoffman and Serjeant S. Prentiss and invite their attendance to make speeches.— I observed that having from various considerations peculiarly applicable to myself, felt it an obligation of duty, to abstain from giving my attendance at any public meeting during the pendency of the Presidential election, I considered it as a necessary consequence that I ought not to take any part in the formation of such meetings; as there would be an obvious inconsistency, in my giving invitations to others to attend meetings, which I do not attend myself. He said Mr Prentiss was now on a visit to his relations in the State of Maine, and was to address a public meeting at Portland next Tuesday— He had some thoughts of going down to Portland on Monday, to hear him, and to invite him to come to the Pic Nic—and he asked me, if, in case he should conclude to go, I would give him a Letter to Mr Prentiss; which I promised I would— I had next a morning visit from Mr Lunt, and a long conversation with him; or rather a talk, for it was almost entirely on my side— I spoke of the pernicious doctrines promulgated with so much perverse zeal, and mischievous pertinacity at this time, and connected with the politics of the day.— He mentioned the collection which he had given notice last Sunday, would be taken up to-morrow, in aid of the funds of the theological institution at Cambridge and said that Mr Whitney and he had thought this was the best mode of proposing a contribution for that object to the members of the religious Society here— But he was apprehensive that some prejudice against the appropriation had arisen from the fact that Mr Emerson’s transcendentalism had been first broached there— I said I had no doubt it was so; and that I must acknowledge, my share of that prejudice. He said some of the professors of that institution, were among the most strenuous and vehement opponents of the transcendental school; and had even written against it. He further said he had lately been on a visit to Plymouth, where he had heard enquiry made whether I should be a Candidate for re-election as a member of the House of Representatives of the United-States; and some suggestion of an intention to address the inquiry to me— I said it was perhaps high time for me to retire definitively from all public life, and I was receiving daily admonitions of the fact from the continual erosions of Time and from the casualties of chance. But having as yet received none from my Constituents, I thought I should leave to them the determination whether I should represent them two years longer in the Councils of the Nation, or bid adieu to the service of my Country at the close of the present Congress— Charles’s wife and family went with Mary-Louisa to the bath this day, but I thought it best to intermit— I answered a letter from Henry R. Schoolcraft, informing me of my election as an honorary member of the Michigan Historical Society— Louisa C. Smith came out from Boston—

16. IV:30 Sunday  Saw Sun rise 5.7. Set 7.1. behind the peak, exactly.  Mr Lothrop, Minister of the Brattle street church Boston, but having his Summer-residence on Milton hill, was the preacher for Mr Lunt this day. His morning text was from Romans 10.10. [“]For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness”—a Discourse upon Faith—ingenious, discriminating, argumentative, written in a style of polished elegance and bating a little affection of manner, well delivered— He traced Religious conviction to three sources—Reason—Experience—Faith and the last as belief founded upon Reason and Experience— He distinguished between the Faith of Reason, that of Experience and that of the heart; the belief as described in the text, unto righteousness— The faith of reason is a cold, unimpassioned conclusion of the Judgment, not dependent upon the will, and liable to err from all defects of that faculty— The faith of experience is the belief of facts as they are made known to us by the testimony of our own senses; also greatly liable to err—but the faith unto righteousness is the belief of the heart founded on our confidence in the testimony of others.— This belief is one of the Laws of Nature implanted in the heart of man: for man is so constituted that he must and will believe the testimony of his fellow man, unless he can perceive some motive of the informer to deceive— This is the foundation of historical faith, and the principal basis of belief in the historical part of Christianity is the notorious fact that the evangelists who wrote the historical books could have no possible motive for falsifying the narrative— Mr Lothrop’s analysis of faith was confined to its passive signification of belief in the testimony of others— He took no note of it as the motive of action; as the reciprocal basis of confidence of others— It is the connection existing between these two properties of Faith and their mutual dependence upon each other in the human mind that I wish to see analysed and illustrated, and will attempt it if I can command the time— After the morning service, Mr Lothrop read the same statement of the condition of the theological school at Cambridge which had been read last Sunday by Mr Lunt; and gave notice that the collection would be taken up this afternoon. Mr Lothrop and Charles dined with us.— As we were going over the Hill after dinner to Meeting we saw a large Steamer passing rapidly up the harbour, which we took for the Acadia expected from Liverpool. Mr Lothrops afternoon text was from Colossians 1.9.—[“]that ye might be filled with the knowledge of his will, in all wisdom, and spiritual understanding.” The collection for the theological institution was taken up; and produced about 40 dollars:— I read the first Sermon of Barrow upon [“]quietness and doing our own business”— Doctrines suited to the restoration age of Charles the second; but not to this time and Country.— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us.— And we had a visit from G. W. Beale junr.

17. IV:30— Monday  Sun rose 5.8.— Set 6.59 beclouded  Deacon Spear was here this morning, and I had a long conversation with him on my private affairs— I gave him the contribution that I had intended yesterday but had left my pocket-book at home— I gave him also a check for 50 dollars which I had subscribed last autumn for Captain John Whitney after his loss of his house and Store by fire— I engaged to go with the Deacon next Thursday afternoon if the weather is fair to view my lands through which the County Commissioners have laid out another new road. these new roads are a grievous oppression, and iniquitous burden upon me; cutting up my lands in every direction, and imposing upon me a heavy tax for fencing; but it is useless to complain, and Patience; while she lasts asswages many a sore.— Mr E Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and I saw him, and walked with him to the quarries beyond his fathers house— We met there James Newcomb, and about 20 of the Stone cutters, moving a block of granite 32 feet long, and about 5 cubic feet thick; for a pillar to the new Custom house at Boston. They were also fluting out another Pilaster of nearly the same dimensions.— Mr Hobart and Mr Sawyer, two young men, members of the Mercantile Library Association came out and reiterated the urgent invitation to me, to deliver their next Anniversary Address; in the course of the ensuing Month— I had not yet definitively made up my mind, but told them I would send them an answer before the end of this week— And Peter Turner came to ask me to wait till tomorrow morning for the payment of his note to me; which I readily agreed to do— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— He brought me one hundred copies of my revenue speech for Mr John Fine; and the two Volumes of Bancroft’s History of the United States which I am to read— Also a check for 1060 dollars 76 cents from Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and notice to attend the probate Court at Boston Tuesday the 27th. instt. upon the claim of the Estates of the two Moses Gill’s, on the Administration of Thomas Boylston— Charles gave me also sundry securities of property— Deeds and certificates, a list of which I propose to enter upon this Diary to-morrow morning— The Steamer which we saw go up the harbour yesterday was not the Acadia from Liverpool, as we supposed, but a boat from Portland—Maine— But the Acadia did arrive this morning, after a passage of 12 days and 14 hours, the shortest ever made from England to Boston—and she had touched to land the mail, and passengers at Halifax—where she lay 6 hours at the wharf— This travelling by Steam is producing wonder upon wonder in approximating to each other the inhabitants of the four Quarters of the Globe— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us.— The day was wasted by me— I know not how— I sent a packet of pamphlets to H. R. Schoolcraft.

18. III.45. Tuesday  Sun rose 5.9. hazy— Set 6:50 beclouded.  I looked for the Star Sirius; but he was lost on the haze— The whole constellation of Orion I saw—  Charles’s birth day 33—  Alpheus Spear came and paid me 205 dollars for the Quarters Rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to the 30th. of June— Morning visits from the Sisters Mercy and Susan Tufts—and afternoon visits from Mr William Minot and Charles P. Curtis— There has been for two or three years a project for a general association of the graduates of Harvard University, to hold annual meetings the day before Commencement, intentionally as a substitute for the Meetings and Literary exercises of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, the day after Commencement— The day before the last Commencement there was a Meeting of the Alumni, at which a Committee of 5 were appointed to prepare and report at the day before the ensuing Commencement a plan for such a general association. Mr Minot and Mr Curtis are members of that Committee, and came to enquire, if I would consent to be put in nomination for the Office of President of the Society— I felt myself honoured by the proposal and said I had only two objections against it— One the consciousness of my inefficiency for the Office; and the other a warm regard for the Phi beta kappa Society, and an aversion to join in any measure which would seem to have a bearing of hostility to them. They said that the members of the Phi beta kappa society had themselves originated the proposal of the general association, and almost universally favoured it— Mr Curtis read to me the report, to be made including a Constitution for the new Society— A President, two Vice-Presidents and 7. Directors are proposed for the organization of the Society— Judge Story and Edward Everett are proposed for Vice Presidents— I consented to place my name at their disposal— Josiah Quincy and his Lady came up on horseback and held a colloquy with Mrs Charles at Sunset, before the porch of her house.

19. IV:15. Wednesday.  Sun rose at 5.10— Set 6:56.—both in haze.  I saw Sirius, about half an hour risen, immediately after I rose— Then the rising Sun from the South-eastern corner of Charles’s house, and the setting Sun, from his porch— Morning visit from two Officers of the Navy: Lieutenants Wilson and M’Neill, stationed as they told me, at the Navy-yard in Charlestown. Afternoon visits from Mr and Mrs Armstrong, and from Baron Maréchal, the Austrian Minister at Washington—with Mr Austin the Attorney General of the Commonwealth— I enquired of the Baron what we were to think of these rumours of Wars between France and England; brought by the last Steamers, from Liverpool, the Acadia, which arrived on Monday at Boston, after a passage of 12 days and 14 hours and the President arrived yesterday in 17 days at New-York— The Baron thinks there is no danger of War; and that the large armament of Louis-Philippe, is merely a demonstration of Louis-Philippe to put a responsibility upon his Minister, and thereby to get rid of him— The first part of the Evening I spent under Charles’s porch with him and Mr Lunt— Afterwards his wife and then himself were at our house— I attempt in vain to economise time for writing beyond the Diary of the day, and one short Letter— I despatched two packages with 50 copies in each of my revenue-bill Speech, to John Fine, Member of H.R.U.S. at Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence County, New-York, and an answer to an invitation from Samuel Lawrence, to address a public whig meeting at Lowell, which I declined— I continue the daily reading of about 20 pages of the 4th. volume of Grahame’s History of the United States, with which I am much less satisfied with than with the preceding volumes. The narrative until the close of the 7 years war and the conquest of Canada continues interesting, and in all the approaches or premonitory symptoms of the conflict between the Mother Britain and the Colonies, the bias of the Historian in favour of the Americans is constant and overruling— In the Appendix 3. p. 147. Is a statement with a proper mark of reprobation, that in the year 1764 there was despatched from England to America a pack of blood-hounds to assist the British troops in tracking the Indians— He says that the British never stooped to the employment of such auxiliaries, except in their contests with Indians, or with negro slaves.— There is some account from Soskiel of the Moravian Missions— The title of the 11th. Book is, the Progress of the States of North-America, till their Assumption of political Independence— The first chapter contains the account of the commercial restrictions subsequent to the Peace of 1763. and of the Stamp-act—but not a word about the argument in the case of the Writs of Assistance.— Grahame never saw the Massachusetts State Papers, nor Novanglus.

20. IV:30 Thursday  Sun rose 5.11. Set 6.55. both transparent.  Morning visit from Mr Thomas Loring and Mr Edward Thaxter of Hingham, who came to propose a fishing party at Cohassett some day next week, of which Mr Loring will give me due notice. Deacon spear came as by appointment at 4 this afternoon with his waggon, in which I went with him and my Son and his Son Charles up into the pastures beyond the two houses of the brothers Ebenezer and Josiah Adams, on the spot where stood the old family mansion of Joseph Adams junr. father of my grandfather John Adams.
