The youngest Son of this Joseph was Ebenezer, and he as has been usual in New-England inherited the family mansion and farm.— It is the old borough—English tenure, the reason of which is fully developed in the natural origin of it, by the law of nature operating upon the state of Society consequent upon the colonization of New-England— The settlers at Mount Wollaston received small grants of land proportioned to the number of heads in each family— As the children grew up to man’s estate— The sons one after another, and the daughters by marriage departed from the paternal fire-side, and went abroad to find new Settlements for themselves leaving the youngest son, to cultivate the farm with the father, and to hold possession of it after his decease.— Thus it was that the first Joseph, the youngest Son, or youngest but one, of the Patriarch Henry, being only 20 years of age, at his death in 1646. inherited the malt house and brewery, which he occupied through a long life and left to his youngest Son Peter— The elder Son, Joseph junr had emigrated from the brew house, and pitched on this spot, a little hermitage remote from the high way; which in 1736, he dying, left to his youngest Son, Ebenezer, whose Son of the same name was, the father of the two brothers, who now at ages of 79 and 77. are still in common possession of the Estate— We found Deacon Josiah at work on his Potato field, and he walked with us to view the ground staked out for the road, from Braintree to the borders of Milton— As usual it trenches largely on my land, and passes very near to the houses of the two brothers— On returning home I found at our door Mr Solomon Lincoln of Hingham, and Mr Fearing, originally of Hingham, but now of Boston— Mr Lincoln enquired whether I should be a candidate for re-election, and whether I proposed to attend any of the public Meetings in the District preparatory to the November elections. I said I did not intend to be present at any of the public meetings; and that whether I should be a candidate for re-election or not would depend upon the people of the District themselves— I should not offer myself; nor should I decline—especially as for the first time since I have represented the district, a formal and avowed opposition to my re-election was announced. He then enquired if I proposed to address the People of the District through the Newspapers as I have heretofore done.— I said I thought I should— Charles spent the Evening here— His wife was unwell, and did not come down.

21. III.45 Friday  Sun rose 5.12. Set 6.54 transparent.  My namesake and nephew, the midshipman was here last Evening—his Sister Elizabeth returned two days before from her visit to Cedar grove Fishkill landing where she went to be present at the wedding of Louisa de Wint, now Mrs Whittemore. She came home sick, and has been confined to the house ever since— This morning Charless wife with her daughter Louisa-Catherine went into Boston, and thence to Medford, where she is to spend a week at her father’s. She took Mrs Frothingham’s son Ward with her—he has been a week of school vacation with her boys here— Mrs Kirk and Mary Louisa, went also with her; and Charles; but they all returned before dinner, and Charles and the two elder boys dined and took tea with us. I have received a Letter from Mr Samuel Cabot of Boston, saying that his Sister widow of the late Professor Follen who lost his life in the melancholy catastrophe of the Lexington Steamer last Winter—is about to publish some account of his life—and that she desires to publish part of a Letter which he wrote to me in 1831. October upon German Literature— And if I have preserved the Letter, she asks for it, for that purpose. This put me upon the search for my files of Letters of the last ten years, which I found in the great confusion, and after the waste of at least three hours, I was yet unable to find the files of 1831— This is an admonition which I must not disregard to pursue connectedly the determination to assort all my manuscript papers so as to have them at my command— The only step towards which that I could now take was to gather and file upon two steel rings the keys of 14 wooden chests in which most of my manuscript papers are contained— Eleven of these chests are now here, and three at Washington; one of them packed up, and expected soon here— We had this afternoon a very heavy thunder gust differing from those which usually happen at this Season: the shower coming first and the thunder and lightening afterwards— It came up very suddenly and the clouds at no time of it wholly covered the sky. Mrs John Codman, wife of the orthodox minister at Dorchester, was passing by, with Miss Allen, daughter of the President of Dartmouth college, and stop’d with us until the storm was over; about an hour— Mrs Codman gave us an affecting account of the last sickness and recent death of Mr Samuel Adams Welles, only grandson of Samuel Adams, who has left ready for the press a Life of his grand-father with vouchers to comprize Six Octavo Volumes— Mr Welles’s last 3 years have been a period of excruciating pains and after the amputation of a leg, a long agony of death. I saw the Sunset from Charles’s porch, and he spent the Evening here— The atmosphere was more sultry after the shower than before— Answered the Letter of C. A. Luzenberg—President of the Louisiana Society of Natural History and Sciences.

22. IV:15. Saturday.  Sun rose 5:14.— Barely visible through haze.  Afternoon visits from Mr Smith, the preceptor of the Hingham Academy, with the two Misses Thaxter, and afterwards from the Revd. Mr Lothrop with Mr John Forbes, second son of Ralph Bennett Forbes, and of his widow, sister of Thomas H. Perkins, who visited us on the 5th. instt. with another John Forbes, not as I then supposed him her Son; but of James Grant Forbes, another brother of my old deceased friend and Classmate John Murray Forbes— Ralph Bennet Forbes my Classmate’s younger brother was like himself a martyr to the gout, and in his last days, dependent, with his family upon his brother John for support— But Ralph Bennet’s eldest Son, of the same name went out very young to China, and in a very few years made an affluent fortune— This John was also there and alike successful.— They came back, and built for their mother the elegant house on Milton hill where she now resides. John built and resides in a cottage near the same spot— But Ralph after his return was unfortunate, became poor again, and went again to China, to reinstate himself in prosperity— He is yet there, unless expelled with the other American Merchants from Canton, in consequence of the Opium quarrel between the English and the Chinese. Mr John Forbes is in great anxiety on his brother’s account, and asked many questions of my opinions, both with regard to facts and principles, involved in this controversy— I told him I was very imperfectly informed of the facts; that I could not possibly bring myself to believe that the British would attempt the conquest of China; and I believed that their demonstration of War, was made merely for effecting an accommodation with the Chinese Government upon as good terms as they could obtain, but that if they do pursue the War they will suffer no neutral commerce with China, and that all the American commercial establishments at Canton will be broken up. He asked if they had the right? I answered no, but that in commercial warfare, the British measure of right was power; and they had no other— He said that many persons entertained the opinion that a British army of 15000 men, the force which they have ordered there, will easily accomplish the conquest of all China; there being no organized military force, and the people having no weapons except bows and arrows. I said that with such an immense population, invasion itself would soon organise a defensive military force, and if they should have no other weapons than the stones of the Streets they would be sufficient to crush a European army of 15000 men. He said he had, and would send me a published statement of the facts—

23. III:30 Sunday.  Sun rose invisible Hazy Horizon. Clear above.  Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2 Timothy 2.5. “And if a man also, strive for masteries, yet is he not crowned, except he strive lawfully.” This was his third discourse against the new, or old vamped up transcendental doctrines— He waxes warm as he proceeds, and gave this day a broadside at Carlyle without naming him for having in his history of the French Revolution, dressed up the character of Mirabeau into a pattern of patriotism— The deadly sophistry of the transcendental school consists in the alliance of Atheism with hypocrisy.— The characteristic of the age is to unsettle all established opinions, and to put into perpetual question all the foundations of human Society— We are to argue pro and con—whether parricide be a crime or a virtue; whether property, is by the law of Nature, or the mere creature of conventional law—whether the contract of marriage constitutes an obligation of duty restrictive of promiscuous social intercourse—in short whether justice or force is at the root of all human institutions— In the process of this argument the transcendentals not only dig up the cornerstones of human Society; but pronounce them decayed, rotten and worthless— The dregs and the froth of the cauldron are boiled up into one impure and poisonous compound and administered to the body politic for healing medicine.— Religion is sapped and undermined by this fraudulent philosophy; the labouring classes are instigated to hatred and violence against the proprietors, and the elements of a civil war of extermination, are stimulated into deadly conflict with one another— Mr Lunt has not yet finished with this subject, but with discourse upon it again— Mr Whitney preached in the afternoon, from Job 14.14.— “All the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change come.”— Upon Death— Mr Whitney has been forty years the settled minister of this Church and Congregation, and he cannot have long to wait for his change— The marks of age are sinking upon him deeper and deeper, every day. The argument of his discourse that Death was not to be dreaded as an evil, but as the necessary proper, and happily devised termination of life, which must of course have an end.— I read two Sermons of Barrow—the second upon quietness, and doing our own business—and the first upon the Love of God.— The following extract is from the Discourse on quietness. “Especially we should not make ourselves parties, in any faction, where both sides are eager and passionate, for then, even they who have the juster cause, are wont to do unjust things in which, it is hard for any man engaged not to have share, at least not to undergo the imputation of them: it is wisdom therefore in such cases, to hold off, and to retain a kind of indifferency; to meddle with them is (as the Wise man saith) to take a dog by the ears; which he that doth, can hardly take care enough of his fingers.”— What a seasonable admonition to me! Charles spent the Evening here. We had two ends of thunder showers, refreshing the air, which has been at sultry Summer heat the last three days.

24. III:30. Monday—  Sun rose beclouded, invisible  Elizabeth C. Adams, dined and spent the day here, and went home this Evening— Her mother went last week to Medford, and is yet there. Charles went to Boston and to Medford, to return with his wife to-morrow— There was a light thunder shower in the course of this day; I had no interruptions of visitors or of business, and yet passed an unprofitable day— I despatched a parcel of my pamphlet discourses, with a Letter to I. K Tefft corresponding Secretary of the Georgia Historical Society, in answer, and return to a Diploma received from him a few days since, as an honorary member of that Society, with the first volume of their Transactions.— My attempts to arrange and assort my files of Letters for the last ten years have as yet only involved them in greater confusion— I have not found the files of 1831. but in assorting alphabetically the files of summer and Autumn of 1834, which on my sudden, and terrible call to Washington to witness the last moments of my dear and ever lamented son John I had left in chaotic disorder here, and had until now, never since inspected, I found, out of place, and time, the very Letter from Charles Follen, 1. Decr. 1831. for which the Letter from Mr Samuel Cabot, received last week had set me, upon the search— I enclosed and despatched it this day to Mr Cabot— I have a Letter from the Revd. Josiah Adams of Parkersburgh Virginia, containing some genealogical enquiries— I began a Letter in answer to him, which I intended should not exceed five lines, but in which I was interrupted to view from Charles’s porch the setting of the Sun; for which, clear and beautiful as it was, I was not quite a Sun’s disk too late. My Miscellaneous and involuntary reading continues desultory as ever— I have now just read Milton’s Areopagitica; A Speech for the Liberty of unlicensed printing—to the Parliament of England— This speech was not delivered but published in 1645. against an order of the Rump Parliament, prohibiting all publications without the imprimatur—published he says as a certain testimony if not a trophy of his Country’s Liberty— [“]For this is not the Liberty which we can hope, that no grievance ever should arise in the Commonwealth, that let no man in this world expect; but when complaints are freely heard, deeply considered and speedily reformed, then is the utmost bound of civil liberty attained that wise men look for.”— The argument against restrictions upon the press is founded on two principles & authority—the practice of all republican Government, before that time having been adverse to such restrictions—and 2. that the corrections of the abuses of the press belong to the pulpit and not to legislation. The style is throughout oratorical, repeatedly addressing the imaginary auditory in the second person— Lords and Commons of England!— The discourse is replete with beautiful imagery, and fortified with cogent argument; though in antiquated language.— The writers and speakers of modern English can derive little benefit from any of the composers of that age, and from none less than from Milton.

25. III:30. Tuesday  Boston— Quincy.  I went to Boston in the Carriage alone, and took with me the 4th. volume of Grahame’s history of the United States to pass the time— I stop’d first at Dr Frothingham’s, but he was not at home— At Charles’s office I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and Charles himself soon after came in from Medford— Mr Spooner was also there— I went with Mr Curtis, to the probate office, where was the judge, Willard Phillips, and Mr Fuller the Administrator upon the Estates of the two Moses Gill’s— A question had remained over upon the allowance by the judge last November of my Account as Administrator de bonis non, with the Will annexed of Thomas Boylston, whether the amount of the Note of the second Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston of 5. Jany 1830. for 984 dollars 78 cents with interest should be deducted from the sum to be paid over by me to the Representative of the Gill’s— Mr Fuller still doubted whether as Administrator, he could consent to this deduction, without making himself liable to the creditors who had claims on the Gill estates. I then made a conditional offer, to relinquish on the part of Mr Boylston, the interest upon the Note amounting to 860:63. and the allowance of 600 dollars made by the judge to me as Administrator, if after deducting the amount of the Note I should be authorised to pay over the remainder to Mr Fuller for the heirs of the last Moses Gill—but I added this was not to be understood if the amount to be paid over by me, would go, not to the last Moses Gill’s heirs, but to claimants upon his or his uncle’s Estates, of the validity or justice of which I knew nothing. The judge urged the acceptance of this offer upon Mr Fuller, and said it could easily be accomplished in legal form—but Mr Fuller declined doing any thing without advice of Counsel— The judge therefore adjourned his decision to some future day, to be notified hereafter— I then went to Mr T. W. Ward’s Office; and returned to his clerk Mr Story, the single order for £10 Sterling, upon the Brothers Baring and Co. London, for which he returned to me the 50 dollar Bill, which he had taken for it— I went to the Store of P. and S. Sprague. 13. Commercial Wharf, and there received a set of three Bills at 3 days sight on the same Baring’s payable to me or my order, and upon which Mr Phineas Sprague gave me 2 dollars and 12 1/2 cents change for the 50 dollar Bill— I attended at Noon a Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, where numerous donations were received and the Chevalier Friederichsthal was elected a foreign member.— I went to Dr Frothingham’s, where I found Mrs Charles, returned from Medford with her daughter Louisa-Catherine— Charles and his wife, returned to Quincy before dinner— I called to see Mr Abbott Lawrence, just returned from the white Sulphur Virginia Springs, with his family very little improved in health.— R. G. Shaw, Dr Sewall of Washington, and Revd. Andrew Bigelow were there. I dined at T. L. Winthrop’s.— Met there Mrs George Sullivan—General Miller from South-America, George Bancroft and about 15 others— Thunder gust— After dinner I took up Charles’s daughter Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s, and returned to Quincy at the dusk of Evening.

26. V:15. Wednesday—  Sun risen. Commencement day.  Mr Loring from Hingham was here this morning with two young girls from Pawtucket visitors at Hingham, one of them a relative of Joseph L. Tillinghast the member of Congress from Rhode-Island— Mr Loring said they had fixed upon the day after tomorrow for the fishing party at Cohasset; and I promised to be at Hingham at 6 or half past 6 that day— I had much conversation yesterday with Mr Bancroft, upon the third volume of his History of the United States which is shortly to come out; and of which he told me that my father would be the hero— But I have learnt to estimate the assurances of Mr Bancroft at their value— I promised to shew him the original Letter of my father to Nathan Webb of October 1755. and the minutes of his journal upon his argument before the Governor and Council on the 18th. of Decr 1765. as one of the Counsel of the Town of Boston, upon their petition for the opening of the Courts of Justice without the use of stamps.— Mrs Lawrence had written me a note, inviting my company at her son’s rooms at Commencement this day— I called at their house yesterday to than her for the invitation, and offer my excuses, not intending to go to commencement— And I gave the same answer to Mr R. G Shaw, who gave me an invitation to the rooms of his Son, also to be graduated this day. I dined this day with my Son, and was conversing with him after dinner upon Plautus and his Translators French and English, when Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in with a copy of a Resolution, which he said had been adopted at a large whig meeting, that a committee be appointed to wait on me, and inform me that it is the wish of the whigs at Quincy, to invite the whigs of the 12th. congressional District, in particular, and the Electors generally to meet with them in Quincy, on an appointed day agreeable to me, to pay their respects to me, and request me, to favour them with an Address on the present state of the country, the present administration of the national government, and the prospects of the whig party— I told Mr Greenleaf that I was greatly obliged to the whigs of the town, for their kind proposal, and especially for the personal accommodation to me intended by calling the meeting here; but that I had already declined attending at a similar meeting to which I had been invited to be held at Rochester in the County of Plymouth, and at many others out of the District— I stated the reasons which had induced me to decline attendance at all the recent meetings considering it a duty resulting from my peculiar situation, and desired him to make them known to the whigs of Quincy, and suggest to them the wish that they would receive this informal answer rather than by sending a formal committee cause the necessity for a written answer from me for publication of my reasons, some of which were rather to be felt than argued— He said he would satisfy the whigs entirely with my answer.— Charles’s wife was very unwell all this day—and could not spend the evening with us— Charles himself did.

27. V. Thursday.  At sun rising— Set in cloud—clear above.  I had intended to go this day to Cambridge, to attend the Boylston prize Declamations and the ΦB.K Oration— But as the time came the spirit failed, and I concluded to stay at home— My purpose was to have improved the hours; but except the record of the last two days, I only finished the reading of Grahame’s History of the United States— The day brought a continual succession of visitors— First Mrs T. Greenleaf with Mrs and a Miss Warren— Then a Messenger with a note from Thomas Adams junr. requesting a Letter of introduction to Mr Cushing of Newburyport, to whom he is to bear a Letter of invitation from the Ladies of Quincy to the Whig Pic Nic here, next Thursday— I gave the Letter and then called and made a deposit at the Quincy Stone Bank— Returning home I stop’d at Charles’s house to see his wife who was quite unwell— She was in her chamber, on her couch, but bearing up in spirits— Mary was with her— Charles gone to Boston, but returned to dine.— After dinner visits from Edward and Mrs Brooks and their niece Miss Wells—short— But they passed the afternoon at Charles’s— Then the two Misses Baxter— Their mother and their Sister Mrs Lee, are both much indisposed— Two wandering travellers from Easton, Pennsylvania followed; came to see me and the rocky ledges and railway; the curiosities of the place— Nightengale introduced himself and his companion by the name of Heim, or Hinds— Next came Thomas J. Noyes— He says he lives on Penn’s Hill in Braintree. He left with me a copy of a Petition, of his Grandmother Mary Pike of Bennington Genessee County, New-York, for a Pension, as widow and relict of Simeon Pike of Haverhill, Massachusetts who was killed at the Battle of Bunker’s Hill 17. June 1775. He had been enlisted for eight months but was killed before he had served six months— The father of this Thomas J. Noyes, married the daughter of Mrs Pike, and she now lives with him— The Petition has already been presented to the House, and I promised if I live to attend the next Session of Congress to call it up, and have it referred, with the authenticated vouchers, to the Committee on Revolutionary pensions, and to do all in my power to obtain the pension for this poor woman who is now 87. years old and a cripple. Dr. Woodward was here to visit Louisa C. Smith, who is again seriously indisposed— In the Evening, Elizabeth C. Adams was here, with her brother the Midshipman andFoster— Her mother has returned from Medford also unwell— Charles was also here, but his wife was confined at home.

28. III. Friday.  Hingham. Cohasset. Fishing party— Quincy—  At half past five this morning, I left home in a Gig, with my son, and went to Mr Thomas Loring’s at Hingham where we breakfasted; with him and a Mr and Mrs Sprague living in his house; another young woman was also there, and the two little girls who came with him to Quincy on Wednesday. After breakfast I went with Mr Loring in his Gig, and the Revd. Mr Stearns with my Son to the small shed at Cohasset, whence we had been upon a fishing party last Summer. A small party soon assembled there now, and six or eight of us embarked from the rocks in a good sized Sail-boat and went out between four and five miles from the shore, and fished for cod and haddock—we changed our position once and caught about 30 fishes, of which I took nine.— At one O’Clock we brought the boat round and returned to the rocks. I should have liked much to continue fishing three hours longer, but the rest of the company were weary and sharp set for dinner, and impatient to return, to which I interposed no obstacle— The Revd. Mr Stearns, Minister of the Parish where Mr Charles Brooks was settled, Dr. John Brazer of Salem with his twin sons John and William, boys about twelve years of age, were of our party— The Chowder dinner company at the shed were about 30 in number among whom were Solomon, and Jotham and Jairus Lincoln, Edward Thaxter James C Doane and others whose names I could not retain— The Revd. Dr W. P. Greenwood, seemed to be in the last stage of a consumption.— After the chowder and some general conversation, I walked an hour with Dr Brazer and Mr Loring to and upon the beach; on returning from which we had a second dinner of fried fish and lemonade, after which I returned with Mr Loring to his house at Hingham, where by his invitation the whole company repaired together with Mr Josiah Quincy junr. and his Son Josiah, who had come at 6 in the evening instead of 6 in the morning, as he had been invited— We took tea at Mr Loring’s and with the light of a bright Aurora Borealis returned home, and alighted at my gate just before the 9. O’Clock Evening Bell.— There was a cold morning fog barely sufficient to discolour the Sun till we reached Cohasset—then a clear sky, smooth water and alternate calm and cool eastern breeze, barely enough to curl the surface of the glass; as fine an autumnal day as the earth ever rolled round her axis— The distant shores of Gloucester and Cape Ann and Gloucester, and the Light house at the entrance of Boston harbour on one side, and the Scituate meeting house on the other bounded the horizon, with the boundless Ocean, dotted with numerous spots of white canvas all over the scene— Mr Loring and Solomon Lincoln told me that the abolitionists of the 12th. Congressional District had held a meeting last Tuesday at Hanover twelve persons present and nominated Seth Sprague junr. as their Candidate for the 27th Congress— That the administration party would nominate John B. Turner, and that Joseph Morton Jackson the old Candidate for the present Congress would be set aside to his sore disappointment.

29. III:45 Saturday  This Mr Bradley, from New-Haven, Connecticut is a travelling Book-peddler, a very common occupation in New England— He brought with him Barber’s historical collections—of Massachusetts—a useful work of minute geography and history of which I gave my name as a subscriber, and took a copy— Mr John Whitney called, and thanked me for my contribution, upon the occasion of the fire which last autumn consumed his house.— He said it had been so heavy a blow to him at the time, that he had been almost discouraged; but he had now got upon his feet again, and was doing pretty well. I planted in the seminary the plumstones of the fruit brought from Mr Downing’s at Newburgh by Elizabeth C. Adams; and the four stones of the early Ann peach which we have this year from the tree— Mr Thomas P. Beal alighted from the Plymouth stage and spent an hour with me under great political excitement— The whole country throughout the Union is in a state of agitation upon the approaching presidential election such as was never before witnessed.— From the organization of the Government under the present Constitution of the United States, the nominations of Candidates for the Office of President were made in Caucus Convention by members of Congress—and by the members of the State Legislatures. The Congressional Caucus nomination of 1824 was in favour of William H. Crawford, and signally failed.— The State Legislature nominations produced only cross purposes; and have been superseded by party popular conventions, increasing in numbers till that of last May at Baltimore of the young men, to confirm the nomination of W. H. Harrison made before, by a select Caucus Convention at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, last December, amounted it was said to twenty thousand delegates— This has been followed by numerous assemblages in all the States where the opposition is in any strength, and not a week has passed within the last four months without a convocation of thousands of people, to hear inflammatory harangues against Martin Van Buren and his administration, by Henry Clay, Daniel Webster, and all the principal opposition Orators in or out of Congress— I received earnest invitations to attend these Meetings and address the People at Nashville, Tennessee, Chillicothe Ohio, Wheeling Virginia, Baltimore, Alexandria, Georgetown, and many other places, all of which I declined both from general principles and from considerations specially and peculiarly applicable to myself— One of these assemblies was held yesterday by a public dinner given to Caleb Cushing by some of his constituents at Newburyport, and a Ball in the evening by him to them— I was invited also there but did not attend— Mr Webster and Mr Saltonstall were there, and a stump speech scaffold, and it is said a procession of 6000 people or more, and a dinner of 1800. Here is a revolution in the habits and manners of the people— Where will it end? These are party movements, and must in the natural progress of things become antagonistical— At the Baltimore meeting one of the marshals of the procession was killed upon the spot— These meetings cannot be multiplied in numbers and frequency without resulting in yet deeper tragedies— Their manifest tendency is to civil war.

30. IV. Sunday.  Sun rose and set beclouded— Fair day.  Mr Lunt though much indisposed performed all the services of both parts of this day. His morning text was from 1. Corinthians 6:20—glorify God in your body, and in your Spirit, which are God’s— A Dissertation to show how it is possible for so poor a creature as man to glorify God— By his natural disposition, his experience of the world, his failure of success in his struggles for a respected standing in society, his infirm and alarming state of health, the prospects of a destitute family to survive him, and the warnings of history. Mr Lunt has not a very favourable opinion of mankind; and being of a meek and quiet Spirit, he thinks of himself almost as humbly as of mankind generally— Piety, tenderness, benevolence, with a tinge of melancholy pervade all his Sermons, but I have never been more affected and pleased with any discourse of his than this afternoon when his text was from Ruth 1.16. “And Ruth said, Entreat me not to leave thee, or to return from following after thee: for whither thou goest, I will go; and where thou lodgest I will lodge: thy people shall be my people, and thy God my God. 17. Where thou diest will I die, and there will I be buried: the Lord do so to me, and more also, if aught but death part thee and me.”— Mr Lunt began by remarking on the peculiar character of the Book of Ruth as distinguished from all the other books of the Scriptures— He said the Bible was generally spoken of as one book; but it was a collection of many books, of very different descriptions— He then enumerated the historical, poetical, prophetical books of the old Testament, the books of Job and of the Proverbs, without mentioning the Ecclesiastes or the Song of Solomon; but considered this Book of Ruth as differing from all the rest— I consider it as belonging to the historical class, an appendage to the book of Judges, and as most essential in tracing the genealogy of David and Solomon, and of Jesus Christ— Mr Lunt dwelt upon the transcendent excellence of the character of Ruth—upon her admirable fidelity and affectionate attachment to her mother in Law—upon her fortitude in the endurance of extreme indigence; upon her active exertions in gleaning the fields for the subsistence of Naomi—and he descanted upon the wonderful vicissitudes of human events in raising from this woman of the detested race of Moab, in the deepest wretchedness of poverty, reduced to glean from a harvested field for daily bread, David and Solomon, kings of unrivalled magnificence and glory; and Jesus the Saviour of Mankind— He finally pointed the moral of his discourse, by exhorting his hearers of both sexes, and of all ages, but especially the young, to emulate those virtues which, exerted in the humblest condition of life under the severest trials with which human nature was ever afflicted, have crowned with unfading glory the name of an obscure Moabitish woman, to be revered through a thousand generations throughout the civilized world— Evening visits from Mrs Miller; her son, and Elizabeth C. Adams, Mr Beale and his daughters and E. Price Greenleaf.

31. IV:30. Monday.  Sun rose 5:23— Set 6.37. both beclouded.  Preparations for departure on our voyage to Halifax, Nova Scotia— Mr Curtis came over from Jamaica Plains to concert arrangements for our voyage.— I despatched a Letter, and a parcel of pamphlets to the Revd Josiah Adams of Parkersburg, Virginia, and a Letter to Mr Thomas Adams junr to apologize for my non-attendance, at the Norfolk County, whig Ladies Pic Nic next Thursday. There was an advertisement in this Morning’s Boston Newspapers requesting that the Passengers by the Steamer Acadia should be on board, by half past 10. to-morrow morning, and that their baggage should be sent on board this evening. but Mr Curtis said Captain Miller had told him he should leave the wharf punctually at noon.— Dijah Bowen came for his papers relating to his claim in the right of Rene Gedeon, to bounty Lands, for enlistment in the Legion of franks at New-Orleans, in February 1814. I thought and told Mr Bowen that I had left his papers on a file at Washington, to be sent round by water to Boston; but after he was gone I found the papers, and a Letter of 30 December 1839. from William Gordon, chief clerk of the Bounty Land-Office to me, adverse to the claim.— I made up a packet of all the papers, and enclosed them to Mr Bowen— DrBowditch and MrBarnard came out from Boston this afternoon and repeated an invitation renewed from last year, and which I had some weeks since received from the Warren street Association, to deliver the introductory Lecture to their course for the approaching Season.— Without positively declining, I referred them to a definitive answer after my return from my proposed excursion.— The Revd. Mr Cornell was here this Evening with youngWood; for whom I made application for a Cadet’s warrant for June 1841. when Zealous B. Tower is to vacate the place of Cadet from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— The young man is exceedingly anxious to obtain the appointment; and I promised to do all in my power to obtain it for him; giving him fair warning of the crosses, and difficulties and dangers and pernicious temptations of the life that he was aspiring to encounter, and fervently exhorted him if he should persist in his purpose and obtain the appointment, to use all his exertions to make good the place of his predecessor, who for three successive years and ever since his admission has been at the head of his class— My wife was much indisposed all this day and evening— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— Miss Henshaw came out from Boston and is to stay with his wife during his absence— I spent the Evening at his house. Louisa C. Smith is sickening into the same state in which she was last Autumn, and is attended by Dr Woodward.

properties.dateline: Boston— Steamer Acadia. Tuesday 1. September 1840. At Sea
properties.text: 1. IV. Tuesday  Went into Boston in the Carriage, with my Son, his wife and Son Charles— Stop’d at Dr Frothingham’s— Then Mrs Charles went with me to Chaffin’s shop, and chose for me two black Stocks, according to order. Then at Charles’s Office alone— Found Mr Curtis there— Degrand came in and gave me some Newspapers— Snarl between Henry Clay and Andrew Jackson— Queer correspondence between Daniel Webster and Nicholas Biddle; about National and State Bankruptcy, and the examples of France and England— I had received a note from Lieutenant Sturges of the Revenue Cutter, offering to take me in his barge from India wharf to the Steamer— Degrand promised me to return my thanks to Lieutenant Sturges, and to make my apology for not accepting his offer— Return with Charles to Dr Frothingham’s.— Took leave of him, Mrs Frothingham, their son Thomas, Harriet Welsh and Mrs Charles; and Jeremy Leary took Charles and me in the Carriage to the Winisimet or East-Boston steam ferry boat. There we left Jerry and the Carriage to return home, and went over in a Hack from the Tremont House; and embarked in the British and North-American Royal mail Steam packet Acadia Captain Edward C. Miller, bound to Halifax Nova-Scotia, and Liverpool England— We met there 34 other passengers, all entire strangers to us, except a Son (George) of Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, going to England, and whom his father had accompanied to take leave of him at the ship— Josiah Quincy junr. Benjamin Russell, and W. W. Clapp. Mr Isaac T Smith gave me his card, and repeated an invitation. I had some time since received to deliver a Lecture next November before the New-York Lyceum. I said I had delayed answering the former application from unwillingness to decline and uncertainty whether I could comply with it. I feared this would not be in my power, but I would send a definitive answer after my return from this excursion— Mr Curtis was already on board the boat, and my trunk which Gillet the Stageman had brought in from Quincy; and sent on board— Two minutes before 12 O’Clock the Mail came on board, and the boat immediately cast off from her moorings at the wharf—passed by the Columbus line of battle ship lying in the stream, and glided down the bay with smooth water beneath, a gentle breeze around, and a glowing Sun above, at the rate of 9 1/2 knots an hour.— The wharf at East Boston whence we parted, and the line of wharves on the western side of the stream were crowded with Spectators, cheering with shouts the Steamer as she passed along The Steamers John W. Richmond, and General Lincoln, thronged with passengers escorted her down, the latter to just below Castle Island, the former to point Alderton and the Light at the entrance of the harbour, where they respectively took leave of her with reciprocated huzzas and returned to the City— And now vogue la Galere, East North East for Cape Sable; and before dark we had lost sight of the Boston State house, the blue hills, the Northern shores of Marblehead,—Gloucester and Cape-Ann, the South shore of Cohasset, Scituate and Marshfield; and were floating on the boundless expanse of waters— The day and Evening continued fair—the Sunset not altogether unclouded, but with a clear sky above— At 10 I retired to my berth N. 56. and turned in for the Night.

3. IV:15 Thursday  I slept little, and from about two in the morning lying in my berth, heard the Pilot on the fore-castle giving his steering orders to the helmsman— Shortly after 3. a gun was fired upon deck which was returned from the shore; and just at 4. the boat was moored to the wharf at Halifax. I rose immediately, and as daylight came on viewed the river and harbour, and the opposite shore, where the small town of Dartmouth in a valley between the slopes of two hills covered with forests of pines forms a picturesque landscape— Halifax itself, like our towns of Haverhill, and New-London, and Georgetown, ranges along in streets ascending like stairs in lines parallel to the course of the river— As the Sun rose, Mr Samuel Cunard and his Son Edward came onboard, and invited us to breakfast with him at 8. In the meantime we landed and took lodgings at the Masonic Hall, kept by a man named Coblentz, said to be the best house of entertainment in the town— We breakfasted at Mr Cunard’s and there saw his four handsome daughters, one of whom two days since was married to a Captain of the 37th. Regiment, named Franklyn.— We here met also for the last time, and took leave of Captain Edward C. Miller, a Lieutenant in the British Navy, and Commander of the Royal Steam packet Acadia.— Half an hour after breakfast, Mr Cunard took us in his chariot, and introduced us to His Excellency Sir Colin Campbell, Lieutenant Governor, of the British Province of Nova-Scotia; who received us politely and invited us to dine with him at 7 this evening— The weather had become stormy, and the rain confined us some hours at the inn, which I was enabled to employ in writing. We met for one moment at the door of the inn Coll. Butler, who had been in 1816 one of the Schoolmates of my Sons at Ealing.— He was now about to embark in the Acadia, as a passenger to Liverpool. I had through the day a number of visitors, inhabitants of the town, and full of kind and courteous hospitality— Among them Mr Archibald, Attorney General and Speaker of the provincial house of Assembly, who was going immediately upon professional business to Cape-Breton; Mr John Fairbanks, son of a refugee from Framingham Massachusetts—Mr James Leander Starr, with whose Lady and her Sister, Miss Throckmorton of New-York, and a little daughter of Mrs Starr. I took a ride of an hour and a half in an open Barouche, in a circle of the country round the town— At 7. Mr Cunard came and took Mr Curtis and me in his Carriage to the Governors to dine. But my Son had been taken, with a severe sick head ache; and could not go with us— The dinner was splendid—served altogether on plate.— The company, eighteen chiefly military officers all in full uniform—Sir Colin wearing the Star of the Bath and the Medallion of Waterloo— Lord Charles Fitzroy appointed Governor of Prince Edward’s Island was there en bourgeois with Lady Mary his wife, another Lady, and a Son and daughter of Sir Colin. Between 9 and 10. a messenger came with advice that the Canadian Mails and Passengers had arrived from Picton, and that the Acadia was unmooring to depart for Liverpool, whereupon Mr Cunard and one of the guests were called out, and Mr Curtis and I took leave of Sir Colin and returned to our Inn.

4. V. Friday  The Steamer Unicorn was to have arrived here yesterday at 3. P.M with the Mails and Passengers from Quebec and Prince Edward’s Island, to go by the Acadia for Liverpool— She was to have departed hence this day to return to Quebec at Noon, and we had proposed to take passage in her.— Lord Charles Fitzroy with his family are here waiting to take passage in the Unicorn, to be landed at Charlottes town on Prince Edward’s Island— But on her passage from Quebec down the river Saint Lawrence she took ground and was detained twelve hours— Her Mails, and passengers were landed at Picton, and came thence by land 102 1/2 miles— They arrived at 9 last Evening and at 1/2 past 11. the Acadia departed for Liverpool— The Unicorn arrived at 8. this morning, and we were flattering ourselves that we should embark in her at Noon for Quebec. But her Engine took some damage by her grounding in the river, and she is detained here for a survey and repairs at least until next Tuesday; and perhaps longer. She is then to take Lord Fitzroy to his Government of Prince Edward’s Island, but will not proceed to Quebec until after the arrival from Liverpool here of the Britannia, expected on the 15th.— Our expedition to Quebec is therefore blown up, and we are put to our shifts to get home as we may— I had many kind visitors again this day among whom Mr Joseph Howe, and Mr Thomas Forrester, representatives of the County and town of Halifax in the general House of Assembly. Mr Howe invited us to dine with him at 6. O’Clock, and in the mean time they both took us a ride of nine miles to the head of the bay which runs up above Halifax, navigable, all the way up— Before going I called with my Son upon Mr Sampson Salter Blowers—a refugee from Boston—said to have turned shortly since, his hundredth birthday— He was the official prosecutor as the King’s attorney defender at Boston of Captain Preston and the Soldiers indicted for the Massacre of the 5th. of March 1770. of whom my father and Josiah Quincy were with him the Official defenders—the lawyers in that prosecution, on both sides sustaining the party to which they were opposed of Preston and the Soldiers— Mr Blowers came from Boston with the British troops, and never returned.— He is one of the Patriarchs of the Province of Nova-Scotia, and was successively Chief Justice of the Superior Court after being Attorney General, Speaker of the House of Assembly, Councillor, and sometime acting Governor— He is now in retirement, said to be wealthy, enjoying bodily health, but with all the faculties of the mind impaired— He received us courteously, and thanked us for calling upon him. I told him I was the son of John Adams whom he formerly knew, but he made no answer— I introduced my Son to him and he enquired what was his age. I said we had arrived in the Steamer Acadia from Boston; he said that was his native place, and he had always retained his affection for it, and rejoiced in its prosperity— He had said it would prosper, and believed it was now the most prosperous place in North-America; and this place was the next— We dined with Mr Howe— His wife a Mrs Godfrey, Mr Howe’s brother, Mr Forrester and Mr Bell the other member from Halifax in the House of Assembly, were of the company— Mr Howe accompanied us to our lodgings, and gave us a Letter of introduction toHaliburton, author of Sam Slick, residing at Windsor, for which we took seats in the Stage to depart at 6 to-morrow morning.

5. V. Saturday  Disappointed in the purpose of embarking in the Unicorn for Quebec, we concluded to return home, by the way of Annapolis and the Province of New-Brunswick.— We took the Stage first for Windsor, and left our lodgings at the Masonic Hall, at 6 this morning with four travelling companions; Mr John Frothingham a native of New-England, and merchant of Montreal in Canada, with his son Frederic a youth of about 17. and a Bostonian namedsettled as a merchant at Mayaguez in the Island of Porto Rico, about 30 years of age, with his wife, travelling for their health.— We came to Windsor 45 Miles from Halifax in three Stages of 17. 15. and 13 miles with the same Carriage and driver twice changing horses— We reached Windsor about 1. P.M. but found no Steamer there nor any expectation of one before next Tuesday—wherefore, we determined to proceed immediately, and came on 13 miles to Gasperaux river and ten miles further to Kentville, which is a part of the township of Horton. We landed just at Sunset having travelled 68 miles, in one Carriage, and with one driver— The first forty miles of the road are nearly one continued forest of what the Germans call needle wood trees—white and pitch pine, cedar, spruce, fir and Larch; with intermixture of white and yellow, birch, beech, maple, and here and there, red and grey Oak— Many of the trees were tall and straight, but none of them large— The soil generally sand or rock, with few settlements on the road— One country seat between Halifax and Windsor, belonging to the Honourable Thomas Nickleson Jeffery the Senior member of the Executive Council, was the only mansion the elegance of which and of the ground around it, indicated opulence— Scarcely one village on the road—but at distances of a quarter or half mile from each other single farm-houses with elderly looking barns, were surrounded with green pastures, indifferent apple-orchards, a stout and strong breed of horned cattle; a few sorry horses, pigs and swine of ordinary size— Turkies and ducks not remarkable—fine looking and numerous flocks of geese, and dunghill fowls in abundance— Very few ragged and no squalid looking persons, and no beggars— The general aspect is of a healthy quiet and contented population. The children especially remarkable for fair complections handsome faces, and rosy cheeks— On approaching Windsor, and part of the way thence to Kentville, the soil is more fertile; the country much more cleared of wood and the farms more productive— The recollection that Halifax leaves upon the mind of the traveller, is of a very moderately prospering, and not enterprizing city. A garrison of three regiments of infantry 8th. 23d. and 37th. with a Corps of Artillery and of Engineers, gives it the appearance of a City besieged, and the accomodations for the army and navy account for its population, much more than any of its adaptations for commercial enterprize which are very small. As we stop’d at Windsor only to change our horses we had no opportunity to deliver our Letter of introduction to judge Haliburton— At Windsor we saw a large ship of 600 tons upon the Stocks— It is one of the Ports upon the bay of Fundy, in Steam boat communication with St. Johns, New Brunswick.

Saturday  Disappointed in the purpose of embarking in the Unicorn for Quebec, we concluded to return home, by the way of Annapolis and the Province of New-Brunswick.— We took the Stage first for Windsor, and left our lodgings at the Masonic Hall, at 6 this morning with four travelling companions; Mr John Frothingham a native of New-England, and merchant of Montreal in Canada, with his son Frederic a youth of about 17. and a Bostonian namedsettled as a merchant at Mayaguez in the Island of Porto Rico, about 30 years of age, with his wife, travelling for their health.— We came to Windsor 45 Miles from Halifax in three Stages of 17. 15. and 13 miles with the same Carriage and driver twice changing horses— We reached Windsor about 1. 6. V. Sunday  The Stages in this Province do not travel on the Sabbath and we were necessarily detained here this day; much to my satisfaction, for I was glad to escape from the overflowing civilities of Halifax, before we could be made conscious that they were burdensome to those who paid them, and as time advances, I long more and more for one day of repose in seven— After breakfast this morning my first enquiry was for a Church where we might attend public worship and were informed of a presbyterian Church two miles and an episcopal church four miles distant both in the town of Cornwallis, and of a methodist church nearer, where there would be service in the afternoon— Sallying out to walk to the presbyterian church we soon met Mr Thomas Hardy a Scotchman and keeper of the public school at Kentville, who walked some way with us, and Mr James D. Harris a judge of the inferior Court and Sessions of the Peace for King’s County who overtook us in his gig, and invited me to take a seat with him, which I did. He took me to the episcopal church, where he and his family attend, and where the Revd. H. L. Owen read the morning service of the Church of England for the 12th. Sunday after trinity and preached a short Sermon from Habakkuk 2.15. “Wo unto him that giveth his neighbour drink, that puttest thy bottle to him, and makest him drunken also, that thou mayest look on their nakedness.” (mark the grammatical transposition of persons, to the verbs—) a plain and sensible discourse against drunkenness, in which the obvious arguments against that vice, were illustrated by quotations from Scripture preceptive and exemplary; not excepting Noah, Lot, and David.— The preachers reading and delivery were very monotonous and sluggish— The Congregation was small but of respectable appearance— Judge Harris’s wife and part of his family were there. He has six sons and three daughters.— His father was one of the refugee, or as they prefer to be called loyalist settlers of Nova-Scotia in 1783. immediately after the close of the revolutionary War— Mr Harris came from Connecticut, a child—he is a judge, and a private Banker; but he told me he had never been a member of the assembly, nor offered himself as a candidate; having no relish for public life. Mr Owen is settled in the neighbouring town of Aylesford; but was accidentally at Cornwallis, returning from a visit to Halifax— He gave notice that there would be divine service at this Church this day fortnight. Judge Harris took me home in his gig, with his son William a boy about 8 years old.— My companions stopped at the Presbyterian church. I had scarcely returned to our inn, when a Doctor W. B. Webster called and invited me with Mr Curtis and my son to ride with him in his Carryall to see a dam and sluice in Cornwallis constructed at an expence of 5000 pounds currency to dike out the waters of the river. we accordingly took the ride and then took tea at his fathers house where he resides. The father is a loyalist emigrant from Connecticut, and a tory of the first water as is a younger brother—he himself is of the popular party— We returned about 10. to our inn.

7. V. Monday.  Our Stage carriage and driver were both changed this morning to our disadvantage, but the substitutes brought us safely in the course of the day from Kentville to Annapolis, 60 miles, over a road the first part of which was heavy with sand, and the last hilly and studded with rocks; but altogether a very good road— We had besides our company from Halifax, an outside passenger taken up on Saturday at Windsor, and Mr John Whidden, Clerk of the House of Assembly, and now a Candidate for election as a member of the house—for there is an election to be held in November, and we are told that it will be generally and warmly contested— The Government and popular parties are strongly marked and ardently opposed to each other— Dr Webster told us last Evening that his father and brother were Government men, but that he was of the popular party— This Dr Webster is what the French call an original, and the English an oddity. Curiosity and mobility seem to be the characteristics of his temper, without depths of observation or brilliancy of imagination— His motive for taking us to see the Cornwallis dam yesterday, with the invitation to tea at his father’s house, must have been pure kindness and hospitality— He has a taste also for natural history, and shewed us a number of birds stuffed and minerals indigenous in this Province; all collected by himself. We left Kentville which is a part of the township of Horton, named from the late Duke of Kent, after his death at half past 6 this morning, with an accession of two outside passengers to our company, and an exchange of a very good carriage for one of doubtful solidity and unpromising appearance; but which brought us however safely to Annapolis with the setting Sun— The first stage was of 17 miles to Crane’s, that being the name of the man who keeps the house—there we had a good breakfast, and the house though standing alone had a neat and comfortable aspect— The sound of a spinning wheel in a room adjoining to that where we breakfasted brought back sixty years or more of reminiscences familiar to my childhood, but which from that time have never been revived— To my Son it was an unwonted and unpleasant sound, but to Mr Curtis it was as to me a pleasing revival of incidents in early life long since passed away.— From this place we proceeded by a stage of 12 miles to Gibbons; another of 17 miles to Bridgetown, a small and neat looking village, but where there was no dinner in preparation for Stage passengers, and we took up with a collation or lunch of bread and cheese and a bottle of nut brown ale— Here we crossed a lofty bridge, necessarily so from the common rise and fall of the river at the place which is of more than thirty feet of the tide from the bay of Fundy— Our last stage of the day was 15 miles to Annapolis, the Old French Settlement of Port Royal, and formerly the chief town in the Province. properties.dateline: Annapolis, Nova Scotia— St. John, New-Brunswick 8 September 1840.
properties.text: 8. V. Tuesday  Our ride yesterday was through a country much resembling that which he had traversed on Saturday— The first part over a heavy sand, and the latter part, through pine clad hills, interspersed with fertile vallies and solitary farmhouses around which we seldom failed to see oxen and cows of large size and in good condition— Fine looking sheep— Flocks of Turkies, Geese and dunghill fowls in abundance— Swine, not so numerous; nor of breeds so choice, yet good looking. Altogether the appearance of the Country, much like that of the interior of Massachusetts sixty years ago— This morning before our departure a gentleman called on me at the inn, and announced himself as a Son of my old and valued friend Benjamin Pickman, heretofore of Salem, now residing in Boston— He has been settled here, he told me about eight years in consequence of having married a Lady of this place, or as Mr Curtis conjectures because he inherited some of his Grandfather Pickman’s sentiments and opinions— We met here also last evening a Scottish Gentleman of the name of Smith, with his arm in a sling from some recent accident, with which I sympathised, according to Swift’s But should some neighbour feel a pain, just in the parts where I complain &c— He told us he had crossed the atlantic 13 times; one of which last year in the British Queen. He was visited while we were at supper by a young man, collector at the Port of Digby, a nephew of Sir Colin Campbell; and who came down with us in the Steamer this morning to that place, where he landed as did several other passengers, while others came on board there— Among them was a tall elderly, cheerless looking Indian, and a young stout, handsome, active ship carpenter from the settlement at Clare about twelve miles from Digby, the still existing remnants of the old Acadian neutral French— We anchored for about an hour at Digby 18 miles from Annapolis whence we had departed, between 7. and 8 this morning— The collector of the Port, brought on board, and lent us Thomas C. Haliburton’s History of Nova-Scotia, which he had casually mentioned in conversation with Mr Frothingham— He requested that the books might be left with Captain Hennenbury, in the Steam boat, to be returned to him when she came back. I would have purchased the books, but he had not a copy to spare— I occupied no small portion of the passage across the Bay of Fundy, in turning over the pages of the first Volume of this Book— The passage between Annapolis and Digby is a narrow basin, like a river broken in from the Bay of Fundy, through a passage between two rocky cliffs not half a mile wide or long. The course from this gap over the Bay of Fundy to St. John is directly North 36 miles.— We had left Kentville yesterday morning, with rain and mist and dark smoky clouds hanging over the sides of all the hills, but it cleared away by noon, and we had a clear night at Annapolis, and a bright Sun this morning— We opened upon the Bay of Fundy about 11. A.M. and could barely discern the opposite coast of New-Brunswick like far off mountains turning into clouds. The Steamer maid of the mist is small and slow and growing old; but the day was fair and without fog, though clouding up, and with a freshening breeze till 5 p.m. when we landed at the wharf in the City of St. John. The gradual receding of the Coast of Nova-Scotia, with the corresponding rise and approach of that of New-Brunswick had a pleasing effect upon the spirits but the rapid tides of the Bay produced a swell which with the briskness of the breeze sickened some of our passengers— A family from Boston a man, his wife, and five boys, from 4 to 12 years old, were among them. We took our lodgings at the St John’s Hotel. named La Hain—

9. IV:30. Wednesday.  I rose this morning an hour before day-light, and wrote till breakfast time, immediately after which Mr A. W. Whipple, and Mr M. H. Perley, inhabitants of the City, visited us, and offered their services, to shew us any of its objects of curiosity.— They took us first to the Officers barracks of the 69th. regiment of British infantry which is stationed at this place. They introduced us to Captain Blackburne the Senoir Captain in command The Colonel being upon a tour in the States, and now at Boston; and the Major gone home to England on leave— Captain Blackburne is a modest and very gentlemanly man, of pleasing deportment, and courteous manners, without affectation, studiously but not fawningly civil— He and several Officers with him shewed us the barracks of the soldiers; their mode of living, their muskets, which he said were not equal to ours, and the curious furniture of their knapsacks, a list of the articles composing which I was tempted to ask, to compare with ours, but refrained— We saw the apartments in which the Soldiers lodge, six, eight or ten in a room, the apartment where they mess—the kitchen where their food is cooked, and the meat and vegetables, in preparation for their dinner.— All which was neat, cleanly, economical, and comfortable— Also the hospital where in two chambers were the sick men in their beds; one of the chambers containing only the cases of ophthalmia which Captain Blackburne told us was a disease more common among the troops than all others put together. He took us also to the room where the musical band were practicing under the direction of the band master; and they regaled us with several beautiful marches and airs conducting with Kate Kearney— From the Barracks we went to the reading room where our names were entered—to the building now in process of erection for a City Hall and Exchange, and to the foundations laid for a large Custom-house— Mr Whipple then took Mr Curtis and me, [(]while Charles staid behind to write a letter home) to a saw-mill on the river two miles above the City, where we saw the operations of sawing logs in to boards and blocks into shingles— On our return to the Hotel, we were visited by multitudes of the Citizens of the place, among whom the Recorder, who in the absence of the Mayor welcomed me to the City, with an offer of a public dinner which I declined, as we are to depart to morrow Morning.— We dined with Captain Blackburne, and the Officers of the 69th. regiment at their barracks about 20 in number, among whom the names of Dalgetty and Kearney, and a Lieutenant Lord Glamis, son of the Earl of Strathmore were the only ones that I remember— Mr Whipple was the only stranger except ourselves.— They toasted the Queen and the President of the United States— Captain Blackburne complimented me, for which I returned thanks and gave the 69th. Regiment, and then the Duke of Wellington— We came home before 11.

10. IV:30. Thursday  At 1/2 past 6 this morning we left the City of St John literally built upon a rock, and said now to contain upwards of 33 thousand inhabitants— We came in a Coach from the inn, to Indian town two miles above the City; and there embarked in the Steamer New-Brunswick, and ascended the river St. John to Fredericton, the seat of Government of the Province 90 Miles— There was a heavy rain all the morning, and the boat was detained a full hour by falling foul of a raft close above the wharf whence we departed— The course of the river is first North, then North-east, then North, Northwest and North North West about 12 or 13 miles each town—about half way up lies on the western bank of the river, Gagetown, named I suppose from General Gage, and the only village settlement, between the City and the seat of Government. The Banks of the river near St. John are on both sides steep—lofty and precipitous rocks covered with seemingly impenetrable forests, but after the first turn the hills fall a way to distances sometimes of a mile or more with intervale lands of great fertility with solitary farm houses, small barns and stacks of hay piled upon stakes to preserve them from the tides— The face of the river’s banks all the way poor but comfortable—the landscapes fair and varied but neither endowed by nature with sublimity nor cultivated into the beauty of art; between Gagetown and the eastern bank there is an island, which interrupts it from the view so that we saw it only from below and from above.— About 7 miles below Fredericton, there is another Island with a shoal and a bar, which goes wholly across the river, and where the water is so shallow that our boat touched the ground and rubbed over it— There were as passengers in the boat, named Babbit and Worden, men approaching 70. both of whom came with their fathers; loyalists from New-York in 1783— Also Major Cairnes of the 37th regiment stationed at Fredericton who introduced himself to me with numerous civilities and kind attentions—he introduced me to Mrs Shore, a Lady of elegant manners and accomplishments wife of a civil and military officer of high distinction in the Province, also a passenger in the boat—as were Captain Ross of the 37th. regiment and several other Officers— We landed at Fredericton just after Sunset, and took lodgings at Jackson’s Hotel; where within half an hour, I received a note from his Excellency Sir John Harvey, Major General, and Lieutenant Governor of the Province of New-Brunswick, with the most obliging offers of service, horses and a kind invitation to us to dine with him to-morrow— Charles answered his note with many thanks and acceptance of his invitation to dinner— We found at Jackson’s hotel Signor Blitz, who gave us tickets of admission to his exhibition of ventriloquism, and of leger de main. We accordingly took tickets and attended— As we returned to the Hotel we were met by Captain Tryon, the Governor’s Aid de Camp and Son in Law—with a second note of invitation, and offer of a Carriage, and we promised to call on the Governor at 11. to morrow morning— We received also an invitation from Major Cairnes and the Officers of the 37th Regiment to dine with them the day after to-morrow.

Thursday  At 1/2 past 6 this morning we left the City of St John literally built upon a rock, and said now to contain upwards of 33 thousand inhabitants— We came in a Coach from the inn, to Indian town two miles above the City; and there embarked in the Steamer New-Brunswick, and ascended the river St. John to Fredericton, the seat of Government of the Province 90 Miles— There was a heavy rain all the morning, and the boat was detained a full hour by falling foul of a raft close above the wharf whence we departed— The course of the river is first North, then North-east, then North, Northwest and North North West about 12 or 13 miles each town—about half way up lies on the western bank of the river, Gagetown, named I suppose from General Gage, and the only village settlement, between the City and the seat of Government. 11. VI. Friday  Early this morning we had a visit from Mr Black, Mayor of St John who expressed his regret that he had been accidentally here, absent from the city, while we were there; and where he would have been happy to have shewn us any attentions, which could make our visit to the place agreeable. He embarked to return home this morning— We had visits also last Evening, and this morning from six or seven Indians two of whom named John Francis—and Neptune—were of our Passamaquoddy tribe, and the rest of the St. John’s or Micmac tribe within this province. They had all been to a general gathering of Indian tribes held in Canada, last month at the invitation of the British Canadian Government for the preservation of Peace. John Francis is the Governor of the Passamaquoddy Indians, and Neptune, who speaks a little English acted as interpreter. They wanted a certificate or paper in the nature of a Passport from me, and said last Night that they were to have one this morning from Sir John Harvey— I asked Neptune if they had got their certificate from Sir John this morning— He said he was too busy.— I told him that I had been, but was no longer a Chief in my own Country, and that a certificate or passport from me, would be of no sort of use to them— The paper of advice from the Canadian Indians which they shewed to me, was an earnest exhortation to them, to adhere inflexibly to the roman Catholic religion, and not to sell one inch of their Lands— On another paper, there was a statement of the motive of their Journey, and a contribution of £5. annexed to the name of Sir John Harvey, upon their journey to Canada in July; from which they are now returning.— The parade of the 36th regiment was to have been at 10. this morning; but there was rain and a lowering sky and there was no parade. At 11. we went in a Carriage to the Government house, where we were received, with great cordiality by Sir John Harvey— He invited us to take a ride with him to view the country round and to name the hour— I named 2. p.m. he said he should then be at leisure, and had sent for Signor Blitz to come and exhibit before his family— We returned to the Hotel, and called at the House of Major Cairnes to return his visit— Not at home— A Committee of 3. Gentlemen came and invited us to visit the reading room which we did at 5 O’Clock p.m. Sir John Harvey’s open waggon had called and taken us to the Government House at 2.— Signor Blitz there performed some of his wondrous works, before the family— Captain Tryon’s little daughter, 3 years old, on Lady Harvey’s lap, and calling the Governor papa mine— Servants called in to see the show. Sir John then shewed us round his grounds; laid out with taste and elegance along the banks of the river— Kitchen Garden well cultivated— He then rode with us about 3 miles up and 2 miles down, on the banks of the river, and landed us at our lodgings at 4. We went with Mr Street the Solicitor General to the Province house; the Legislative and Judicial Mansion— Undergoing repairs— Portraits of George the 3d. Queen Charlotte, and Lord Glenelg— At 5. we visited the reading-room—Newspapers—Featherstonhaugh and Mudge’s Report and Maps. Dined with Sir John Harvey at 7. Captain and Mrs Tryon— Lieutenant Harvey. Mr and Mrs Shore— Major and Mrs Cairnes. Evening party and Ball— Numerous Ladies— Many Officers— Captains Ross and Hogshaw— Beverley Robertson and brothers— Dancing— Waltzing. Home to our lodgings at Midnight.

12. IV:30. Saturday—  At 7 this morning after breakfasting at our lodgings, Jackson’s Hotel at Fredericton we started in the Stage for Woodstock. The river above Fredericton is not navigable for Steamboats; but the road runs all along as close as possible on the banks of the river; nearly the first halfway on the South, and the rest on the North bank of the river— We were 12 passengers in the Stage, 9 of whom inside, including 2 women— The Stage was old and crazy. When we stopped at the Post Office warned our driver that she would break down, and one of the springs on which the thorough braces were supported was loosened— We nevertheless proceeded—the first Stage was of 18 miles— 35 miles from Fredericton there was a ferry to cross— The Stage and four horses crossed in a flat bottom boat, to serve which there were two ferrymen only— The passengers had alighted from the Stage, and the approach to the landing place was inaccessible to them for the mud.— There was a small boat at hand, grounded on the bank, with a foot deep of water at the bottom— Some of our fellow passengers baled out the water, and one of them rowed us, with crosshanded oars over the river— All save one, a Frenchman, named Baire; from the disputed territory at Madawaska—jumped into a small canoe, and paddled himself over.— The road thence for seven miles was heavy with hills, deep with sand and studded with rocks; through a region covered with forests of pine, cedar, spruce, fir, and hemlock, a primitive growth tall and slender, with here and there small birch, beech and maple and rarely red and grey oak interspersed with burnt stumps, and tall strip’d trunks of pines looking like the stacks of chimneys of burnt dwelling houses.— Then prostrate pines, fit for the masts of some high ammiral?, with their roots torn up from the soil like the side wall of a mud built hovel; or fallen till sustained by the dividing branches of other yet standing trees Here and there a small cleared lot, with a small house, and perhaps a barn, cattle, sheep and domestic fowls— The proportion of dead trunks of trees standing in the midst of others, gives the whole landscape an appearance of desolation, and the almost total absence of birds, adds a darker gloom to the solitude of the wild. But the river flows through all this scenery; with strings of narrow long islands, most of which are cultivated and present an aspect of fertility. 42 miles from Fredericton, we dined at the house of a Scotchman name Munro.— We got a tolerably good dinner to which our driver sat down with us.— We had witnessed no such usage in Nova-Scotia. The carriage had broken down two or three times, and at Munro’s, was detained nearly two hours for a blacksmith’s repairs— Mr Munro with much complaisance told me that he had heard me spoken of very respectfully, in the ould country— We had at one stage after dinner, a third pair of horses tackled to the Stage.— The accidents we met with, were fortunately without hurt to our persons, but delayed our progress till after dark— But the weather which had been rainy and gloomy cleared off towards Night, leaving bright moonshine— We crossed without difficulty at 8 the second ferry five miles from Woodstock; and the creek there, to Mrs Grover’s house at 9. She is a widow, born at Halifax, and says she kept the Masonic Hall at that place, till five years ago, when he died—after which she came here with her mother, who is yet living. She has also a Sister married here— We found on our arrival here a fire made in the common parlour— The first we have met since we left Boston.

properties.dateline: Woodstock. New Brunswick— Houlton, Maine 13. September 1840.
properties.text: 13. V:30. Sunday  There was a frost last Night, and frost ice this morning. Mr Baire the Frenchman from Madawaska, went off this morning in the stage for that place— An open waggon with 3. Seats, for 6 persons including the driver— There were 8 persons in it, and an enormous load of baggage, which Mr Baire called le butin, before they left the tavern door; and they were to take up two passengers more. Mr Baire had been silent all day yesterday in the Stage, of which I had not known the cause— On finding that he was French, I spoke to him in that language, and found him very willing to converse and apparently glad to talk; but I had so little time for discourse with him that I learnt very little about the Madawaska settlement— On enquiring for an opportunity to attend public worship we found there were in the neighbourhood of our Inn two Churches—one Episcopal Church of England—the other, Wesleyan Methodist; but that the ministers of both were absent, and that there would be no divine service at either. Afterwards however, Mr English, brother in Law to Mrs Grover, and the Postmaster of the place, came and accompanied us to the Methodist Church, where a young man, a native of the Province (vulgarly called a blue nose) named George Williams, performed the services of prayer, and giving out by semi-couplets the hymns to be sung, and read a Sermon of John Wesley from Luke 12.7. “Even the hairs of your head are numbered.” A sensible and not enthusiastic discourse upon a general, and particular Providence— Mr Williams repeated the prayers with fluency, but is a very indifferent reader.— The Revd. Mr Johnson was the regular preacher, and Mr Williams announced that he would preach the next Sunday— The Church is small, but very neat—the congregation not numerous, but well dressed, of grave and decent demeanour, and highly respectable in appearance— We dined at Woodstock. O’Clock— The dividing line between the Province of New-Brunswick and the State of Maine is about 2 miles short of Houlton, and just before we reached it, a solitary, long, narrow, and apparently empty house, separated by three partitions, our driver told us was a smuggling shop—on the American side; near the line were two Cash stores.— We saw the boundary line, and the summits of Mars Hill, at the distance of 30. Miles— About an hour after us, arrived at the same Inn Major Graham one of the U.S. Commissioners to survey the boundary line; with Lieutt. T. J. Lee and a surveying party— Coll. Pierce and Major Kirby of the Regiment stationed here, called upon us this Evening. Dr Lawson, and five other Officers, are boarders in the House. I met in front of the house, Mr Houlton, after whom the place was named, and had some conversation with him— Maine election to-morrow— Clear Sunset.

properties.text: 13. V:30. Sunday  There was a frost last Night, and frost ice this morning. Mr Baire the Frenchman from Madawaska, went off this morning in the stage for that place— An open waggon with 3. Seats, for 6 persons including the driver— There were 8 persons in it, and an enormous load of baggage, which Mr Baire called le butin, before they left the tavern door; and they were to take up two passengers more.
