14. IV:30. Monday  Notwithstanding the fair promise of last Evening’s Sunset, there was a copious rain in the night, and through the greatest part of this day; with occasional intervals, but not a glimpse of the Sun— I rose early, and wrote by candlelight more than two hours— Immediately after breakfast, General Abraham Eustis, commanding the first Regiment of U.S. Artillery stationed at Houlton, called on me, and invited us to visit the barracks— I accordingly walked with him to them and as we approached them, a salute of 13 guns was fired, which he told me was intended for me— The Officers of the Regiment were introduced to me, and the men were ordered out for parade— General Eustis observing that I had been heretofore the commander in chief of the armies of the United States, enquired if I would review the troops— I answered that being no longer in the capacity of Commander in Chief I should ask to be excused from that service, to which he readily assented— The regiment was however paraded, and went through the exercise and marching with great accuracy and precision. I said to the general that they were quite as expert and rapid in their movements as any part that I had seen of the British army— He said the scarlet coat had an advantage over the blue—immediately after the parade, one of the companies were marched off to repair to Eastport and the whole corps escorted them about a mile on their way— Another company is to march the day after to morrow for Portland. There have been eight companies here, while there is room at the barracks only for six— Several of the Officers have therefore been obliged—to board at the Inn, which has a bad effect on the discipline. General Eustis said he had deeply regretted that Coll. Pierce and Major Kirby had visited me last Evening—that they had both returned to the barracks under a very high degree of excitement— I said I had not observed any thing of it, at which he said he was surprized. They were the only two Officers in the regiment liable to such susceptibilities— We visited Mrs Eustis a Lady from South Carolina—and whom the climate of Houlton does not suit. The General said, he had thought as badly of the place, before he came to the place, as was possible; but had found it much worse than he had anticipated— He has lost since last May 250 men by desertion, and there are not 500. men now here— We returned and dined at the Inn— It is the annual and congressional election day at Houlton, and throughout the State of Maine— The Barmaid at our inn was told that a man who had offered to vote, had been rejected as an Alien— An Alien? what’s that?— A blue nose— Well, said she, I hope Mr Harrison will be chosen President of the United States next November and if he is not, I will leave this place— At 3. p.m we left Houlton in the Stage for Bangor— We had as travelling companions Lieutenant Wayne, a son of the judge of the U.S. Supreme Court—a Soldier this day discharged and going to New-York; and a woman weighing at least 200 lb avoir du pois, and with a face for one of Macbeth’s witches— We came in heavy rain, through a dreary wilderness 25 miles to Hainesville; a solitary house, and a new Landlord, who served us up Moose, killed by an Indian, and gave me a log-cabin, down East for a bed room to sleep in—

14. IV:30. Monday  Notwithstanding the fair promise of last Evening’s Sunset, there was a copious rain in the night, and through the greatest part of this day; with occasional intervals, but not a glimpse of the Sun— I rose early, and wrote by candlelight more than two hours— Immediately after breakfast, General Abraham Eustis, commanding the first Regiment of U.S. Artillery stationed at Houlton, called on me, and invited us to visit the barracks— I accordingly walked with him to them and as we approached them, a salute of 13 guns was fired, which he told me was intended for me— The Officers of the Regiment were introduced to me, and the men were ordered out for parade— General Eustis observing that I had been heretofore the commander in chief of the armies of the United States, enquired if I would review the troops— I answered that being no longer in the capacity of Commander in Chief I should ask to be excused from that service, to which he readily assented— The regiment was however paraded, and went through the exercise and marching with great accuracy and precision. 15. II:30 Tuesday  The rain continued through the Night and all this Morning. At half past two we were summoned from our log-cabin beds, and proceeded 20 Miles to breakfast at Mattawamkeag. Our Amazon fellow-passenger came no farther than Hainesville, where she had until recently been the keeper of the house at which we lodged—a good (not a fair[)] sample of the female pioneer of the wilderness.— From Mattawamkeag, we came a 9 mile stage to Lincoln. 13 miles to Enfield. 16 to the place where we dined—then 16 toand 16 to Bangor, where at half past 7 in the Evening, we alighted at the Bangor Hotel, the best public house we have seen since we left Boston— We travelled this day ninety miles, almost entirely through a wilderness, covered with spruce, pine, fir, and birch trees resembling exactly what we had seen in Nova-Scotia, and in ascending the river St. John— There was one extensive tract, known by the name of the burnt district, where great ravages have been committed by fire among the woods— The lots of ground covered with stumps from 3 to four feet high, looking like a huge bowling green with the nine pins set up in order upon it were numerous. Many of the trees appeared to have been burnt off. The living trees were lofty, with stems of no unreasonable size, but perfectly straight, from 30 to 50 feet high, and suitable for masts of different sizes— Scarcely any ground cleared, and scarcely an attempt to eradicating the stumps. In some places there was grain, rye or Indian corn or grass on the soil, where the stumps were still standing— We came part of the way, along near the Bank of the Penobscot river, on which Bangor is situated— Yesterday was the election day—throughout the State of Maine, and at every stage at which we stopp’d, and every Post-Office by which we passed we witnessed great excitement of anxious curiosity to learn how the vote of yesterday had gone in the towns through which we passed.— At one town, Lincoln, the Postmaster was in fine Spirits, and said they were looking up; because the democrats had gained 4 votes upon the election in 1838—that of 1839. not having been seriously contested—but in all the other towns the gain had been on the whig side—much to the annoyance of our driver and of most of the Postmasters— About 20 Miles short of Bangor, we took up as passengers a man named Haines, and a young man, a son of Professor Cleveland who said he had come 150 miles, for the single purpose of depositing his vote, and we shall elect Fairfield, said he, by 5000 majority—ten minutes after he said—if we do not carry Fairfield by more than 2000 majority I will go for Harrison in November— Shortly after he asked my Son, if he was acquainted with John Quincy Adams—upon which Charles pointed to me, and said that’s he—upon which he offered me his hand which I readily took. At the Bangor house they shewed me into the Ladies parlour, where there were two ladies and a gentleman— In a few minutes the room filled up with visitors, all strangers among whom were Mr Carr the Mayor of the City—Edward Kent, Ex-Governor and now a candidate for election to that Office; and George Barrell Moody, both Classmates at Cambridge of my dear departed son George—Dr Benjamin Dixon Bartlett, a graduate of 1810—Mr Jerome, formerly of Boston and others almost numberless— Mr Carr the Mayor invited me to receive the visits and greetings of the Citizens generally, to which I assented appointing the hour of 10. O’Clock to-morrow Morning, but I said I must ask them to excuse me from addressing them in a speech.

15. II:30 Tuesday  The rain continued through the Night and all this Morning. At half past two we were summoned from our log-cabin beds, and proceeded 20 Miles to breakfast at Mattawamkeag. O’Clock to-morrow Morning, but I said I must ask them to excuse me from addressing them in a speech.

16. IV:15. Wednesday  The Bangor Hotel, is one of the public houses, set up in many of our large towns in imitation of the Tremont house at Boston, and in point of accommodation for lodgers is the best that I have yet visited— At half past seven the lodgers were roused to breakfast, by the sound of the Gong, a very noisy and discordant substitute for the Bell.— The two Ladies and the Gentleman whom I had found in the Ladies parlour last evening were at the breakfast table, and I apologized to them for the interruption and breaking up of their musical party by the numerous visitors who came in.— At 10. O’Clock, the Mayor, Mr Carr came, and proposed to me to receive the Citizens who wished to see, and shake hands with me, in a large upper dancing hall in the Hotel to which I assented— There for about half an hour, I received and shook hands with all that came—two or three hundred— They were named as they came, but were all strangers, not one of whose names I can recollect— Many others came merely to look on, and to hear.— They soon filled the hall, and I saw it was impossible to dismiss them without an Address— I told the Mayor that although I had requested to be excused from addressing the Citizens to day; yet as they were now assembled, I could not possibly part from them after this meeting without saying a few words; whereupon, a gentleman named M’Gaw, I suppose some City Officer, in a style far more complimentary than agreeable to me; and I mounted on a Sopha at one end of the Hall, and spoke for about an hour and a half to the People— I gave them my reasons for the request I had made to the Mayor to be excused from addressing them in public— My position as an Ex-president of the U.S. and as possibly a Candidate for re-election as a member of Congress— Reasons for which I had declined attending any of the large public meetings which have been held within the year, from that of Baltimore last May, to that of Bunker hill last week— I should continue to decline attending all such meetings in future, and should now confine myself to two topics specially interesting to the People of the State of Maine, and to myself— I then rectified certain misrepresentations of my opinions made by Joshua A. Lowell, a member of the present delegation from Maine in Congress, and spoke with disgust of Featherstonhaugh’s recent report on the North-eastern boundary— The crowd still collected in the Hall, and the Mayor proposed to me to adjourn to the steps of the House for fear of breaking down the Hall— I preferred closing my discourse, which I did with an abundance of cheering. Then at 12. O’Clock Mr Pierce accompanied me to visit Mr Philip Coombs; a heavy lame invalid old gentleman, whom more than fifty years ago I had known as a tall, slender, active, sprightly young man, living at his father’s house at Newburyport. Mrs Coombs is a relation of the Harrod family. At 1/2 past 1. we dined, and here met Ezekiel Whitman, heretofore a member of Congress from the State of Maine and now a judge—and here we parted from our fellow traveller Lieutenant Wayne—from 4 to 5 I rode to the heights above the City with Mr Carr the Mayor and several others— The view of the city, and the prospects around it from these heights are extremely beautiful— At 5 we visited at Mrs Hammett’s. Mrs Hammett is a niece of Mrs. Cushing the wife of Judge William Cushing once of Scituate. Mrs Cushing was an intimate friend of my mother, and Mrs Hammett has the whole collection of my mother’s Letters to her— Here I met Mr Hedge the Minister— Tea party at Mr Pierce’s, and from 1/2 past 7 to 10. I received visits from the Ladies, at the Hotel. Mr and Mrs Jerome—Major Freeman from Boston. Mrs Fearon requested two autograph signatures. Note and Books from E. F. Duren— Packed up— Bed past 1. A.M—

17. IV. Thursday.  Up again at four O’Clock this morning. At 5 we embarked in the Steamer Bangor Captain Howes for Portland, and Boston— That was the hour at which she should have departed from the wharf: but although the Night had been clear, and the Sun rose bright, with the Sun there came up a thick fog and there was a bar of a few miles below the City, to pass which it was expedient to wait for the flood tide. It was near 7. when we loosened from the wharf with a multitude of passengers—Men—women and children, among whom as sedom fails in a Steamer one, excessively fractious and troublesome baby— Judge Whitman, U.S. District judge Ashur Ware, and judge William Pitt Preble were also of the company— They all live at Portland and have been a fortnight at Bangor upon an arbitration— Mr Fessenden, an elderly member of the bar at Portland, father of the young man just elected to the 27th Congress in the place of Albert Smith was also of the party, and Mr Dwinell a Gentleman to whom we were indebted for many civilities yesterday, but of whom I know nothing further— It is indeed impossible to conceive of the confusion of the mind, and forgetfulness of names upon the presentation of hundreds of persons at one time— In descending the Penobscot river, we passed first by Frankfort on the right and Bucksport on the left bank of the river— I had yesterday several visitors from Brewer; on the opposite side of the river to Bangor.— Frankfort is about 7 and Bucksport 9 miles below— As we approached Frankfort, guns were fired from the shore, and bells were rung—a crowd of people were assembled on the wharf, who as we parted from it gave three cheers— I supposed it a rejoicing of the whigs at their election victory— As we approached Bucksport, the firing of guns and ringing of bells were repeated— Judge Whitman said to me, that is for you— I said surely not—but for the whig victory— As we parted from the wharf the cheering was a hearty shout— The right of petition—the right of petition—huzza for the man who sustains the right of petition—left no doubt of the meaning of the guns and bells— It was a happy moment leaving me to lament to how little purpose I had defended the right of petition.— We afterwards passed by Waldo, and Prospect, Belfast and Castine on opposite sides at the mouth of Penobscot river and opening to the Bay.— Then Lincolnville and Thomaston—through the whole day, sudden and entire alternations of clear, bright Sunshine, and of impenetrable and perplexing fogs disclosed and concealed some of the most beautiful scenery upon earth— For several hours from 9. A.M. till noon there was nothing beyon the vessel to be seen, and I retired to a birth in the lower cabin and ruminated but did not sleep— We afterwards passed the Fox-islands, numerous ledges of rocks— Seguin island light—Pemmaquid point, and just at Sunset went in to Boothbay harbour and anchored at Townsend. Captain Howes was afraid to proceed in the Night, with a fog he said as dense as he had ever seen— Within half an hour after Sunset however the fog cleared away, and the anchor was soon weighed at 8. p.m. we passed by the mouths of the Sheepscut and Kennebeck rivers and Cape Smallpoint— I had a long conversation upon political topics with Mr Fessenden; and then retired without undressing to a couch in the lower cabin, where I slept till awaked by the fastening of the Steamer to the wharf at Portland, precisely at One, in the Morning.

properties.dateline: Portland. Maine— Portsmouth New Hampshire 18. September 1840.
properties.text: 18. VI:30. Friday  We landed from the Steamer Bangor, on the wharf at Portland at one O’Clock this morning, and took lodgings at the Cumberland House; another good imitation of the Tremont— I went immediately to bed and slept till half past 6. when I rose in sound health, and fresh from the fatigues of four preceding days— At half past 7. we breakfasted at the ordinary, and there met Mr Virgil D. Parris a member of the present Congress from Maine, but who has just failed as a candidate for re-election— We had barely breakfasted, when Mr C. A. Daveis, called upon me, and proposed to me to walk with him to the hill, upon which my father held his last interview with Jonathan Sewall in 1774 immediately before the commencement of the revolutionary War—as related by my father in the preface to the republication of the essays of Novanglus and Massachusettensis— I went accordingly with him upon the hill, which presents one of the most beautiful prospects, that I ever beheld an extensive view of islands; mountains, vallies, and the distant ocean with that own poor house, bosom’d high in tufted trees— Mr Daveis pointed out to me the spot where he supposed the interview between my father and Jonathan Sewall had been held— The place is now a grave-yard, and a deeply affecting spot for the monuments which it contains over the graves of Lieutenant Commandant Willian Burrows commander of the United State Brig Enterprize, and Samuel Blythe commander of the British Brig Boxer, captured by the Enterprize on the 5th. of September 1813. and brought into Portland— The Commanders of both vessels were killed in the action, and here they sleep in death, and in glory side by side, as if they had been man and wife— Mr Daveis said that he felt some mortification in stating that the monument over the remains of Lieutenant Burrows was erected at the expense, not of the citizens of Portland, collective or individual, but of Matthew L. Davis of New-York. Another Monument, which awakened long slumbering sensibilities in my breast was that of Commodore Preble, one of our gallant naval commanders, whose name carries with it round the world the honour of our Country— On returning with Mr Daveis to the Hotel, we met in the Street the Mayor of the City, Mr Ilsley, in former times Collector of the Customs and GenlWingate heretofore a Member of the House of Representatives, U.S. and whose wife is a daughter of the late General Henry Dearborn— With them there was a throng of Citizens of the place whom the Mayor stated to be desirous of paying their respects to me and of shaking hands with me, which they did for about half an hour in a hall of the Hotel. We then went to a new yet unfinished Courthouse and Exchange building, with a dome on the top of it, which we ascended and there again beheld the fair city at our feet, and the exquisitely beautiful prospects of hills, around and the more distant view of the Ocean— Met judge Ware, in his chamber adjoining the Court room and Mrs Ware was with him. The throng continued to shake hands, and I gave them a short parting address of half an hour in the Court room— At 12. Met General Wingate, Mrs Wingate and numerous Ladies at his house— Mrs Bailey (Charlotte Welsh) Short parting address— Dined at the Hotel— Stage to Portsmouth at 1:30. Rockingham house at 8.

19. VI. Saturday  At Portland yesterday Genl. Wingate had expressly invited me to his house at 12 O’Clock to meet the Ladies, who wished to see me— There were many there; but none with whom I had any previous acquaintance, except Mrs Wingate and Mrs Bailey— Many fine women, but whose very names escape me— My parting address to them was extremely Laconic—on our way back to the Hotel, we met three young Ladies who were going to Genl. Wingate’s, and whom Mr Daveis introduced to me in the Street— At his request we stop’d at one house, where he introduced to me two others— On our return to the Hotel, I received a polite note from Mr Albert Smith inviting me to dine with him at his boarding house— And while we were at dinner at the Hotel he came in, and I thanked him for his kindness and apologized for being deprived of the pleasure of accepting his invitation to dinner by our immediate departure for Portsmouth— In the Stage from Portland we had a very handsome young woman from Newburyport married at Portland, who was going to Newburyport; with a young man, perhaps her brother. Before reaching Saco, they left the Stage to proceed in a horse and Chaise. At Scarborough, the Innkeeper made himself known to me, as heretofore a Sea-Captain, introduced to me as Master of one of Mr Gray’s merchant vessels at St. Petersburg— His name is Hovey.— But since 1811. I had thoroughly forgotten him— From Portland to Portsmouth is 50 Miles— We passed through Saco, and over the river—then through Biddeford, Kennebunk, Wells, York Kittery, in view of the Boon Island light, and across the long bridge over the Piscataway river to Portsmouth; we came to the Rockingham house, where we found Mr Curtis’s son’s wife, with her daughter and son—and a MissThe town was in an uproar of Politics.— Mr Henry Hubbard a Senator in Congress from New-Hampshire was haranguing a loco foco convocation in one house and there was a crowded assemblage of whigs at another. The latter followed us, mob fashion, shouting, huzzaing, and calling me out by name— I went out to them, and as it was as dark as pitch, thanked them heartily for their kind reception—gave them good news from Maine, and asked them to excuse me from addressing them then whereupon they dispersed with three cheers— Mr and Mrs Austin called to see Mr Curtis— Mr Upham called upon me and apologized for the disturbance of our repose, by the tumultuous but friendly impetuosity of the people, which we cheerfully overlooked. He and several other gentlemen, urged me with great earnestness and pertinacity to stay at Portsmouth and address the whigs, and counteract the eloquence of Mr Hubbard— But we had irrevocably fixed to take the Stage this morning, and to close our excursion this day. We accordingly breakfasted at 6. A.M. and after a fruitless chase in the rain for a barber, We started in the Stage from the Rockingham house 16 Miles to Exter—then two Miles further to the place to which the railway from Boston to Portland has hitherto extended—there took the cars—landed at the Tremont house Boston at 1/2 past 12. and there parted from Mr Curtis who returned home to Roxbury— Found a Barber— Visit to Mr Abbott Lawrence who told me he had this day resigned his seat in Congress— Dined at the Tremont house. A Belknap—Chevalier Hulseman—Judge Smith of Florida—Captain Webster— We came in Gilletts Omnibus to Quincy— Arrived at Sunset— Family all well [symbols] Elizabeth De Wint here— Her Mother went to Boston Yesterday.

20. V:20. Sunday.  Clear morning— I went to the corner of Charles’s house, and saw the Sun—just risen 5:44. Heard the Revd. John Langdon Sibley, this morning, from 1. Corinthians 1.12. “Now this I say, that every one of you saith, I am of Paul: and I of Apollos; and I of Cephas, and I of Christ. 13. Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?” This was a discourse on the diversities of Sentiment and opinions among men, as resulting from the constitution of human nature; and upon the duty of mutual toleration and liberality resulting therefrom— Mr Sibley’s remarks were sensible and judicious, manifesting a Christian temper and benevolent disposition; but not much depth—of observation or of research.— His delivery is good, but not remarkable— Much superior to any thing that I have heard the last two Sundays, since I left home. Mr Sibley was a Classmate of my son Charles at Cambridge— He dined with us— He expressed great curiosity to have mount Wollaston, and the place where John Hancock was born pointed out to him; which I did—walking over the hill to Meeting, after dinner— I had shewed him also at his request, my Library—the Volumes of my diary, and some of my Letter-books and my father’s . The original Letter to Nathan Webb of October 1755. and the Book copy of the Letter to my mother of 3. July 1776.—I gave him also copies of my three Eulogies, of the Oration of 4. July 1837 at Newbury-port—the Speech on the right of Petition in June 1838. The Jubilee of the Constitution, at New-York April 1839. and the Speech of May 1840. on the English system of smuggling.— Mr Sibley’s afternoon text was from 2. Corinthians—6:14—[“]for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness.”— I had not time in the leisure of this day, even to read through all the Letters which have been received here for me, during my absence; among which are invitations of 1. September from the Whigs of Michigan to attend and take part in a whig convention at Detroit on the 30th of September, from the whigs of North-Carolina to attend their Convention at Raleigh, on the 5th. of October, and from the whigs of the Western part of New-York to attend and address a Convention at Buffalo on the 7th. of October— Letters also from E. J. Lee of Alexandria, from Philip R. Fendall and from a Committee of the Proprietors of the second Presbyterian church at Washington, upon various political topics and religious concerns which will require my particular notice, and early attention— Mary-Louisa, my Granddaughter read to me in the French Bible, the third chapter of the Book of Judges, to which she had read before I went away.— Charles and his wife, the Midshipman John Quincy and Elizabeth C. Adams spent the Evening here— I have been several Nights in my sleepless hours brooding over a project of verses upon the memory of childhood.

21. V. Monday.  My son went to Boston this morning, and returned home to dine— His wife, and Mary, went also to Boston, and took Elizabeth De Windt with them— She had received a Letter from her mother, who had left her here last Friday, and gone herself into Boston to Mrs Keating’s, and now directed Elizabeth to come to her— I went up the hill to Charles’s house it being the equinoctial day, but the Sun rose beclouded—and I could not note the time or place— With the exception of a short visit to my garden, nursery, orchard and seminary, the day was occupied with this diary, in which I have a new arrear of eight days to redeem— About Sunset, I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and found her recovered from a recent indisposition— Her Sister Mrs Foster is to leave her to-morrow, going on a visit to Bangor— The Midshipman John Quincy walked home with me, with the illumination of a splendid Aurora Borealis— With this sets in the sharp autumnal cold, which kindled a fire in our dining room; and I found one at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— At home I found Mr Price Greenleaf as a visitor, and my Son had a proof print of the portrait of my mother to be published with the volume of her Letters which he has prepared for publication, and which he expected would have been published before our departure for Nova-Scotia. The print is a copper plate engraving, from the Portrait in water Colours taken about 1764 or 1765 shortly after my mothers marriage—during her absence in England, about 1785. this portrait with that of my father taken at the same time were removed from the house at the foot of Penn’s hill, by my aunt Cranch to her house, where they remained upwards of 50 years, till about the this time last year, when I took my father’s portrait to lend to Mr Bancroft at Boston, to be engraved for a forth coming volume of his history of the United States— Since then, Charles has undertaken to publish this small volume of my mother’s Letters, and had this portrait engraved, to front the title-page. But it is wretchedly executed, and he doubts whether to accept and use it, or to publish the book without any portrait. I thought, bad as it is, that it is better than none—and better than to delay the publication till another plate can be engraved— The inconvenience of this would be increased by the fact, that there is already a favourable review of the Book in the North-American Review for the present quarter, which will be published the first of next Month— And so think the Ladies of the family.  And now that I shall at least for some time have no memorable daily facts to record, I ought from day to day to make up a summary of reflections resulting from my observations in a three weeks excursion to the British Provinces of Nova-Scotia, and New-Brunswick, and through the State of Maine, and a corner of New-Hampshire— For, to what purpose is travel, but to replenish the mind with observation? and to what purpose is a mind full of observation, but to impart?— Oh! for the mind of a Humboldt!— How poor and barren is mine!

22. V: Tuesday.  Birth day of my Son Charles’s eldest Son, John Quincy who is seven years old— Cloudy morning, so that I could not observe the rising of the Sun— Miss Abigail Quincy with Miss Phelps and Mr Josiah Quincy junr two younger children Samuel and Mary paid a morning visit to our Ladies— My wife and Mrs John Adams, went this afternoon over to Weymouth— I planted the stone of a very large peach, with two Nova-Scotia plum-stones 6. Shagbark walnuts in the drupe, and 6 English white-oak acorns in patch 3 row 7 of the seminary, opposite the old plum tree— I had a large young Peach-tree, transplanted into this patch last autumn; which being now dead, I had taken out of the ground, and these Stones, nuts and acorns put down in its place— There is a black currant-bush, and an Apple-seedling growing in the Georgiana patch, where the violet blossomed through the whole of last Summer, and is not yet extirpated. I cannot approach the place but with sweet and bitter tears— I paid a visit to Mr Thomas Greenleaf of the early part of this Evening— Charles and his wife were here the latter part of it— We had fire in the dining room, and I had need of some self-controul to abstain from having one made in my Library where I was writing to retrieve these arrears— In our recent excursion the observation frequently recurred to me of the results upon the physical, political and moral face of the country, under the colonial, and the independent condition, compared with each other— The aspect of the Provinces of Nova-Scotia and New-Brunswick constantly reminded me of that of Massachusetts-Bay, in the days of my childhood, as far back as I can remember. The Provinces are prosperous—their population increases from year to year— The British Government, taught by woful experience the absurdity of expecting to raise revenue from these Colonies, passed to the other extreme, and pours forth from her own funds, with a lavish hand— They maintain their authority over the Provinces at enormous sacrifices of men and money. The Salaries of the Lieutenant Governors of Nova-Scotia and New-Brunswick, fall little short of that of the President of the United States. An army of 16000 men, is now maintained in these two Provinces and the Canada’s. The whole army of the United States is now 12500. Nearly doubled as it has been within the last 3 years— There are three regiments, the 8th. 23d. and 37th. stationed at Halifax besides divisions of Royal Artillery and Engineers— Twenty-three regiments of Nova-Scotia-Militia, all armed, officered and trained—a Navy of 26 armed vessels and 6 armed Steamers—all together presenting the aspect of a community clad in complete steel and prepared for defence against the most formidable assaults— There is a regiment the 69th. at St. John, and a Regiment the 36th. at Fredericton— In the Canadas are many more; and a Governor General, holding a Court, and maintaining an Establishment little less than royall. All this for a population less than one half equal to that of the State of New-York—and all this maintained at the expense of the British Nation— These possessions are cherished as destined to hold in check, and under controul the growing power of the United States of America, an object for which John Bull considers no sacrifice too great.

23. Wednesday. IV:30  Sun rose 5:47. behind a lofty distant tree— Fahrenheit 38.  Morning visit from the Chevalier Hulsemann, Secretary of the Austrian legation; whom we met in the Steamer Bangor to Portland, and on our return to Boston at the Tremont house. I did not then recollect his name, having seen him not more than once or twice at Washington last winter— He told me that he had been out here with Mr Caleb Cushing at the Pic Nic on the 3d. and they had visited our family—but the Ladies had not remembered him any better than I did, and until this day knew not who he was— Mr Beale and his daughter Caroline were here this Evening; and Charles and his wife of course.— I walked this afternoon to Mr John Greenleaf’s, and saw him and his two daughters, Mrs Lucy and Mrs Mary Dawes. He is 78 years of age, of which he has been upwards of 60 years blind, and for some years past hard of hearing, though not absolutely deaf.— Mrs Greenleaf, my Cousin, once Lucy Cranch, is but three months younger than myself. She is now confined to her chamber, by a dropsical disease, from which there is no hopes of her recovery— I called next at the house of Mrs T. B. Adams, but she was gone with her son John Quincy, to visit Mr John Marston at Taunton, and Elizabeth was at Mr Edward Miller’s. My last visit was Dr Woodward who is building a house— There I met two young women daughters of Henry Wood— His wife is a daughter of Deacon Ebenezer Adams, first cousin both by father and mother’s side to my father. I did not know them. There is hardly an old family in this town, with whom I have not some affinity in blood— But to return to the province of Nova-Scotia— Mr Curtis purchased for me at Fredericton, Thomas C. Haliburtons Historical and Statistical account of Nova-Scotia, in two 8vo. Volumes, published in 1829. a very valuable work.— From this it appears that the population of the Provinces in 1790 was about 30000. in 1817. 82053. and in 1827. 123,848—besides 30000 in the Island of Cape Breton: Hence within the last half century the population has more than quadrupled; and has kept a full proportion to the average increase throughout the United States; though in no wise comparable to the increase in our Western States, or New-York or Pennsylvania— Two thirds of this population of Nova-Scotia proper consists of the remnants and descendants of 20000 loyalists or refugees from the North-American States who settled there in 1783 immediately after the close of the American revolutionary War— The numbers of the people now including the Island of Cape-Breton must exceed 200,000— The territory of the Peninsula covers an Area of 15617 square miles nearly double that of the State of Massachusetts; and with a population of 100 to a square mile, which is about that of Massachusetts, would number more than one million and a half of inhabitants— It is not probable that it will ever feed such numbers— Its situation however is favourable to commerce, and its climate to the establishment of manufactures. Of these there are now none, the policy of the mother country being to furnish them for the Province— They are imported duty free, and there is neither capital nor shill in the colony to start or maintain a competition with the manufacturers at home.

24. IV:30. Thursday.  Sun rose under cloud. Fahrenheit 50.  The day of the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, which I did purpose to attend; but on reflection, I thought it would be a useless waste of time, and concluded to stay at home. Since my excursion of three weeks, I find propensities of dissipation stealing upon me which it is advisable to controul, and to return as far as possible to the duties before me— Returning home last Evening, I met Mr Richards of the Quincy Lyceum who had called at my house, to solicit a Lecture from me for that Institution, which I promised to deliver before my departure for Washington— As yet the arrears of the Diary absorb all my time, excepting a morning hour, which I have devoted on resuming the perusal of Bancroft’s history of the United States— Elizabeth C. Adams dined and spent the evening with us— Charles attended a Meeting of the democratic party this Evening, at which George Bancroft, Collector of the Customs at Boston, Superintendant of Light-houses within the Commonwealth, and Commissioner for building a Custom house at Boston, delivered an electioneering democratic address— This practice of itinerant speech-making has suddenly broken forth in this Country to a fearful extent.— Electioneering for the Presidency, has spread its contagion to the President himself—to his now only competitor; to his immediate Predecessor—to one at least of his Cabinet Counsellors, the Secretary of War—to the Ex-candidates Henry Clay, and Daniel Webster, and to many of the most distinguished members of both Houses of Congress— Immense assemblages of the People are held—of 20, 30, 50,000 souls, where the first Orators of the Nation, address the multitude, not one in ten of whom can hear them, on the most exciting topics of the day— As yet the parties call and hold these meeting separately and seldom interfere with each other— But at the Baltimore convention last May one of the Marshals of the procession, a respectable mechanic of the city was killed, by an attempt of individuals of the opposite party to break it up— At a meeting a few days since on long Island, Mr Webster in a speech of two hours and a half, observed that there was to be held a meeting of the opposite party another great meeting at the same place on the next day; and he gave what was equivalent to a challenge to Silas Wright and all the administration leaders to meet him on the stump.— A hand bill was this day circulated in this town, severely reflecting on Mr Bancroft, for coming to deliver this address— Charles says that at Medford there has already been hostile collision between the parties—and the tendency of all this undoubtedly is, to the corruption of the popular elections, both by violence and fraud— Charles came in after hearing Mr Bancroft’s address, which was delivered at the Universalist Meeting house— Bancroft is an apostate federalist, as are almost to a man the leaders of the mock democracy of this State— Most of them, have cast off their caterpillar skin within the last five years— My father used to say of such

25. IV:30. Friday—  Sun rose 5:49. Set 5:54. Fahrenheit 32. frost. New-Moon—  Morning visit from Mr Thomas Greenleaf, my neighbour, and Mr Thomas Payson of Peterborough, New Hampshire, Classmates at Harvard University, and graduates of 1784. I have been for a few years past in occasional correspondence with Mr Payson, who at the age of 76 after a life not prosperous in the smiles of Fortune, retains great vivacity and sprightliness. He laughs as heartily as if he were but 25— Mrs De Windt and Harriet Welsh came out from Boston to spend the night here. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. He and his wife spent the Evening here— I gave an hour in the seminary, and planted English white oak acorns, and shagbark walnuts, with a peach and a plum stone, in patch 3. row 4. and patch 4 row 5. Walking up the hill to see the Sunset I met Mr Josiah Brigham at my Son’s house.— Settled Mr Curtis’s account of our expenses on our recent tour— Among my remarks during that excursion, was the contrast between the excessive election excitement, which we left behind us at Boston, and found again blazing out, on the very day of our entrance into the State of Maine, and the calm and almost lethargic condition of the British Provinces. The British Government makes itself felt there only by its favours— Levies no taxes; pays nearly all the charges of Government—keeps an army at great cost, and a considerable naval force, for the protection and defence of the Country; and humours the people in every thing— They have also made excellent roads through the forests of Nova-Scotia; and are now doing the same in New-Brunswick— No Government upon earth probably so assiduously labours to make itself acceptable to the people under its rule as these Colonial authorities— There are however representative assemblies in both Provinces, and in each a Legislative and an Executive Council— Their provincial Parliaments were like the House of Commons at home elected for seven years; but that of Nova-Scotia, is already reduced to four, and they are expecting the same alteration in New Brunswick— There is in Nova-Scotia, however, a sharp and sturdy opposition in the house of Assembly, and that body last year passed a vote of censure upon Sir Colin Campbell, the king’s Governor.— The British privy Council, fully approved the measures, censured by the Assembly; but they recalled Sir Colin, and since we were there Lord Falkland has arrived in the Steamer Britannia, at Halifax, and has taken his place— This is a very convenient mode of adjusting dissensions between the Legislative and Executive authorities— An election for a new house of assembly is now about to take and the prospect was of a large majority to sustain the last house, and against the Governor.— Lord Falkland will find no difficulty in disarming this majority; if he walks in the footsteps of Sir John Harvey— His qualification for the office is that his wife is a cousin of Queen Victoria; being a daughter of Mrs Jordan, and of the Sailor king, when duke of Clarence.

26. V. Saturday  Sun rose 5.50. Set 5.52. Fahrenheit 42  My daily task is the diary of the preceding day, and the redemption of one day of recent arrears— It failed of accomplishment this day, because I wasted my time in idle researches among newspaper advertisements— Mrs De Windt and Harriet Welsh, had intended to return this Morning to Boston, but finally concluded to stay and dine at my Son’s— I dined there with them, and Mr Beale and Mr Lunt— Immediately after dinner, my wife and Mrs John, and Mrs Charles, took Mrs De Windt and Miss Welsh into Boston left them at Mrs. Allyne Otis’s and returned home this evening.— Charles was not here— Mrs De Windt had with her the first copy of the volume of my mother’s Letters. It deserves notice how very little intercourse there has heretofore been between the People of the United States and those of the adjoining British Provinces, and most especially with Nova-Scotia— Yet they well deserve to be studied by a young American Statesman; for they are destined to have hereafter a very powerful influence over the condition of the North American Union and especially over its Northern and Western Sections. The Policy of the British Government has been to excite and main divisions of interest among the colonies themselves as well as to nourish and stimulate their animosities against the neighbouring States. In 1784. the Province of New-Brunswick was set off from Nova-Scotia, and constituted a separate colony— So was the island of Cape-Breton, which has however been since re-annexed to Nova-Scotia. There are very perceptible mutual rivalries and jealousies between the Provinces and, a great indifference in both to the Canada’s.— They levy an impost duty of five percent upon all imported goods from one to the other, and it is very apparently part of the political system at home to keep them as much as possible alienated from each other; that all my be more perfectly dependent upon the common parent— Another precaution at home is a rigorous prohibition to recruit any of the regiments in the provinces— Of the ten companies constituting a regiment they always retain four in England in depot; and send them out from time to time, to supply the vacancies by death or desertion. The last are very rare— The men are enlisted for life, and as they are all taken from the paupers of the three kingdoms, and are fed, clad and lodged at the king’s expense, and trained exclusively to the performance of military service, they are nested in a condition of existence from which they have little temptation to depart, especially at the risk of capture and severe punishment— Yet on the day that we were at Saint John, a Court martial was held upon a Soldier who had deserted from the 69th. regiment, and who one of the Officers said had been taken at Portland— I mentioned this at Portland, to their great surprize—

27. IV:30. Sunday.  Sun rose beclouded— Fahrenheit 60—  Mr Motte is the Pastor of a small congregational Church in Boston.— He is a native of South-Carolina, and was a Classmate, and two years chum of my dear Son George at Harvard University— He was educated and ministered sometime in South-Carolina, as an episcopal clergyman, but upon consciencious conviction became a convert to the unitarian doctrine, and was for sometime settled as Minister of the Unitarian church, at Washington— For the last ten years he has been Minister of the South Congregation, Washington Street Boston— He preached this day at our Church, by exchange with Mr Lunt— His morning text was from James 5:11. [“]Behold we count them happy, which endure. Ye have heard of the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the Lord; that the Lord is very pitiful, and of tender mercy.” and he read part of the first, and of the last chapters of Job— Patience under affliction was the exhortation of his discourse, and I thought he had selected this Sermon for delivery here, with reference to my misfortunes, and to his former relations with my beloved Son— I felt grateful to him for his intention— He dined with us. But the conversation which seemed most agreeable to him, was upon European politics. His afternoon text was John 20.31. [“]But these are written, that ye might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God; and that believing ye might have life through his name.”— Upon the evidences of Christianity. My attention and thoughts were too much absorbed by the volume of my Mothers Letters which my Son has published, and of which he sent me this morning a copy— An admirable Memoir of her life, written by him is prefixed to the Letters, and the reading of it affected me till the tears streamed down my face— It disabled me for all other occupation, and the arrears of this diary, and the Sermon of Barrow were forgotten Charles was here this Evening; but his wife was detained at home by the rain which fell copiously. I had heard Mary Louisa read two chapters of the Book of Judges in Saci’s french Bible, and had read the 6th. chapter of the first Volume of Bancroft’s History of the United States— This chapter is entitled restrictions on Colonial Commerce— It is a very lame account of the English Navigation Act, and a florid panegyric upon the first settlers of Virginia; upon the soil, and climate of that Country—upon the Indian Monarchs, Powhatan and Opechancanough in equal measure. Bancroft is that combination of sycophant and slanderer, which formed Shakespears Iago— The “flatteur dehonté, et calomniateur au besoin” of Mirabeau. With all this he has transcendent talents and indefatigable industry— Every page of his history teems with evidences of profound research, quick perception and brilliant imagination— It is extremely entertaining— The style diffuse and declamatory; far less chaste, though more fascinating than that of Irving or of Prescott. The morality ostentatious, but very defective.

28. IV:30. Monday  Sun rose beclouded Set 5.49.  Morning visit from a Mr Smith with a young girl his Sister. He is a brother of Mr Isaac T. Smith, who came to me on the first of this Month on board of the Steamer Acadia, with a repeated application to me to deliver a Lecture next November before the New-York Lyceum— I answered again indecisively but discouragingly and promised an answer definitive at an early day. In the afternoon I had a visit from Mr James L. Curry late President of the Boston Mechanic Apprentices library Association, with his Successor the present President of the same Society, requesting me to deliver the introductory Lecture, about the first of November to their Winters course— Mr Webster had encouraged them to expect that he would perform this service for them— But he is now itinerant as a political orator, and has informed them that his engagements will not admit of his being here in time to discourse as he had promised them. These perpetual, and almost numberless applications are to me very distressing: between the wish and the inability to comply with the request of a favour, itself importing kindness and respect— I have however declined, upon the chance that I may be called to Washington, before the close of the next Month— Mr Curry has ceased to be President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s library Association, because his apprenticeship has terminated. Mr Haley was the Secretary when I prepared the two Lectures for them, and delivered one of them last November— I this day brought up the arrears of diary into which it fell during my recent excursion, but leave many remarks which I ought to have made, never to be recorded.— In the account of the visit that I made to Sampson Salter Blowers, at Halifax I was mistaken in the statement that he had been the prosecutor of Captain Preston, and the Soldiers of the 29th. Regiment, for the Tragedy of the 5th. of March 1770— He was on the contrary one of the Counsel for the accused, with my father and Josiah Quincy. The Prosecutors were Samuel Quincy, and Robert Treat Paine— Blowers however named as one of the Counsel for the Soldiers, appears to have taken no part in the argument— There were five indictments, one for each of the five inhabitants killed in the fray, each charging first the soldier, whose fire killed the individual charged in the Bill as murdered, and then charging Captain Preston and other soldiers of the guard as accomplices in the murder— The first indictment against Wemms charged also four individuals not soldiers as accomplices in the crime; they were however separately tried, not till the next December, and were all acquitted—on the five indictments, Preston, and six of the eight Soldiers were acquitted— Two Matthew Killroy, and Hugh Montgomery, were found not guilty of murder, but guilty of Manslaughter, and were discharged upon the claim of the benefit of clergy and the brand of cold iron upon the hand— There is more curious matter in this trial which would make a good Lecture— Midshipman John Quincy was here this Evening.

29 IV:30 Tuesday.  Sun rose beclouded, and setFahrenheit 38.  There is no waste of time like that of reading. My mother’s Letters. Bancroft’s history— Speeches, and pamphlets—and above all newspapers; which steal the hours away and leave nothing for memory to record— Having redeemed my last arrears, I expected to have this day several hours of leisure; but could accomplish nothing more, than the record of yesterday, and an answer to John H. Weedon and sundry others, Committee of a whig Tippecanoe association of Pawtucket, Rhode-Island, from whom I have an invitation to appoint some day, to go and address them upon the Presidential Election— I declined— Afternoon visit from Dr Palfrey; and Mr Lothrop, the Minister of the Brattle Street Church and Society. Dr Palfrey’s object was to repeat the solicitation to me to furnish two Articles for the North American Review—of which he is now the Editor and Proprietor— One a biographical account of William Tudor junr. and the other an Article upon the present condition of the Empire and trade of China; and particularly upon the case or prospect of War between Great-Britain, and the celestial Empire— It is impossible for me to prepare an Article upon either of these subjects because I have not, and have never been able to obtain the material facts of the life of Mr Tudor—and because I have no particular information; nothing but loose, disconnected, Newspaper Reports upon the controversy between Great-Britain and China— I received a few days since from Mr John M Forbes, a folio volume of 458 pages, being the Correspondence relating to China, laid before both Houses of the British Parliament, last Spring by command of Queen Victoria— With the aid of this volume together with the information which I might collect from other sources, which it will indicate, I might make out a tolerable Article, but for the want of time. As it is, I shall have more than enough to do, to prepare a Lecture for the Quincy Lyceum, which I have promised, and the subject of which is yet floating in uncertainty upon my mind— In addition to all my other troubles, I took last Saturday, I know not how, a severe cold, and catarrhal cough, which torments me ever since. Visited my garden and nursery this afternoon— Gathered sundry Shagbarks and English white oak Acorns. Two rows of which, 6 of each in each row, I planted—at the left hand of the garden gate next North of the House— I have numerous fruit and forest trees of growth from one to ten years old—but twenty years are necessary to raise an orchard, and thirty years for a forest so that I might leave the accomplishment of that purpose to my Successors— At the dusk of Evening, I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s to deliver a Letter to her daughter Elizabeth which I had received this morning— But Mrs Adams, and Elizabeth, and John Quincy were all gone to Medford, and are expected to return to-morrow Evening— Dr Palfrey spoke to me this afternoon of an Article in the National Intelligencer; upon Featherstonhaugh’s report on the North-eastern boundary, with a map, which I have not seen—

30. IV:30. Wednesday.  Sun rose and set beclouded.  Deacon Spear was here this morning, and I had much conversation with him concerning my property in this town, and the necessary measures for the prudent and economical management of it; a subject exceedingly irksome to me, and for which I become from day to day more and more incompetent— The Mount Wollaston farm, the Penn’s hill farm—the Mansion house farm, the Salt-marsh and the woodlands, the repairs and preservation of buildings, the making and maintenance of fences, and the continual laying out of roads, all require persevering care, and skillful attention, nearly all of which I have committed in trust to my Son, but of which a small portion remains sufficient to be burdensome upon my spirits, and to tax my time— I agreed to go into the woods some day next week with Deacon Spear, and Mr Lemuel Humphreys the Weymouth surveyor in search of a woodlot of which I am part proprietor, but how much, and with whom as tenant in common I know not— I am and for many years have been taxed for the whole; and as the wood upon it is now in condition to be cut off and sold, I propose to exercise that right of possession for the whole, responsible to each of the other proprietors for his part of the proceeds— Lewis Bass was next here, collector of the town and County tax. 288 dollars which I paid by a check on the Quincy Stone bank— Bass and Harvey Field are joint Lessees of my Penn’s hill farm— The lease expires next April and Field and Bass are desirous of having a new lease each for himself of the whole. I told Bass that I should prefer to have him sole tenant for the whole, but referred him for final arrangements to my Son.— He and his wife, and three elder children dined with us, and about an hour before dinner Mrs De Windt came in from Boston with a young Clergyman named Simmons, who has acquired some notoriety by preaching two Sermons at Mobile in the State of Alabama, where he had been two years settled, exhorting his hearers to emancipate their Slaves— This was no longer ago than last May; and the immediate consequence was that he was exhorted to depart from the City and the State, which he did, without delay. Since then he has been some time preaching at Fishkill landing, and became an inmate in the family of Mrs De Wint. They dined with us, and returned this Evening to Boston— After dinner I took him with me into my garden, Nursery and Seminary to view my seedling trees; and then up the hill to the porch of Charles’s house to view the prospect of Boston Bay and City, Mount Wollaston, and the villages of Quincy.— While we were at dinner, Mr Barnard, brother of the one who came on the 31st. of August with Dr Bowditch came for an answer whether I would deliver a Lecture before the Warren Street Association— I promised an answer within ten days.

1. IV. Thursday  Rain all Night, and almost the whole of this day.— I had a fire at last made in my Library, having kept if off, for the last ten days, perhaps at the expense of a severe catarrh— I had been unable yesterday when I gave a check to Lewis Bass, to find my Quincy stone bank check book, and after a vexatiously fruitless search for it, had conjectured that I might have left it at the Bank, the day before my departure for Halifax— I therefore walked this morning to the Bank and made enquiry for my book but it was not there. I then bethought myself of looking for it, where upon my return home I found it; in the pocket of my trunk. There I had deposited it for special safekeeping; this is one of the now almost daily warnings of the decay of Memory, which is growing upon me, and for which I would in vain seek a remedy. The very excess of caution produces the effect of total heedlessness— My early rising enabled me to effect more this day than usual, though three hours of it were occupied in reading Mr Webster’s Speech to a great meeting of Merchants last Monday, at New-York— One of the most remarkable peculiarities of the present time is, that the principal leaders of the political parties, are travelling about the Country from State to State, and holding forth like methodist preachers, hour after hour to assembled multitudes, under the broad canopy of Heaven. Webster and Clay, W. C. Rives, Silas Wright, and James Buchanan, are among the first and foremost in this canvassing Oratory, while Andrew Jackson, and Martin van Buren with his heads of Departments are harping upon another string of the political Accordion, by writing controversial electioneering Letters— Besides the prime leaders of the parties numerous subaltern officers of the administration, are summoned to the same service, and instead of attending to the duties of their Offices Rave, recite and madden round the land— Mr Bancroft’s lecture last week, though said not to have been acceptable to his own party, because not sufficiently violent has yet given to the whigs of Quincy so much uneasiness that they applied to my Son, to deliver a Counter-lecture to them this Evening, which he did at the same place, where Bancroft spoke, at the Universalist church— I went and heard him. He spoke about an hour and a half between 7. and 9. O’Clock, professedly in refutation of Bancroft’s Lecture— The house was crowded as full as it could hold, and the discourse was received with frequent, and finally with long continued applause— After he finished, Adam Curtis one of the whig committee read a notice that to-morrow evening at the same hour, and in the same place, Mr Abel Cushing of Dorchester, would deliver a Lecture in reply to Mr Adams— Charles rode home with me— His wife was here, but as it was raining and the road was muddy they both went immediately home in the carriage— I began a desperate attempt to write a Lecture upon Faith to be delivered here before the Quincy Lyceum. The subject is a perfect Chaos in my mind, and I dare not indulge the hope of shaping it into a discourse of at least an hour— But I must try.

2. V:30. Friday  Another dull gloomy day, with alternate rain, mist and fog— It confined me to the houses, till the twilight of Evening suspended my writing.— Daniel Hardy of Hanson came while we were at dinner, to enquire concerning the condition of the claim of the widow Eunice Everson to a revolutionary War Pension— I told him it was suspended upon two obstacles—first a deficiency of evidence; and secondly upon an empty Treasury, and a consequent stubborn opposition in Congress at their last Session, to all further extension of revolutionary War Pensions— He said she was very old, and destitute and greatly needed the pension— And that her friends had collected all the testimony, believed to be now attainable to support her claim— That Mr John Smith of Hanson, who had heretofore corresponded with me on the subject, had requested him to call on me, and make these enquiries, and to ask my opinion of the prospect of obtaining the pension at the next Session of Congress— I told him that if Mrs Everson’s friends would transmit to me the testimony which they have collected, I would present the claim again at the Commencement of the next Session of Congress, and do whatever might be in my power to obtain a decision in its favour— But that with regard to my opinion I could give little encouragement to hope for its success, at the next Session—the short Session, with a worse than empty treasury, and either a prospect of immediate change of the responsible agents of public affairs, or a confirmed fixture of those in power, releasing them from the obligation of all pledges or bonds for good behaviour; and from all tender concern for the claims of revolutionary worthies or their families. their chance with the next Congress, might be more propitious— At dusk I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and found her at home with Elizabeth and the Midshipman, John Quincy to whom I gave a Letter from his brother Isaac Hull.— Miss Mary Harrod was also there—yesterday from Portland— I walked home in darkness and through the mire, without stopping to hear Abel Cushing’s reply to Mr Adams, at the Universalist Church. Charles went to Boston and returned home to dinner. He brought me Lord Brougham’s translation of the Oration of Demosthenes for the crown— Miss Hannah Adams’s Memoir of her own Life, published by Mrs H. F. Lee; a gift from Mrs Hannah Bigelow—with a note from Harriet Welsh and an extract from a manuscript Memoir of MrsHay, by her niece Mrs Lee—and lastly, from Dr Palfrey, a copy of his funeral Discourse on the late President Kirkland— What a scattering of temptations to read; with Bancroft’s history, my mother’s Letters and the daily newspapers already on hand— I could not resist Lord Brougham’s introduction, where with self complacency somewhat ludicrous, and yet not without plausibility he insists that none but a practical orator can be competent to translate the Oration for the crown— He cites the example of Cicero—but Cicero translated into Latin the Oration of Eschines against Ctesiphon, with that of Demosthenes for the crown.— Brougham should have done the same in English— The Oration of Eschines, is indispensable, to appreciate the full power of the answer to it, by Demosthenes.

3. IV:30. Saturday.  The third successive day of rain, mist and fog, confining me to the house, but enabling me, to write more of my Lecture upon Faith—a subject upon which I have long meditated, and formed opinions, perhaps worthy of being communicated to the world, but immature in my own mind, and which can never be wrought into consistency, but in the form of a Dissertation— My principal difficulty consists in the dryness and hacknied nature of the subject profoundly metaphysical, and buried in the bottomless depths of religious controversy— Can I take it up without encroaching upon the province of the pulpit? Can I touch it, without getting entangled in the theological snarl, between Salvation by Faith and by Works? Can I trace, and unfold to demonstration the indissoluble union between religious and moral faith? can I show that it is the link of responsibility between man and his maker, and the only bond of Association between man and his brother? that it is the characteristic of his immortal nature? that it is the adamant of all human Society the cohesive principle of the gregarious animal man? Can I define its legitimate powers— Its vitality to the institution of government? to the relations of domestic life? to the peace and justice of independent communities? to the intercourse of trade and commerce? to all the public and all the private duties of man? Can I mark its limits— Its modifications of active and passive faith—of confidence, and fidelity? Can I sift the question how far Faith, is or is not dependent upon the will? and above all can I approach the question when and how far Faith may be violated without wrong—when and how its violation may be matter of indifference—when and how it may become a dictate of indispensable duty? And can I dress up all this matter—with seasoning to make it palatable for an hour and a half to a popular auditory who would not endure for a half an hour in a Sermon? I make with intense and foolish anxiety the attempt— Foolish, because after all a dull Lecture, would not be a very crying sin— My mothers Letters, Bancroft’s History, Broughams Oration for the crown, and this Evening Brownson’s defence of his Article on the laboring classes divided with newspaper trash, the reading hours of this day. I read half a dozen of my mothers Letters every day—economizing exquisite enjoyment, by taking it in small parcels— I can read scarcely one of them but with a stream of tears.— Charles hopes the publication will succeed, and says the bookseller told him he had sold 200 copies in five days from its first exposition for sale— This is moderately promising, but if the whole edition is not sold within a month, there will be little demand for the book ever after— As a double monument of Memorial to my mother and Son, it affects me so deeply, that my judgment of it, is all absorbed in feeling. The Ladies took tea, and spent the Evening at Charles’s house— I walked there in the dark; but the road was so miry that I rode with the Ladies home— I took with me Augers French translation of the Oration for the crown to compare him with Brougham— As to Mr Orestes Augustus Brownson I must use him at leisure, for a trial of temper.

4. IV:30. Sunday.  Sun set 5:39.  Communion day— Mr Lunt preached this morning, from Matthew 11.25. “At that time Jesus answered and said, I thank thee, O Father, Lord of Heaven and Earth; because thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast revealed them unto babes”—an argumentative and eloquent discourse upon the character and history of the Christian religion, comparing the obscurity, and feebleness of its origin with the magnificence and grandeur of its results. The lowliness of its founder with the sublimity of its purpose, and the vastness of its expansion— This is a theme upon which it is easy to be impressive, and impossible to exaggerate— If the personal history of Jesus Christ were all a fable, the miracle of the system would remain as inexplicable to human reason as it is to account for the facts. Mr Whitney joined, and took his part in the administration of the Communion—but he has passed the critical corner of three score years and ten, and is tottering to the last stage of all, which ends this strange eventful history— Mr Lunt’s afternoon sermon was from Matthew 3.11. “I indeed baptize you with water unto repentance: but he that cometh after me is mightier than I, whose shoes I am not worthy to bear: he shall baptize you, with the holy ghost and with fire.” The humility of John the Baptist, in proclaiming himself only the precursor of the Messiah was particularly noticed—but I want from Mr Lunt, an entire discourse upon the history, character, genealogy, birth, life and death of John the Baptist—of whom Jesus himself declared that among those that were born of women there was not a greater prophet— With regard to the language of the text Mr Lunt remarked that there in physical nature three materials of purification—Water Air and fire—and that the saying of John the Baptist, had allusion to this when he said figuratively that Christ would baptize with the holy ghost, and with fire.— Mr Lunt gave notice that from this time forward, for the winter the Sunday morning bell would be rung at half past ten, and the afternoon, at a quarter before two— The day was fair and the sky clear— I saw the Sunset in all his majesty from the porch of Charles’s house— The midshipman John Quincy, and his Sister Elizabeth spent the Evening here, as did Charles and his wife— I read a few of my mother’s Letters and a few pages of Bancroft’s History; but the burthen which now weighs me down is the Dissertation upon Faith, into the metaphysical part of which I am wading beyond my depth— My argument is assuming a religious complection from which I was desirous if possible of escaping, but which I perceive is unavoidable. As yet I am labouring it to lengthen it out, but before I finish, I may perhaps find it necessary to contract the field of discussion— I give myself till this day week to finish it, but shall find it necessary to labour in season and out of season, to bring it to a conclusion.

5. IV:30. Monday.  Sun rose 6.1.— Set 5:38.  Deacon Spear was here this morning, and told me that Mr Humphrey the Surveyor had agreed to come with him next Thursday, if the weather should be fair, and if not, the first fair day, afterwards; to go into the woods and measure the lot of woodland, derelict for want of an authenticated owner, but of which I am part owner, and the whole tax upon which the Assessors fasten upon me— They are to come at 9. O’Clock in the morning, and I desired Deacon Spear to ask my Son to go with us. Mr Peter Whitney, paid us also a morning visit— Very much gratified with my Son’s Lecture of last Thursday evening, which he wished might be published— He spoke also with warm approbation of the Memoir prefixed to my mothers Letters; and of the Letters themselves—and said he wished to see more of them.— This experiment is still upon trial— Mr Rogers of Marshfield, with his Son Dr Rogers came to converse with me concerning the petitions from the towns of Marshfield, Hanover and Pembroke, for a new survey, preliminary to an appropriation for the clearing out of obstructions in North-river— I told him that the petitions had at the last Session of Congress been referred in the House of Representatives to the Committee of Commerce, together with the old Petitions from Scituate for an appropriation to effect the improvement recommended by the report of the former survey— I observed that the petitions were in conflict with each other, and asked if the parties interested could not come to some compromise among themselves, as the effect of which their petitions would not clash with each other— Mr Rogers complained that Mr S. A. Turner, and the people of Scituate harbour had not been quite fair, in their exertions to obtain the removal of the obstruction at the precise spot most favourable to them, who in point of numbers bore no proportion to those who wished for the new survey; but he did not encourage any expectation that the parties could come to any agreement respecting their opposite petitions— He expressed a wish that I would go and visit them at Marshfield, for which I fear I shall not be able to find time this autumn; and he requested me ask Mr Webster for perusal of the papers which they sent to him with their Petitions last winter, which I promised to do— Charles told me that Mr Fuller, the Administrator of the two Moses Gills, had determined to decline accepting the proposal I made at the probate Court in Boston, to compromise the matter of the claim upon the Estate of Ward Nicholas Boylston, and had called upon John Lane Boylston for an Account as trustee for the annuity which his father had secured to the second Moses Gill— He thinks Mr Fuller is advised to go into the Law, upon this matter, and that it will cost him more than the whole amount of the claim— I am so much engrossed with the Lecture upon faith, that I have no time now to give continuous attention to any thing else— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.

6. IV. Tuesday.  The Caledonia, the third of Mr Cunard’s line of Royal Mail Steam-packets from Liverpool to Halifax and Boston; arrived at the wharf East-Boston last Saturday Morning, having left Liverpool on the 19th. of last month, the day of our return from our excursion— The Acadia had arrived at Liverpool on Sunday the 13th. at Midnight, the day of our arrival at Houlton— It is scarcely possible for me to realize the rapidity with which these Steamers accomplish the passage across the Atlantic— I chanced to be reading my mother’s journalizing Letter to my Aunt Cranch, of her voyage from Boston to Deal in June and July 1784. fifty six years bygone an excellent summer passage of 30 days.— And now in 34 days, I have learnt here the arrival in England of the vessel in which I embarked for Halifax on the first day of September. There is one more ship to be put upon this line—The Columbia, after which they are to depart twice every Month— The three ships in succession the Britannia, Acadia and Caledonia have performed their voyages in an average of 13 days, touching at Halifax both coming and going.— Harvey Field was here this morning, and spent with me two or three hours talking of trade, farming, house building and selling and politics— He is collector of the parish tax, and I paid him 209.12 the amount of my tax for the present year, 149.25 of which was his payment of rent to me, for the Penn’s hill farm— He is desirous of having renewed the lease of that, together with Lewis Bass and Mr Wilde for 5 years more. I referred him for all this to my Son. He asked me for a list of all the towns in the 12th Congressional District, which I gave Charles for him— He was much delighted with Charles’s Lecture last Thursday Evening, and wishes him to deliver another.— Mr Smith came out from Boston again, with another, elder Sister to repeat the invitation from the New-York Lyceum to deliver a Lecture before them, sometime in the course of the next Month— Wearied out with importunities, I gave him a conditional promise that I would comply with the invitation if it should be in my power. His Sister also asked me for an autograph of my father; and I promised to look up and send her one— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— He purchased for me ten shares of the Boston and Providence rail-road stock at 95 1/2 for which I gave him a check on the Quincy Stone Bank for 955 dollars— The ladies took tea at Mrs. T. B. Adamss—and I walked with Charles there in the Evening— Found Elizabeth De Wint there.— Her mother left Boston to return home to Fishkill Landing last Saturday. Mr Simmons had also been this afternoon at Mrs Adams’s, but was gone before we got there.— We walked home— In the reading of my mother’s Letters I have reached the period after the close of the revolutionary War, and a smoother Sea. They still affect me beyond expression— I read some pages of Brownson’s defence— To pass from my mother’s Letters to the effusions of this viper, is like a leap from Paradise to Purgatory— I went to Charles’s house and saw the Sun rise at 6:3. and again and saw him set at 5:36 Fahrenheit this morning at 48. Day warm with clear Sunshine—

7. II and VI. Wednesday—  Sun rose beclouded. Set 5.34.  While we were at breakfast this morning, I was called out by two young men, who introduced each other by the names of Bannister and Moore— They wished to see the Library given by my father to the town, which I accordingly shewed them. Mr Moore said that he was a lawyer, and might wish occasionally to consult the books in the Library. He had heard that it was open for the use of the Inhabitants of the town. I told him that it was so, and that if he wished to come and consult the books, I would have a table placed in the chamber for his convenience— I had heard that this young man had recently come to this town to practice the law, for which John M. Gourgas appears already more than enough— The next visitors were judge Thacher from the State of Maine, and Mrs Thatcher, a daughter of the revolutionary General Henry Knox— The other daughter is at present the wife of Mr John Holmes— Judge Thacher spoke to me of a claim of the children of General Knox, for 1100 acres of land under a resolve of the old continental Congress for his service in the revolutionary War. He did not know whether the General had ever received the land or not, and enquired if I thought the information could be obtained at Washington— I supposed it might, at the general Land Office, and offered to make enquiries when I should go on to Washington as I propose next Month— He promised to write me a statement of the claim, and of the particular information desired, of which I take note to be remembered at the proper time He said it was reported in Maine that the present Legislature of the State, now in Session had it in contemplation to take the choice of electors for the ensuing presidential election from the people, and to choose them themselves, which I can scarcely credit— Mr Lunt was also here this morning and introduced Mr William Joseph Adams, a teacher of one of the public schools in Boston, who is engaged in compiling genealogical notices of the family and descendants of the first Henry Adams of Mount Wollaston— I lent him the copy of his Will which came from Jedidiah Adams; and also the transcript from the first Volume of the original town Records of births and marriages and deaths at Braintree— This William Joseph, is a lineal descendant from the second Henry, of Medfield through a succession of four generations by the name of Moses.— his elder brother is the 5th. of that name.— George W. Beale junr was here this Evening.— I found in the National Intelligencer of the 3d. inst a curious Article upon John Forsyth and the Pope Gregory 16. with the Popes Bull of 3. December 1839. against the African Slave trade. Mr. Forsyth in an electioneering Letter to a democratic committee in Georgia attributes this Bull to English influence— I had long been wishing to see this Bull, of which I had before heard, but which had not been published in any of our Newspapers. Forsyth’s Letter is in Niles’s Register.

8. III:45. Thursday.  Mr William Joseph Adams, came this morning, and returned the Volume copied from the Braintree Records and the other papers that he had yesterday borrowed— Neither his researches nor those of Dr Shattuck have discovered much additional information concerning the Adams family to the scanty notices which had been collected before. Immediately after breakfast, Mr Humphrey the Surveyor came with Deacon Spear and his Son, and we went with my Son, and surveyed the lot, the property in which has not yet been fully ascertained, but for which I have been many years taxed— On the 14th. of October 1834. I visited this woodlot with Deacon Spear, notice of which is in my journal of that day. Vol. 12. p. 421. since which I have done nothing concerning it— We now surveyed it regularly with chain and compass, and Mr Humphrey will make a plan of it, upon which we can afterwards proceed. We returned just in time for dinner. I invited Mr Humphrey to dine with us, but he declined. Ruth Turner is here, upon mantua making work.— Mrs T. B.
