Adams her daughter Elizabeth, with Mary Harrod and Elizabeth De Wint took tea here, and spent the Evening— The Midshipman John Quincy came in after tea— Charles and his wife was here of course.— My excursion into the woods cut short my journal for the day, but I did not intermit the portion of writing on the Lecture upon Faith— Yesterday Morning I waked up not knowing the hour, and upon lighting my lamp, and coming into my chamber found it was two O’Clock— It was warm so I sat down at my desk in my loose gown, and wrote upon my lecture till four—then went to bed again, and dozed till six—broad daylight, and just before Sun rise— Brownson’s defence of his Article upon the labouring classes, and my mother’s Letters, occupying my reading time for the present— Brownson covers his attack upon religion—by pointing it against the priests—under which denomination he includes all regularly settled clergymen— He professes the Quaker creed, and greatly admires their meetings of silent meditation— But his greatest of all abhorrencies is poverty, as a remedy for which he proposes to abolish all hereditary property— Men are to dispose of their property at their pleasure while they live, but when they die it is to revert to the community— This he deduces as an irresistible consequence from the natural equality of men, and from the principles of Democracy. Brownson has a petty Office, given him by the Collector of the customs at Boston George Bancroft, whom he accordingly bedaubs with fulsome flattery— The drift of all his discourse is to inflame the passions of the poor, against the rich, and as Van Buren’s policy must be to sustain the institution of Slavery, Brownson stoutly affirms that Slavery is better than the system of free labour.— Some of his opinions are so odious that the leaders of his party dare not endorse them—they complain that he has brought them out too soon— He replies to this objection by repeating the doctrines, and blustering about his Independence—

9. IV:30. Friday  The last four days have been so warm, that I have had no fire in my library; but I was obliged to come to it again this afternoon. Charles went to Boston this morning, and returned to dine— He and his wife and two elder Sons, dined with us, and Mr Lunt, who told us that George and Augustus Whitney, had prevailed upon the Sexton of the Stone Meeting house to open the tomb in our grave-yard, where all the past Ministers of the church lie buried— That a parcel of bones was all that they found there except a small piece of wood, the remnant of Mr Wibird’s coffin, and a tinplate— That his skull was entire—that George Whitney took it out of the vault, and expressed some desire to carry it away.— The whole procedure struck us, as neither very regular, nor very delicate— Charles and his wife did not stay to tea, but came in afterwards and passed the remainder of the Evening here— I was occupied nearly the whole day in endeavouring to retrieve the lost time of yesterday—without success— I got through the reading of Brownson’s defence, and incline to prepare a Lecture upon Democracy. I am drawing near to the close of that which I am now writing. It will be as long as I could have desired, but is altogether unsatisfactory to me, and I fear likely to be not less unsatisfactory to the hearers. I have not been able to gather into it all that I wished to say on the subject; nor to methodize it into a regular dissertation— The two main positions which I wish to establish, are truths infinitely important to religion and morals. 1. That religious faith, and moral faith are one and the same principle and 2 That religious faith is dependent upon the will— The great fault of the subject is that it is Dry as dust, and I fear will prove as tedious as a dull Sermon, while it must be as long as three. The part which I have failed to work into the composition is the successive enumeration of the Covenants of God with man, recorded throughout the Bible, and an impressive series of illustrations of the transcendent importance of faith as a rule of morals.— I ought to write this Lecture over again, or another on the same subject— My mother’s Letters continue deeply to affect me, as I read them; about half a dozen a day.— They bring back to my recollection so many scenes that I passed through, and which were almost obliterated from my memory, so many persons, with whom I was acquainted, and some of whom were my dear friends, and above all so many tokens of tenderness and affection more that maternal, which she heaped upon me throughout her life, that I can scarcely touch the book, without falling back into childhood— The merit of the Letters as literary compositions, though always known to me, never struck me so forcibly as in this collection. Very favourable notice of them has been taken in the North-American Review, the Boston Daily Advertiser, and this day in the Courier.— The Bookseller told Charles this day, that about half the edition of 1000 copies has already been sold.

10. III.30. Saturday  Sun rose 6.6. Set 5:29.Fahrenheit 32.  Jonathan French some time my gardener, now teacher of one of the town schools, came with one of his boys, a son of Mr Gillett the stage driver, and asked to see what he called the record of the Adams family; by which he meant the old table of concentric circles made in 1799. by Elijah Adams of Medfield, which I shewed him— He said that Gillets son wanted to make out a similar table of his own family; but I imagine that the teacher wanted it as much as the pupil. This passion for genealogy, seems to be anti-democratic, but it is deeply seated in human nature— I feel it intensely myself, and often regret that the first and second Henry Adams, left no memorial of their emigration from England, whence they came and when—and what relatives they left in England.— Of the first and second Joseph Adams, the birth, marriages and death are recorded on the parish or town books: the copies of their Will, and town records contain a few very scanty notices of incidents in their lives, but not a book or scrap of paper remains— Willards body of Divinity is the only book of my grandfather’s that has come down; to that folio volume, printed in 172he was a subscriber, and in a blank leaf before its title page are entered in his own hand-writing the date of his marriage with Susanna Boylston, and of the births of his three Sons, John, Peter Boylston and Elihu— He was a Selectman of the town, and Deacon of the Church, but his education was only that of the town school, and his condition of life, much like that of the brothers Ebenezer and Josiah Adams of the present day— That I suppose was the condition of the family from the settlement at Mount Wollaston—till my father. Harvard College, made my grandfather’s elder brother Joseph Minister of Newington, and my father’s Cousin Zabdiel Minister of Lunenburg. A spark of etherial fire in the Soul of my father, kindling at the lamp of that call made my father a scholar, a lawyer, a patriot, a Statesman and one of the prime founders of the greatest republics that ever honoured the race of Man. That father, a mother worthy of such a husband, Harvard College, Leyden University, seven years of youthful travel, and the blessing of Heaven, have made of me a common-place personage, par negotiis nec supra—just able to sustain the position in which they placed me, and about to disappear from the Stage, leaving nothing behind me worthy of being remembered in after ages.— Having lived with unceasing aspirations for unfading glory as a benefactor of mankind.— The spark of ethereal fire descends not from sire to son— A proof of this will be seen, in my Lecture upon Faith, this day finished—for the measure of a man’s mind is in every paper that he composes for public exhibition— If I try again it will be with no better success.— My wife, with Mrs John and Mrs Charles went to Boston this afternoon and returned to tea— I visited my garden and Nursery and gathered walnuts and English Oak Acorns, but planted none.

11. V. Sunday.  Sun beclouded— Cold rain. Evening clear.Full Moon  Morning Sermon from Mr Lunt Ezekiel 1.28.— “This was the appearance of the likeness of the glory of the Lord. And when I saw it, I fell upon my face, and I heard a voice of one that spake.” He had read the whole first chapter of Ezekiel, and had given out the 100th. Psalm, and the beautiful hymn of Watts, the 61st. of Belknap’s collection— The Sermon was an admirable exposition of the vision, with the narrative of which the prophet introduces his Message from the Lord.— He noticed the time and place of the vision—the fifth day, month and year, by the river Chebar in the land of the Chaldeans— The whirlwind from the North, the living creatures with their four faces of a man, a lion, an ox and an eagle—the wheel within the middle of the wheel—the firmament over the living creature,—the noise of the wings like the noise of great waters—the throne above the wheels, and the likeness of a man upon the throne— The allegorical meaning of all this was explained with great ingenuity, and how it all concurred to form the likeness of the glory of the Lord— The connection between this Book, and the Apocalypse of the New Testament was not alluded to, nor the supposed designation of the four evangelists Matthew, Mark, Luke and John— The remarks upon the temper of mind suited to the discharge of the duties of the prophetical office were impressive and their application to the prophetical functions of the Christian ministry of modern times, though not directly made were sufficiently perceptible in the tenour of the discourse— The afternoon text was from Acts 17:11. “These were more noble than those in Thessalonica, in that they received the word with all readiness of mind, and searched the scriptures daily whether those things were so”— The comparison between the Thessalonians and the Bereans, with regard to the reception of the gospel, is more of a common topic for a sermon, than the vision of Ezekiel— There can be no novelty in the discussion, but Mr Lunt always commands the attention of his auditory, and always gives them matter for useful meditation. He read this afternoon a notification that the annual convention of the friends of education in Norfolk County would be holden in this first Congregational Church, next Wednesday at ten O’Clock in the forenoon— That an Address would be delivered by the Honourable Horace Mann, the Secretary to the Board of Education, and that several interesting questions would be discussed in relation to the best modes of governing and examining schools. All interested, as well ladies as gentlemen were requested to be present, especially School Committees and teachers—and friends of the cause from other parts of the State— The Norfolk County Association for the improvement of Common Schools are to hold their meeting at the same time and place, and a full attendance is desired— Mr Degrand came out from Boston; dined with us, went to meeting with me this afternoon, and spent the remainder of the day and evening with us— He brought us the Boston and other Newspapers, which give favourable accounts of recent elections held in the States of Delaware and Maryland— The prospects at present are that Martin Van Buren’s Administration will terminate on the 3d. of March next, and that William Henry Harrison of Ohio, will succeed him as President of the United States— Quod felix faustumque sit— I have not yet dared to indulge myself with the hope.

12. V. Monday.  Sun rose 6.9. beclouded. Set 5.26.  Mr Lysander Richards the present President of the Quincy Lyceum came to enquire if I could deliver the Lecture which I have promised, before that Institution next Wednesday week; and I engaged accordingly; but the pressure upon my time is insupportable— I received this day a Letter from Joseph E. Sprague of Salem, most earnestly intreating me to deliver a Lecture there— I have three applications pending from Boston, and one from Brooklyn Long Island besides numbers which I have declined— I commenced this day a second Lecture, to succeed the one which I have finished upon faith—but I have no plan for this second one, and I know not where it will lead me— I have debarred myself from the discussion of political subjects while all others are uncongenial to my taste, and foreign to my qualifications— I find indeed that upon whatever subject I begin, my thoughts involuntarily run both into religion and politics. Subjects frequently occur to me upon which I fear to begin; apprehensive that they would absorb more time than I can bestow upon researches necessary for treating them suitably— And there is something consummately ridiculous in travelling 3 or 400 miles, to deliver a lecture which nine-tenths of the hearers will yawn through the meeting where it is to be pronounced— Mr Cornell, and Mr Moore the young Lawyer recently moved into this town came this afternoon—requesting to visit the town library— Mr Moore borrowed the first Volume of the Quarto Blackstone, and Mr Cornell the first and second Volumes of Goldsmith’s History of England— Mr Moore boards with Mr Cornell, and the Mr Chamberlain who came here with him last week is now preaching at the orthodox church.— Mr Baynes who brought me last autumn a letter of introduction for Dr Codman, did not remain here more than three months, and is now preaching at Amesbury. Mr Cornell has about 20 scholars and repeated the invitation to me to visit his school— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, and took my balanced book, and occupied a considerable part of the morning in settling some of my monthly bills.— After dinner I wrote two very short Letters—one to George Fuller of Medford, and the other to Francis Hall joint Editor of the Commercial Advertiser, who had written to me, requesting a copy of my Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette, for a correspondent of his in lower Canada.— I send him a copy accordingly. The volume of my Mother’s Letters still holds out, and still affords me a daily hour of exquisite enjoyment— Several of the Letters I had never before read.— Those to myself are more admirable than they seemed to me when I received them— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here, and E. Price Greenleaf.— Ruth Turner is still at work here; and Miss Sampson up the hill at Charles’s.

13. III.45. Tuesday.  Sun rose 6.10. beclouded. Set 5.24. clear.  Alpheus Spear was here this morning; and paid the quarter’s rent due the 30th. of last Month— We left for after arrangement to which I must not fail to attend, the parish tax upon the Mount Wollaston farm, and the releasing of the farm, from and after the 31st. of next March. The Midshipman my namesake was also here this forenoon, and Mr Loring of Hingham after dinner.— He told me that the administration party of the 12th. congressional District had held their Meeting yesterday, and had nominated Morton Jackson as their Candidate for the next Congress, and he seemed apprehensive that the abolitionists of the District would also vote for him, and he was evidently more uneasy for the result than he was willing to acknowledge— The aggregate vote of the 24 towns in the District, last year was a majority for Governor Morton, although the abolitionists voted for Mr Everett. The abolitionists this year have nominated Seth Sprague junr. but he is absent in Europe, and Loring thinks they will vote for Jackson; a fiery abolitionist. He said that Mr May of Scituate was friendly to me, and wished to see and converse with me, upon the subject— That he had been sore upon my declaration against the immediate abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, but that he was disposed overlook that on a pledge from me in favour of a prohibition of the Slave trade in the District— I told him I should be glad to see and converse with Mr May; but I gave no encouragement to the idea, of calling upon me for a pledge— The whigs of the District are to hold their Convention at Plympton to-morrow. It is probable, but not certain that they will nominate me. If they do, and the abolitionists vote for Jackson, he will carry the election against me— If they vote for Sprague there will be no choice.— There is not in the United States a District in which the issue is more uncertain, and my mind must be made up to bear the last stroke of dismission from the public service, by the total abandonment of the people— Mrs Edward Miller, Elizabeth C. Adams, and Mary Harrod, were also here— Miss Harrod takes her departure to-morrow for New-Orleans— Mrs Morton and Sarah Apthorp called to visit my wife; but she was engaged, and I thought she was out. Mrs Morton is four-score years of age, and retains a ruin of her former beauty—with apparent good health— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine; and sent me the unexpected intelligence of the success of the whigs at the elections in Georgia— I rode with the Ladies to Mr John Greenleaf’s, and saw in her chamber his wife, my Cousin, once Lucy Cranch.— She is suffering with a disease which it is apprehended she cannot long survive— She told me she believed the wife of our ancestor John Norton was a daughter of Daniel and Elizabeth Mason. I walked home. Charles and his wife were not here this Evening.

14. III.45. Wednesday—  Sun rose 6.11. Set 5:22 both clear.  This day was taken away from my ordinary occupations, when I could ill afford to spare it. Just before ten this morning I called at French’s tavern, and enquired for Mr Mann who was there— I found Mr Pettes with him, and Mr Lunt— I invited them to dine with me— They were both engaged to Mr Lunt, but he released them in my favour— The meeting of the Norfolk County Association friends of education and the Society for the improvement of common Schools, was exceedingly slender, certainly not amounting to one hundred persons including at least one half women.— Even of the Committee of Arrangements who had been appointed to rally a numerous meeting, Mr Pettes was the only one present; Mr Cozzens being out upon a journey; and Mr Ira Cleveland detained by the necessity of attending a political Caucus— A Committee of 3. was appointed to report sundry Resolutions for the Convention to consider and they reported them, all apparently prepared by Mr Mann, and which were adopted after some discussion, and an amendment of the first resolution which left it much as it was— Mr Barnard a Secretary of the board of Education in Connecticut made some very interesting remarks respecting the condition of the School houses in that State. Between 12 and 1. they adjourned till 2. and ten of the company whom I invited came home and dined with me, together with my Son— While we were at dinner Mr E Wright came with a subscription paper for a translation of La Fontaine’s Fables with a Lithographic caricature print to each fable.— As I could not well attend to this gentleman now he promised to come again to-morrow. As we were returning to the Church after dinner, Mr Barnard said he was charged with an invitation from a joint literary historical association at Hartford, and New-Haven, to deliver an introductory Lecture before them on my way to Washington. I promised an answer at an early day— These invitations multiply upon me, most oppressively— The afternoon meeting was rather more thinly attended than that of the morning— The Officers of the Association were re-elected for the ensuing year and Mr Mann delivered his address; occupying nearly two hours, though he appeared to read not more than half what was written— A truly eloquent discourse upon the duties of Parents in the education of their children— The Convention adjourned at 5. O’Clock— Returning home I stop’d at Charles’s house and saw the Sun set. Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. and his wife were there, and took tea. They had been at the afternoon meeting— Mrs Charles had a severe head-ache— So had Mrs John, and our Evening party at home was small.

15. IV. Thursday.  I forgot to mention yesterday that Mr Lemuel Humphrey brought me the plan of the woodlot which we surveyed last Thursday, and for which I paid him 4. dollars— This morning Mr Wright came again with his subscription paper, for his translation of the Fables of La Fontaine— There are to be three editions at a price from 3 to 10 dollars for a copy. I had read several of those in the little volume he had left with me, and thought them very flat—much more so than the translations of several of the same fables that I had myself made,—a circumstance which doubtless biassed my judgment— I declined subscribing for the book— Mr Wright told me that he had been a Secretary of an Anti-Slavery Society; but that has now become a very unprofitable concern. Mr George G. Spencer of Hartford, Connecticut, brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Joseph Trumbull, a member of Congress from that State— Mr Spencer came to invite me to deliver a Lecture, before the young men’s Institute; the same which had been mentioned to me yesterday by Mr Barnard.— I told him that being uncertain when I shall proceed to Washington and whether I can take my way through Hartford, or not, I could not give him a definitive answer now, but would write to him in the course of a few days. Mr E. Price Greenleaf called this afternoon, and returned one volume and took out another of Muratori’s Annals of Italy from the town Library.— He told me that the whig convention, for the 12th. Congressional District had their meeting at Plympton— That the meeting was numerous, and had unanimously nominated me for re-election to the 27th. Congress— That the Delegates from Quincy had been instructed to urge the nomination of me, but had no occasion to produce their instructions— That no other person was named or thought of— That there were several abolitionists among the delegates, but they all concurred with the rest— He said Mr Rowe had been appointed a delegate from Milton to this Convention, but had mistaken the day, supposing it was this day, and had thus not attended yesterday; but that he would have voted with the rest.— I went this afternoon with my wife and Charles and his wife to Milton to visit Mrs Forbes, the widow of Ralph Bennet Forbes, and sister of Coll. Thomas H. Perkins, but she was not at home— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us— Yesterday morning I finished reading the printed volume of my mothers Letters— They fill a duo decimo volume of 500 pages; and three volumes more might be published of those which she wrote, scarcely less interesting. I am still drudging upon a Lecture on the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and upon Democracy.

16. IV:15. Friday.  I received this morning a Letter from Mr Horace Mann the Secretary of the board of Education; mentioning that he had brought out a copy of the Abstract of the Massachusetts school returns for 1839 and 1840, intending to give it to me; but had forgetfully left it in his chamber at French’s tavern, where he requested me to call and claim it— I went accordingly, and it was delivered to me by Mr French’s Son.— It is an octavo volume of nearly 500 pages— At the Stone Bank where I called to make a deposit and draw 100 dollars by a check I found an Atlas extra with later and more favorable reports of the election in Pennsylvania than those received yesterday.— The election of Charles J. Ingersoll to Congress, by a majority of more than 1600 votes, in the third District, was a heavy damper to the exultation of the whigs, for it shews the public opinion has definitively settled down in the district, against the validity of Naylor’s election in1838. But the Atlas shouts Io triumphe for New-Jersey, where it boasts that the whole ticket of the whigs rejected last winter, has now been elected to the 27th. Congress— This is five times in number, and 500 times in principle, an equivalent for the loss of the third District in Pennsylvania— Naylor had sometime since declined standing as a candidate for re-election, which had cast ominous conjecture on the whole success. Mr John B. Newhall now of the territory of Iowa, being upon a visit to his friends and relatives in this State of which he is a native, called merely to indulge curiosity in seeing me— His father is living and resides at Lynn.— He emigrated in 1835 to the western country, and lives at Burlington, the principal settlement in Iowa, where he says there is now a population of 1500 Souls.— He gave me a crooked stick which he said was cut off from the spot where had stood the wigwam of Black Hawk, and he shewed me a beautiful map drawn by himself of the territory of Iowa, shewing that he has no lack of talent.— He left me at Noon to return by the Plymouth Stage to Boston— Mr and Mrs James H. Foster were also here before dinner, and Mr E. Price Greenleaf after dinner— He walked with me round my Garden and Nursery and Seminary, all which are looking desolate with the falling leaf and frost-bitten flowers— Charles and his wife were here this Evening, and I read to the family my Lecture upon Faith; to consult them whether it would be expedient to deliver it here or any where— It occupied an hour and ten minutes— They thought it might do at Quincy; possibly at Boston, but Not at New-York. I am making steady, but very indifferent progress in the composition of another.

17. IV:15. Saturday.  Mr Lincoln of Hingham, Mr Richards of Braintree, and Mr Brigham of this town, came this morning as a Committee of the Convention of the 12th. Congressional District, held last Wednesday the 14th. instt at Plympton by the whigs, to inform me that I had been unanimously nominated for re-election to represent the District in the 27th Congress, and he gave me a Letter signed by the three members of the Committee, containing the same information, with a request that I would accept the nomination— He read to me also from the Hingham Patriot a Resolution of the Convention declaring their unabated confidence in me; and left the paper with me— I told them that I accepted the nomination with a grateful sense of the Resolution with which it was accompanied— That I would answer their Letter; and should avail myself of the occasion to repeat what I had already stated to Mr Lincoln, that I had felt myself under a peculiar obligation to abstain from attendance at all the public meetings which had been held in the course of the present year having reference to the approaching Presidential Election— That a sense of propriety, had heretofore prescribed it as a rule to all Ex-Presidents of the United States, to abstain from all interference in the election of their Successors; and although the last President, Jackson had departed from that rule, as the present President Van-Buren has departed from another rule forbidding any candidate for the Presidency to canvass for himself, disapproving of these practices; I am unwilling to give countenance to them by following the example— That besides this any active electioneering on my part would be liable to the imputation of personal envy, resentment or revenge, and to the further interested motive of seeking to promote my own re-election to Congress. I had therefore refrained during this recess of Congress even from addressing my Constituents by Letter as I had repeatedly done before. Mr Lincoln intimated a wish that I should allude in my written answer to the Committee to these reasons for my silence, which I promised to do.— After dinner Dr Bowditch, and Mr James M. Barnard came, and repeated again the invitation to deliver a Lecture to the Warren Street Association—which I promised to do on Tuesday the 27th. instt.— I am to meet them at the chapel at half past 7 in the Evening, and they are to have a Carriage there ready to bring me home after the Lecture is over.— Ruth Turner has been working here as a seamstress several days, and took leave this Evening. Mary-Elizabeth Dawes is here, a companion to our Mary-Louisa.

18. V. Sunday.  Heard Mr Lunt; this morning from Hebrews 2.4. [“]God also, bearing them witness, both with signs and wonders, and with divers miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to his own will.” The necessity of the performance of miracles, by Jesus Christ himself, and his Apostles, to authenticate his mission from God, was stated and well-reasoned so far as it can be sustained.— The necessity cannot be demonstrated any otherwise than by inference from the fact— It was necessary because it was the will of God—for independent of that what necessity was there for miracles then, any more than now— Miracles, exhibited now, would propagate the gospel more effectively than any merely uninspired preaching.— And we see not why the Christian system of religion and morals could not have made its way by its internal evidence then as well as now. The truth is that at this day, the history, is the chief obstacle to the belief in the doctrines— There is great difficulty to believe the Miracles— The religious and moral instructions are all surpassing beauty— And Mr Lunt dilated with admirable eloquence upon the miracles achieved by Christianity upon the hearts and upon the conduct of mankind— This is a perpetual miracle and an inexhaustible theme. Mr Lunt dined with us; as did my Son. The afternoon text, following a prayer by Mr Whitney, was from Matthew 22.30. [“]For in the resurrection they neither marry, nor are given in marriage; but are as the Angels of God in Heaven”— This was the answer to a captious question from the Sadducees who disbelieved a future state. They enquired which of seven husband that a woman had married successively on earth would be her husband in Heaven. The answer is that the relation of husband and wife will not be continued in the future world—whence it follows that there will be no relation of parent and child there. Mr Lunt speculated ingeniously, and feelingly upon the possibilities of our future state of existence; but there is little satisfaction in anticipations founded upon mere conjecture.— The resurrection of the dead to reward or punishment is a cheering promise and a tremendous commination, but what the reward or the punishment will be is veiled in impenetrable darkness— As there is no marriage, there can be no distinction of sexes; and though Milton says that Spirits can assume either sex at pleasure he had no warrant for the assertion, and knew no more about it than one of us.— There is no reason to believe that the Angels or Spirits of the just made perfect possess in Heaven the power of reproduction; or that they multiply otherwise than by recruits from Earth. Mr Lunt’s visions are pleasant—but I cannot take them for promises. Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us.

19. IV. Monday.  Sun rose 6:17. Set 5.14. Fahrenheit 32.  Mr Clendenin a travelling bookseller who brought here this morning a Quarto Volume called Pictorial Geography—by Samuel Griswold Goodrich, but with whom Mr Clendenin says that Mr Jared Sparks is associated in the composition of the work. It is a system of Universal Geography with very few maps, and those on so small a scale as to be quite useless but with several hundred wood cuts a fashion of modern printing which may be, or might be made instructive— I declined subscribing for, or taking the book, the price of which was 7 dollars, and I supposed to be worth 3. Mr Goodrich himself called on me this afternoon, and in the Evening delivered an Address of an hour and three quarters before the whig Association of Quincy, at the town Hall— He told me what had entirely escaped my Memory that about 15 years since he went to Europe, that he visited me at Washington with an introductory Letter from his uncle Chauncey Goodrich with whom more than thirty years I had sitten in the Senate of the United States. I have only an indistinct recollection of having received such a Letter from Mr Chauncey Goodrich— I went to Charles’s house at their teatime, and met there Miss Sampson the seamstress— Charles went with me to the town Hall, where we were much amused with Mr Goodrich’s Address— A species of Oratory which he possesses in an eminent degree— Free, fluent, familiar he mingles up desultory argument with frequent droll, laughable stories, exactly suited to the taste of his auditory. He was continually cheered by shouts of laughter and clapping of hands.— The Hall was crowded to over-flowing— His topics were the anti-tariff and anti-bank, and anti-currency policy of Martin of Kinderhoek, and most especially upon the great plea for the subtreasury that it will reduce the working man’s wages.— As soon as Mr Goodrich closed his Address, Mr Brigham read a notification, that next Friday Evening Mr Isaac Hill of New-Hampshire would deliver an Address to the Democratic Association of Quincy— The political excitement is so great that scarcely an evening passes without a political Address; and the parties take the nights alternately— It has opened a new school of Oratory, which I fear will not deserve the name of a school of eloquence— After returning home I answered the Letter of notification of Messrs. Lincoln, Brigham and Richards the Committee of the whig Convention of the 12th. Congressional District, accepting the nomination— I am excessively cramped for time, to fill the daily record of my existence, and two pages of preparation for a Lecture— I am so hurried with that upon which I am now engaged that the composition will be the worst that I ever delivered.

20. IV. Tuesday.  I am hurried and worried with invitations to deliver lectures, till I know not what to do, and neglect business which ought to be indispensable— One of its consequences is that it sets my mind to wandering in search of subjects to make a variety and scatters my thoughts from those on which I have undertaken to discourse— I am drawing towards the close of the second of those which I am preparing for the present Season—and they are both too grave and dry— I rack my brain for one which will be amusing— This requires wit and humour of which I am lamentably destitute; and reflection whispers that the attempt to make others laugh recoils upon him who makes the experiment, and raises the smile at himself, when he is too heavy to carry the hearer with him— A very serious danger is that of ruining my Style by over hasty composition. General Dearborn, and Mr Joseph E. Sprague of Salem were here— I had received a Letter from Mr Sprague with an urgent invitation to deliver a Lecture before the Lyceum which I now agreed to do on Wednesday the 4th. of November. I had much conversation with these Gentlemen, on the recent news from Europe, and the prospect of a general War.— The Acadia arrived at Boston last Saturday Morning, having left Liverpool on Sunday the 4th. of this Month; and been detained 10 hours at Halifax— From the 1st. of September to the 17th. of October is 47. days both included, in which time this ship has completed both her voyages to and fro— This is marvellous in our eyes.— The prospects of War, are for the final dismemberment, and it is to be hoped extinction of the Ottoman Empire; and for breaking down the impenetrable barriers of the celestial empire of China— Here are two new doors opening wide for the extension of the power of man over the globe of earth— The prevailing opinion in Europe and here, yet is that there will be for the present no War, but there are strong indications of a kindling martial and mutually hostile spirit— The elections in the States of Pennsylvania and Ohio have just been held and the returns coming in daily keep up a constant excitement— There never has been so hotly contested an election and the result is yet extremely doubtful. My time was absorbed the whole of this afternoon from dinner till dark in searching for two papers, neither of which could I find— Miss Sampson was here.

21. V.15 Wednesday  Drizzling rain the whole day and evening—with occasional copious showers. My wife, Mrs John, and Charles and his wife went nevertheless to Boston, and returned to dine; the Ladies having passed most of the morning at Dr Frothingham’s, and been obliged to postpone most of their shopping, to another day.— I was intensely occupied with the Lecture upon the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and democracy, till the carriage returned at 3.p.m— I find that when I commence a Lecture, I know not where it will lead me. I have begun a lecture on the Constitution of Massachusetts, with reference to democracy and I find myself slumping into Sir Robert Filmer, Algernon Sidney and John Locke— I have not Sir Robert Filmer’s works within my reach— But I have Locke and, I went over and brought from the town library two Editions of Sidney’s Discourses concernind Government.— One in 2. Volumes 8vo. Edinburgh 1750. with my fathers name 1766. written with his own hand on the blank leaf before the title page; and the other one quarto Volume—London 1772. With his Letters and his trial in addition to his Discourses concerning Government— Looking into these books I found not only matter pertinent to my Lecture but leading into the temptation to write another Lecture exclusively concerning Sidney, his life and writings—but this absorbed a considerable part of the day.— There is a deep shade of melancholy hanging over the whole life of Sidney, whose opinions seem to have resembled in many respects those of La Fayette.— The motto on his standard “Sanctus amor patriae dat animum”—the perseverance of his spirit—the harshness of his father, who contrived to keep well with all the prevailing parties during the civil wars and at the restoration of the Stuarts resumed his seat in the house of peers and became a privy Councillor—the abandonment of him by all his relations, and friends—his long exile of 17 years before his pardon was obtained, and the horrible baseness and cruelty of his trial and execution sink the spirits to read.— This afternoon Mr Green the editor of the Quincy Patriot, came with a message from Mr Lysander Richards President of the Quincy Lyceum requesting me to postpone till this day week the delivery of the Lecture which I had promised for this day, to which I readily assented, there being no prospect of an auditory in the foul weather of this Evening.— Charles spent it with us, but not his wife— I brought over also from the town library the report of the proceedings of the Convention of 1820 for amending the Constitution of this Commonwealth; but had not time to consult it this day. I read a few pages of the Correspondence, concerning the Affairs of China, reported last year to the British Parliament—

22. IV 15. Thursday.  The rain and foul weather continued through the Night and till noon this day, when it cleared off with a Northwester cold— Alpheus Spear was here, and brought a load of wood from the dead trees on the mount Wollaston farm— He spoke about his fence which he said he must remove if the Lease should not be renewed, before the frost should take hold of the ground. And that he would not give the same rent, on the renewal of the lease in the present condition of the meadows. I told him he might remove his fence when he pleased— The farm would be advertised, and he might renew the lease or not, at his pleasure; but not for the rent at which he now has it— My Son, his wife and three elder children dined and spent part of the Evening with us; but he was suffering with a very severe headache, and they left us early in the Evening. Russel Freeman was here this afternoon— He came from Sandwich on Tuesday, and now on horseback from Boston— He came to ask my advice about his prospect of recovering his place of Collector at New Bedford, from which Andrew Jackson removed him immediately after his inauguration as President in March 1829. He said he considered it as settled that General Harrison would be elected President—that the present Collector Smith’s commission will expire in January 1842. That all the respectable merchants at New Bedford are in favour of his restoration, but he believes Mr Clifford, an influential whig would be glad to obtain the place for his father in Law— What would I advise him to do— I said, to wait— General Harrison was not yet elected— It was not certain that he would be— If he should be I thought it probable that Mr Webster would be Secretary of the Treasury, in which case all the papers, which he Freeman had exhibited to the present Secretary Woodbury, would be on the files of the Department, and his prospects would be very fair. If Mr Van Buren should be re-elected and Mr Woodbury should remain in the Treasury Department, there would be no chance for any application from him— He told me over again the story of his poverty and the gradual decay of the little property that he had: but he said he was much comforted by the advice and hope that I had given him— Good wishes are all that I have or shall have to bestow— I was buckled down to the table the whole day— I was hurried through Algernon Sidney upon whom were it not that the theme is so melancholy I could occupy a month to great advantage. I took a short walk at Sunset, and plucked a few red wedge apples from the tree for seed— I finished my Letter to Mrs Henrietta M Dawson, and wrote one to Mrs M. Harrison Smith.

23. IV:30. Friday.—  Sun rose 6.22. Set 5.8.— Fahrenheit 32.  My son was yet unwell this morning, but went to Boston, and returned to dine quite recovered— I despatched my Letters to Mrs Dawson and Mrs M. Harrison Smith—the former with a copy of my mother’s Letters— The letter with the Memoir of Miss Hannah Adams by Mrs Lee. This absorbed time, and then Algernon Sidney and Locke, absorbed the day, so that I could not finish my second Lecture as I had intended— I write so constantly hurried that the style is shockingly neglected; and my only comfort is, that remaining unpublished, the critics will have no hold upon them; and that possibly by perceiving the effect of them as read at different places, I may form some opinion of what may be worth preserving; and what must be committed to the flames.— While bringing this second Lecture to a close, I am deliberating upon a subject for the third; for I must have three to meet the engagements which I have already contracted before I reach Washington— I have nearly come to the determination to take the quarrel between Great Britain and China with which I can make at once a Lecture and an Article for the North American Review, which Dr Palfrey has earnestly requested of me— I cannot be insensible to the fact that in these compliances with the importunities of young men to hear me speak, I stake the little remnant of reputation that I have; and that in flattering myself that I am yielding to the impulse of good nature and a hope to do good, I may only be giving way to egregious vanity, and a passion for applause— As far as I am able to judge of my own motives they are stimulated by the desire of performing my duty as a citizen and a man, and sharpened with an excessive anxiety to give pleasure and profit to those who invite me, and to obtain their approbation, perhaps their applause— There came again this afternoon Mr Warren and Mr Felton, two young men from Charlestown, who invited me to deliver a Lecture there, which I promised to do Deo favente on Tuesday the 3d. of next month— They are to send a Carriage for me at Charles’s house in Boston, between 6. and 7. O’Clock to take me over, and will send me back after the Lecture is finished— They left with me an Atlas extra, issued to counteract a hand-bill issued from the Morning Post trumping up a tale of Governor Seward of New-York’s being arrested, and Mr Grinnell, having absconded for a stupendous fraud co-extensive with the whole Union to effect the election of Genl Harrison—

24. V. Saturday.  My wife with our two daughters, and Mary-Louisa went to Boston and returned to dine—the Ladies for shopping and Louisa came back with a heart and cross for a necklace.— Mr Wright came, and took back his sample of the fables of La Fontaine in English verse, of which I advised him to publish rather a cheap edition, within the reach of every purse rather than a large book with magnificent caricatures to cost from 3 to 10 dollars— He thought it would be best to publish the splendid edition by subscription first, and the cheap edition afterwards— We conversed much upon abolition and anti-slavery Societies, about which, and their dissensions I gave him very freely my opinions— I told him that many of the them acted more like Bedlamites than like reasonable men, and instanced the ferocious attacks of Garrison upon him, and his crack-brained woman, no government, and non-resistance balderdash— He gave me a Massachusetts abolitionist extra of which he said he had several with him, but of which he is no longer the Editor.— He charged Garrison with having wronged him in publishing a private and confidential Letter which he Wright had written, but spoke of him with much reserve, and said the cause of abolition would prosper and triumph, in spite of all these snarlings among its advocates— He adhered tenaciously to the third party nominations, and was sure that however feeble they may now be, they would ultimately triumph.— This afternoon Mr and Mrs Abbot Lawrence, with their two daughters and younger Son came out from Boston and visited us— Mr Lawrence is slowly recovering his health and strength; but is, I fear immedicably diseased— Since he resigned his Seat in Congress, Mr Robert C. Winthrop has been nominated to succeed him and will undoubtedly be elected. Mr George W. Beale and his Son were here this Evening; and Charles, but not his wife, who was fatigued with her morning visit to Boston— The pressure upon my time, and upon my brain increases— This day I finished the second of the Lectures that I am to deliver before sundry Lyceums, and other associations, and began an attempt at the third; a subject from which I shrink as I approach it—China— At the first entrance upon its threshold, like a bather at a shelving beach I step forward to meet the tide and an overwhelming surge sweeps me back upon the land; too happy, if in its recoil, I can cling to the ground, and save myself from being swept back beyond my depth, and sunk into the fathomless deep— My first page has plunged me into the Laws of Nations, and I am frightened at the anticipated sound in my own voice— Vattel and Martens, and Ward, and the Parliamentary correspondence relating to China, what shall I do with you, in the compass of one fortnight?

25. V. Sunday  Anniversary of my father’s marriage in 1764— New Moon—  Mr Stearns of Hingham preached morning and afternoon from Ephesians 6.13. [“]Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.” Fortitude against evil by the weapons of religion— This Epistle was written from Rome, when Paul was there in prison—written to cheer and encourage the church of Ephesus under the persecution which he and they were enduring— In this and the preceding chapter he has been urging upon them the system of Christian morals in contrast with their moral condition before they had been converted to faith in Christ— The whole epistle is a summary of Christian doctrine and ethics— He declares himself an Ambassador commissioned by God to unfold to them the mystery, of the admission of the whole heathen world to the blessings which had in preceding ages been confined to the chosen people of God. He then exhorts them to the practise of all the virtues—of Temperance, Prudence—Benevolence—to observe the relative duties of husbands and wives of Parents and children, of Masters and Servants, and lastly he summons them to Fortitude, to fervent prayer, to vigilance, and calls on them with reiterated solemnity to put on the whole armour of God, to stand against the wiles of the devil—a spiritual and defensive warfare, not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, and powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high places. This militant figure of speech is beautifully carried through in detail. The combatant must have his loins girt about with truth—he must have the breastplate, the greaves, the shield, the helmet, all defensive weapons, and lastly the Sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God. It is apparent that all this is especially applicable to the time when the Epistle was written, to the state and condition of the writer himself and to the Church of Ephesus to which it was addressed. Heathens converted to Christianity. This consideration should never be left out of sight in applying the precepts of Scripture to the present times. Christianity is still a spiritual warfare— Its powerful and inveterate enemies now are not the Jews and Heathen-Romans, but Infidels, and Profligates— Mr Stearns’s sermon took a different view of his text; and considered the Christian Fortitude enjoined in the text as bearing only on the ordinary evils incident to human nature. He dined with us; the weather was chilly and raw, portending snow. Charles and his wife spent the Evening here: but I was absorbed in the perusal of the voluminous Report to the British Parliament of the Correspondence relating to China. Not having time to read it deliberately through, and having undertaken to review it in a Lecture, I am compelled to skim it over, and I fastened upon it this Evening and glanced at the whole correspondence to the end, till it was near two O’Clock in the morning when I retired thoroughly chilled to bed.

26. VI: Monday  When I went to bed this morning, a storm of hail was pattering on my windows— I dozed rather than slept through the Night. I was upwards of an hour recovering from the chill with which I went to bed. About 3. in the morning I was awaked by a tremendous long reverberating thunder clap, soon after followed by another— Rising by broad daylight, and looking out of my library windows, the whole surface of the ground as far as sight could range was covered with snow, like Lapland in January, and the snow continued to fall with intermission till near noon.— Charles had intended to go to Boston, but postponed his visit there till Wednesday— In the intenseness of my desire to make progress with my review of the parliamentary document concerning China I lost the day for the diary and it went in arrear— I got entangled with Vattel, and Rayneval upon the Freedom of the Seas; and Bell’s account of the Russian embassy to China in 1719. and th account of Lord Macartney’s embassy in 1792. in Mavor’s collection of Voyages and travels, and Selden’s Hebrew Law of Nature and Nations; but above all the Newspapers swallowed up the daylight, till the dusk, when I went up the hill, and spent an hour at Charles’s, after which he and his wife from 8 to 9 in the Evening were here— I was worn out with multitude of occupation and by 10. retired to bed— The Newspapers are full of the charges of conspiracy of frauds to carry the presidential election, bandied between the two parties at New-York— In these frauds, Governor Seward, Mr Grinnell the member of Congress, a Mr Wetmore of New-York, Mr Swift, now Mayor of Philadelphia, on one side, and Benjamin F. Butler, ex-Attorney-General, of the United States, now District Attorney for the Southern District of New-York, Jesse Hoyt, collector of the customs at that Port, and a man named Edmonds, with many others on both sides are deeply implicated. The explosion began by a clandestine examination before a party judge of a criminal court in New-York, of two worthless characters, named Stevenson, upon hearsay from the other named Ghentworth, charging these distinguished members of the whig party with having imported from Philadelphia in 1838 men to vote and who did vote at the Election in New-York. The tables are now turned, and Ghentworth upon whose expected testimony the whole charge of whig fraud and bribery rested, has made an affidavit, charging Butler and Hoyt, and Edmonds with attempting to bribe him with promises of money and office to accuse Governor Seward, and the whig leaders with these frauds.— This mutual crimination and recrimination is exasperating the parties against each other to such a degree, that there is imminent danger both of fraud and violence at the approaching Presidential Election, which will terminate no otherwise than in civil War and a dissolution of the Union.

27. V. Tuesday.  Sun rose 6:27. Set 5.2. Fahrenheit 21.— Arcturus 4.40  Boston, Warren Street Association. Lecture. Quincy.  Mr Ellis Gray Loring of Boston, and Mr Lewis Tappan of New-York, called on me this morning, and earnestly intreated of me to assume as assistant Counsel to Mr Baldwin of Connecticut, the defence of the Africans captured in the Amistad, before the Supreme Court of the United States at Washington, at their next January term— I endeavoured to excuse myself upon the plea of my age and inefficiency—of the oppressive burden of my duties as a member of the House of Representatives, and my inexperience after a lapse of more than thirty years, in the forms, and technicals of argument, before judicial tribunals, and said I would cheerfully do, what I had heretofore offered that is give any assistance of Counsel and Advice to Mr Baldwin, and any other person charged with the argument before the Court— But they urged me so much and represented the case of those unfortunate men as so critical, it being a case of life and death, that I yielded, and told them that, if by the blessing of God my health and strength should permit, I would argue the case before the Supreme Court; and I implore the mercy of Almighty God, to controul my temper, to enlighten my Soul and to give me utterance that I may prove myself in every respect equal to the task— They promised that Mr Baldwin would furnish me with a complete brief and Mr Tappan left with me two scrap books, containing in slips from the Newspapers all the publications relating to the trials from the time of the capture by Lieutenant Gedney.— Mr Whitney came to take leave of us previous to our departure for Washington— Mr Lunt came afterwards— He is about to compile a new Hymn-book, for the use of the Church and Society here, and he asked me for the loan of my version of the Psalms with liberty to select any of them for publication in his book, to which I agreed, but could not find my manuscript. I promised to look it up, and bring or send it to him— I lent him Goode’s version of the Psalms— We dined at 1. and immediately after dinner, I went with my wife and Mrs John Adams to Boston— They set me down at Mr James H. Foster’s; after which they went shopping and returned to Quincy at the dusk of Evening.— I went to Charles’s house, where I saw Catherine— Then to Mrs S. A. Otis’s, to see Harriet Welsh; but she was out. Then called at Samuel T. Armstrong’s and Abbot Lawrence’s— Neither of them at home— Then at Mrs Samuel Dexter’s, and found her confined to her house with Lumbago. She seemed however cheerful, and is always intelligent— I then found the Warren Street chapel—went and spent an hour with Dr Frothingham— Then at 7. to Mr Foster’s, but he was gone. Charles Foster went with me to the Chapel where I delivered my Lecture upon Faith, from half past 7. to 9.— Then returned to Quincy in a Hack provided for me, by the Committee of the Association— Home at 10.

28. V:30. Wednesday—  Last Evening, after closing my Lecture, I received a note from Mr Abbott Lawrence inviting me to come and lodge at his house— Mr Foster had given me a similar invitation.— Mrs Felt, who was at the Lecture, did the same.— Harriet Welsh and Elizabeth De Wint, were also there, and Miss De Wint told me she wished to go with my wife and family to New-York— The chapel last Evening was full; but there were at least four women present, to one man— Except my own Relations, and Degrand, I saw there none of my acquaintance, except old Joseph May whom I had not seen for many years— Dr Bowditch asked if I should be willing to give the Association a copy of my Lecture, for publication, but I declined, as I proposed to deliver it at sundry other places—and indeed it is not worth publication.— As the carriage to bring me home was waiting at the Chapel door, I could not answer Mr Lawrence’s Note, but Mr Barnard promised to send him word, that I had previously arranged to return to Quincy— One of the Committee offered to come out with me, but I thought it too severe a tax upon his complaisance, and came alone. Dr Bowditch’s wife, an English woman said to me that an ex Subject of the very fine girl thanked me for my Lecture— This morning Deacon Spear and Harvey Field called together; and had some conversation with me about my farm, and a house and lot bordering on the Quincy Canal which Field wishes to sell— He returned last evening from a trip to Bangor to make a purchase of lumber, and brought back my Umbrella, which had been left on board the Steamer Bangor, when we landed in the Night at Portland. The Deacon spoke about making sale of the wood on the lot which we surveyed on the 8th. of this Month—but I referred him for all my business here to my Son, who went this morning to Boston, and returned to dine.— Mr Minott Thayer was here with a young man by the name of Ides.— My Son delivered a Lecture last Evening, to the whigs at Braintree, with which Mr Thayer was highly delighted. He promised to send me the 50 copies of my address of last year delivered before the Inhabitants of Braintree at Mr Storrs’s Meeting house— Mr Loring invited us to a political whig meeting at Hingham to-morrow Evening to hear Mr Caleb Cushing, but I have other engagements, and Charles has promised to deliver a political address to-morrow evening at Cohasset.— Mr Loring brought and shewed me a Letter from me to his Aunt Hannah Thaxter dated 16. Jany 1775 now in possession of his Sister Mrs Whittemore—and he told me that Mrs Nehemiah Parsons had a file of Letters from my mother to Mr John Thaxter.— This Evening at 7 O’Clock, I delivered at the town Hall the introductory Lecture for the Season, before the Quincy Lyceum. Charles went with me.— The Hall was full, but not crowded— Home at 9.

29. IV. Thursday.  I began the day this morning with the record of yesterday which I finished before breakfast— I then resumed my Chinese Lecture, and from the multiplication of matters for discussion in treating it, found that it cannot be properly considered in the compass of one Lecture; and made still more clearly the discovery of my own incompetency to discourse upon the subject at-all— And yet having undertaken it I must go through— The very first principles of the Laws of Nations are involved in the controversy, and the accredited writers, especially Vattel, rather offuscate than clarify the investigation— The History of China, and especially of the twenty-second of Tsing dynasty now occupying the throne, gives occasion for earnest enquiry, which I have not yet found the means to satisfy. I have thumbed over Vattel and Ward, and found sundry questions for debate. The Abbé Raynal’s Philosophical and political history of the European Establishments in the two Indies has an article concerning the origin of the Portuguese Settlement at Macao and a summary of the history of China, absolutely romantic— There was a fashion at the time when the Abbé wrote, among the philosophical French writers of extolling the Governments of all other Nations over that of France.— He himself was ultra-republican in all his opinions, and declamatory in his manner of presenting them; and yet he puffs up the Chinese government as if it were a model of perfection. The most absolute despotism upon earth, rotten with the filthiest corruptions affecting to look down with scorn upon all other Nations, one would suppose from his narritive the very model of perfection— It is impossible it shoul be true— A general description of China, translated from the French of the Abbe Grosier 1788 from which I have been unable to collect nothing of any value— An abstract in Mavors collection of voyages from the writings of the Jesuité Le Comte and Du Halde; not more profitable; and lastly Sir George Staunton’s account of Lord Macartney’s Embassy to China in 1792, which I had not even time to skim— There was rain early in the morn—and a heavy gale, with torrent showers was gathering the whole day— My Son, with his wife and three elder children dined and spent the day with us—and Ruth Turner— Captain Drew of Duxbury came to enquire the state of his petition before the house, for remission of a fine levied upon him at New-Orleans— I could not tell; but must ascertain at the approaching meeting of Congress.— Captain Drew said he was going to New-Orleans, and Europe again; but not to sail till after the 9th. of next Month. I wrote Letters to Mr Nelson Moore at Waltham, and the Revd. Charles W. Upham at Salem—

30. IV:30 Friday  A Gale, almost a Hurricane, with heavy Showers of rain continued through the night and part of this morning.— The wind then subsided and it cleared up towards Night. Charles had some difficulty in getting home with his family and Ruth Turner who had been here at work. I was busily occupied all day.— Charles and his family dined with us, it being the last day before their return to the City for the Winter— Last Saturday Captain Josiah Bass came and introduced Mrs Harriet Spear who has a Son, enlisted as a boy in the Navy under the act of Congress, and now on board the Columbus in Boston Harbour.— Both mother and Son, are extremely anxious to obtain his discharge and she came to solicit my influence to obtain it— I advised her to write a letter to the Secretary of the Navy soliciting his discharge, and to send her Letter to me, promising to forward it, with an additional recommendation of my own— I have accordingly received her Letter, and this day, wrote to the Secretary of the Navy, enclosing it— I wrote also to Mr Nelson Moore, at Waltham; offering to deliver a Lecture there Saturday Evening of next week— At the dusk of evening I walked over the hill; the only exercise I have taken for two days— I continue my investigations for my Chinese Lecture, and deeply regret that I have not another month to examine, and discuss the whole subject— I am now on a critical analysis of the three first principles of the Law of Nations, laid down, by Vattel, and shewing their inconsistency with each other.— I am looking also for Chinese history, and especially for the succession of Emperors of the Mantchoo Tartar or Tsing Dynasty being the 22d. I find in the great Work of Du Halde that Tsong-te ascended the throne by conquest in 1644—but died immediately— His Son Chun-Tchi reigned seventeen years till 1661. succeeded by his son Kang-hi who reigned 60 years till 1722—then his son Yong-tching 13 years till 1735. the reigning Emperor when Du Halde’s work was published.—Then came Kien-Long—another reign of 61. years till 1796. when he abdicated in favour of his Son Kia-king— Kien-Long died in 1799 and Kia-King reigned till 1820. when the present Emperor succeeded— The newspapers still teem with the New-York plot and counterplot; the basest part of which is the tampering of the U.S. District Attorney, with two men of infamous character to run down the whig party with false charges of fraud at the Elections of 1838 and 1839. and the Star-chamber inquisitions of the Recorder Morris.

31. V. Saturday  My Son went this morning into Boston, with his family for the Winter— I was distracted with the settlement of monthly bills, and with arrangements for our departure next week for Washington. My wife and family propose to go on Monday. I have to deliver Lectures next week at Charlestown, at Salem, at Waltham, and perhaps at Boston— And I propose to stay till after Monday the 9th. of next Month being the day of the Elections— I called at the Quincy Stone Bank, and took an assortment of Bills and specie for the expenses of my family’s journey to Washington— At the town Hall where the Selectmen gave me a minute of the particulars of my tax bill for the town and County.— The Selectmen, are Charles A. Brown, Charles A. Cummings and Daniel Baxter— Cummings said he could not find the particular statement of my personal property, which my Son had given in— I called also at C. Gill’s shop and paid his bill for book-binding— Met J. A. Green in the Street, and requested him from this time to send my Quincy Patriot weekly to Washington— Mr Carr came with a subscription book for the whig Association reading room— I gave him a small contribution to purchase books for the room, but declined joining the association as a member having never been a member of any private political Society— Elizabeth C. Adams dined and spent the Evening here. Her brother John Quincy came and escorted her home.— I received this morning a Letter from Charles Johnston member of Congress from Dutchess County New-York, inviting me to deliver a Lecture at Poughkeepsie— I have also received similar applications, from Schenectady in New-York, and from Springfield in this State— Also from the College at Brunswick, to deliver the ΦB.K— Oration there next Summer. I find it impossible even to answer all these Letters; and fear I shall be obliged even to leave my lecture upon China unfinished— I took up this day Sir George Staunton’s account of Lord Macartney’s Embassy, and found much matter of entertainment, and much to the purpose of my Lecture— The name of the present Emperor is Taou-Kwang and he succeed Kia-King in 1820. This is therefore the 20th. year of his reign—

1. V:15— Sunday.  Mr Peter Whitney performed the services of the morning, and preached from Proverbs 13.21. [“]Evil pursueth sinners.”— A plain Discourse easily divided into illustrations of the manner in which evil pursues the different classes of Sinners.— The dishonest man—the intemperate man—the profane swearer—he did not touch upon the gambler, the fornicator, the infidel; nor specially upon the hypocrite— He had difficulty in reading his Discourse—his eyes, his teeth, his voice, his Memory are all in decay; his articulation is so indistinct, and his utterance so feeble that I heard not more than half his Sermon— Mr Degrand came out from Boston and brought budgets of newspapers and news from Philadelphia and New-York.— Richard Haughton Editor of the Boston Atlas came from Philadelphia yesterday morning at 9. O’Clock and brought reports of the election of Presidential Electors, the day before in Philadelphia, and the adjoining Counties of Bucks, Chester and Delaware— The result in the four Counties is favourable to the whigs, but the authenticity of the returns is not sure, and the gain is so small that there is little hope of Pennsylvania— The New-York papers are filled with electioneering plots and counterplots from which I cannot escape the conclusion that fraud and violence, are creeping and breaking fearfully into our elections— These practices were first introduced by the mob government party, who call themselves democrats, and one of their most impudent devices, is to charge their adversaries with their own crimes.— This they did but too successfully in the case of the New-Jersey election, and they are playing the same game over again in New-York. Mr Lunt performed the afternoon services, and preached from Genesis 25.27. [“]And the boys grew: and Esau was a cunning hunter, a man of the field; and Jacob was a plain man, dwelling in tents.” a beautifully contrasted character of the two brothers and of their fortunes and descendants— He attributed this to the difference of their religious principles: and while tracing the sublime and melancholy series of vicissitudes which have distinguished the children of Israel from the days of their progenitor down to their present dispersion all over the earth he marked its transcendent superiority over the brief prosperity and awful extinction of the race of the Edomites and the recently discovered ruins of their city upon the rock, now called, Petra. He referred to the 49th chapter of Jeremiah, the 25th. of Isaiah, and the prophesy of Obadiah.— Mr Degrand left us about 8. P.M. Mr Beale and his daughter Caroline were afterwards here. John Quincy and Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us.

2. V:30. Monday  Mr Isaac T. Smith came from Boston this morning with his Sister and proposed to change the day upon which I should address the New-York Lyceum, as I had conditionally promised on the 11th. of this month. I agreed to substitute the 18th. or the 25th. not being certain that I can reach New-York so early as the 18th and promising that if I cannot, I will give him timely notice. Miss Smith repeated a request which she had made before, and which I had forgotten; for an autograph of my mother, and one of my own— My Son also came out for an hour or two but returned before dinner.— He is nominated as a candidate, one of 35. from Boston, to the House of Representatives in the Legislature of this Commonwealth— It was urged upon him last year, but he declined. We had an early dinner; and at two O’Clock P.M. my wife, with Mrs John Adams, her daughter Mary-Louisa, and Jeremy Leary, left our House at Quincy to take the Stonington Railroad Cars at 4. for New-York, and Washington. Elizabeth C. Adams who had passed the Night here, went home to her mother’s, and I remained with Louisa C. Smith to go to the City to-morrow— I was under peine forte et dure with occupations—but Mr William Ellis of Dedham came and spent two hours of the afternoon, with me about the Pension claims of Relief Dunbar and others, the Pension of Benjamin Buzzey, Ogle’s speech, the furniture of the President’s house and other gossip. About Sunset Mr Horatio Moore, and Mr Burton came in from Waltham. I had written to Mr Nelson Moore, that I would deliver a Lecture to the Adams Association there next Saturday evening. They came to say, that by a previous engagement of the whig Association at Waltham the town hall would be occupied by Mr Robert C. Winthrop and Mr Franklin Dexter, in addressing the whigs on Saturday Evening, and it would be necessary to change the Evening for my Lecture to the Adams association, and I accordingly agreed to go, next Tuesday Evening, instead of Saturday— They wished me also to go to be there at an early hour of the Evening; and I agreed to be ready at my Son’s house, from half past 3 to 4 of the afternoon for the Carriage which they are to engage to take me to Waltham and back.— Being in some perplexity with regard to the second of my political Lectures, which is dry, dull, and too political, I took an old unfinished Essay upon Society written about twenty years ago, and wrote two pages, merely to bring it to a close, and I shall endeavour to pass that off for a Lecture.— It was written at leisure and is therefore much better composition than any thing that I can write now— Of course my labour upon the Chinese lecture is suspended, and I am ready to give it up in despair— I wrote unremittingly from the dusk of Evening till half past 11. when I retired to my solitary bed.

properties.dateline: Quincy— Boston. Tuesday 3. November 1840— Charlestown. Boston
properties.text: 3. V. Tuesday—  White frost. Fahrenheit 30.  At 8. O’Clock this morning, I departed from Quincy in Gillet’s Omnibus, with Louisa C. Smith leaving home as usual in great haste, and all my books and papers in confusion. We took up Passengers all the way along till there were twelve women, two babies, and 3 men, myself included in the Stage, of whom the only person except Miss Smith, whom I knew was Elisha Turner; though his wife and daughter were of the party.— Louisa C. Smith alighted at Mr James H. Foster’s, and I was set down at my son’s house N. 3 Hancock Avenue— Dr George Parkman having met the Stage on Washington Street got in and came with me to the door, leaving with me, an invitation to come and see him.— I remained at Charles’s till 6. in the Evening; before dinner, Mr Edmund Terry, a son of a former member of Congress from Connecticut, but now an inhabitant of Brooklyn, Long-Island, came to repeat an invitation to me from the Hamilton Literary Association at Brooklyn; to deliver a Lecture there on Wednesday the 19th. of this month, which I promised to do, if I could reach and stay at New-York till that time— While we were at dinner, Mr Gould came in, and I agreed with him, to dine with the managers of the Society for the diffusion of useful knowledge at the Tremont house next Saturday.— I had received an invitation from Dr Francis Parkman, to dine with him and the Trustees of the humane Society next Friday.— At 6 O’Clock, Mr Warren came with a Carriage, and took me over, to his house at Charlestown. I walked thence with him just before 7. to the town-hall, which was already filled with a crowded auditory.— As the Clock struck 7. Mr Warren announced to the Lyceum, that the Lecture next Tuesday Evening would be delivered by Professor Henry Ware junr of Cambridge, and would be entitled the biography of the Globe— He then introduced me with a complimentary phrase; and I said that as a Lecture was announced to them for next Tuesday on the biography of the globe I might call that which I was about to deliver to them, the biography of man— And I delivered the Dissertation on Society, which was listened to, with deep and silent attention, and a hearty clap of approbation at the close— I then returned with Mr Warren, who is a lawyer at Charlestown, to his house where I met a numerous party of Gentlemen; and after an hour of conversation, and a plentiful supper I returned to my Son’s house at Boston. Mr Bates a Son of the late Chaplain of the House of Representatives at Washington came home with me, and we met Charles at his door— I rejoiced that I had taken his advice, and substituted this Lecture, for that which I had prepared on Democracy.

4. III— VII Wednesday  On lighting my lamps this morning I found it was but 3. O’Clock—but I was wide awake, and Charles’s study adjoining my bed chamber was well-warmed— So I sat down in my flannel gown two hours, and wrote the diary of yesterday— I then returned to bed, and lay till 7. in repose, if with little or no sleep— Mr Foster came with a Letter from Charles W. Brewster, Secretary of the Lyceum at Portsmouth N.H. inviting me to deliver a Lecture before them on Tuesday the 17th. or any other day of that week— Mr Foster said he was going this day to Portsmouth, to bring home his wife who has been spending some days there at his brothers. I desired him to inform Mr Brewster that I shall be obliged to proceed to Washington, on the 17th. and to say that I would answer his Letter— Mr Curtis of Roxbury came and left with me a Letter, from Petty Vaughan, unimportant and invited me to dine with him, next week on Thursday, and to deliver a Lecture that evening before their Lyceum; which invitation I accepted— I returned to Mr Curtis the Note from Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston— I visited at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s, Mr B. W. Crowninshield’s, and Dr G. Parkman’s but neither of them was at home— Dr. Frothingham called and passed an hour with me.— and afterwards Dr. G. Parkman—with whom I promised to dine, next Wednesday— As I was preparing to start for Salem, Mrs Charles told me that Harriet Welsh had been with her, and advised that I should deliver this Evening at Salem, and to morrow at Boston the Lecture on Faith, and not that upon civilization; several persons who had heard both, much preferring the first. I walked down to the ferry boat at Lewis’s wharf, and precisely at 6 p.m crossed to Chelsea; took the Cars of the Eastern rail-road for Salem, and at a quarter before 7. found Mr N. Silsbee, and Mr Joseph E Sprague, waiting for me at the depot.— Mr Silsbee had a carriage ready, and took me to his house, where I found, his eldest daughter Mrs Sparks; with a little girl, Mr Sparks’s daughter by his first wife—Georgiana, Mr Silsbee’s second daughter, and Miss Storrow of Cambridge. Just before 7. Mr Silsbee took me to the Lyceum Hall, which was as full as it could hold, and the whole company rose as I entered. On the stand at the further end of the Hall, were Chief Justice Shaw—Judges Putnam, Wilde and White, Dr Flint, Dr Hezekiah Packard, Mr Upham, and several other respectable gentlemen— I delivered the Lecture on Faith which was well received, though without any clapping of hands— We then returned to Mr Silsbee’s where about 30. gentlemen came, and spent the remainder of the Evening— I sat in conversation with the family till Midnight.
