24. V. Tuesday.  I received soon after my arrival last Evening, a Note from Mr J. H. Lowden, styling himself of Charleston, and as representing the heirs of Commodore Paul Jones, of Revolutionary War renown requesting an interview with me— I answered the Note early this morning, and appointed any time between 10 and 12 to receive him. He came accordingly, with a reprinted copy of Document N. 19. H.R.U.S. 24. Congress 2. Session. a Memorial of Janette Taylor for herself and the other representatives of John Paul Jones, dated 12. December 1836. and then referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Claims.— No report was made by that Committee on the case; but at the special Session in 1837. Mr Caleb Cushing reported from the Committee of Foreign Affairs a Resolution requesting the President to negotiate with the Danish Government in behalf of the claim.— There was no action of the House upon this Resolution— But there was a report of the present Secretary of State John Forsyth upon a Resolution of the Senate of 1. Feby 1836. referring to him the Memorial of Janette Taylor, to that body. Mr Lowden shewed me now a Letter to the Secretary of State, enquiring if he had any further information of the condition of the claim— And he asked my advice whether it would be proper for him to address this Letter to the Secretary— I told him I saw no objection to it; nor to his calling personally on the Secretary of State, and conversing with him on the subject. This evening I received another Letter from Mr Lowden stating the result of his conversation with Mr Forsyth; and sending the printed copy of the house Document N. 19 and a Manuscript copy of Forsyth’s Report to the Senate in 1836. with a request in flattering terms that I would take charge of the advocacy of the claim in the house; and closing with a notice that he should leave the city to-morrow— Mr Lowden appears to be a Scotchman of education and gentlemanly deportment; but he has an impediment in his speech, which makes it painful to converse with him— Mrs W. S. Smith now living with her brother T. B. Johnson was here, and also Mary Cutts; and Mrs Stuart, whom I did not see, but who read to my wife, a Letter from her daughter Mrs Parnell, in Ireland— I called at Mr T. B. Johnson’s house to see him but he was riding out— I then walked to the Capitol, took out from the Library, nine volumes of different works relating to China; found that R. W. Habersham had taken the Seat in the House which had been Mr Abbott Lawrence’s at the last Session, and my name on the table which was Rice Garland’s, and which he had transferred to me at the close of the Session— I bespoke some Stationary, and a packet of Newspapers which were lying for me at the Post-Office. I then came home, and spent the remainder of the day and Evening in reading my Letters and papers, and in Auber’s China, published in 1834. and in journalizing till 10. P.M.

25. IV:30. Wednesday.  Rain again, the whole day long. Morning visits from Dr Sewall, and from Mr Hodgson, who, since the close of the last Session of Congress has been to Europe as a bearer of despatches, and has just returned, in the British Queen, which arrived at New-York last Saturday. Mr Hodgson carried out to Berlin a Treaty negotiated there by Mr Wheaton, with the Minister of the king of Hanover—between the United States, and Hanover— It was ratified by and with the advice and consent of the Senate of the United States at their last Session. The Treaty was sent by Mr Hodgson for exchange of ratifications, but it was drawn up in the English and French Languages, and his Hanoverian Majesty declines exchanging the ratifications, unless upon an agreement that the French text shall be declared the original Treaty— Mr Hodgson returns therefore, without the Hanoverian Ratification— I walked to the Capitol and called at the Clerk’s Office— The Documents and Journals of the last Session have not yet been received from the Bookbinders. I exchanged an Inkstand The Books which I took yesterday out from the Library are 1. Henry Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amherst’s embassy to China in 1816. An Edition published at Philadelphia in 1818. 2. Notices relating to China, by Sir George Thomas Staunton Bart. published in 1822 3. British Relations with the Empire of China in 1832, An anonymous pamphlet. 4. China—by Peter Auber. 1834. 5. The Fan-Qui in China in 1836–7. by Toogood Downing, in 3. Volumes. 1838. 6. China opened—by the Revd. Charles Gutzlaff—revised by the Revd. Andrew Reed D.D. 2. Volumes 1838.— All these books are necessary to enable me to do any thing like justice to the Article on the quarrel between Great-Britain and China, which I am preparing for Dr Palfrey, and I brought with me four small volumes of the Library of entertaining knowledge—entitled the Chinese—by John Francis Davis—published in 1837— After writing as long as I was able, I devoted this evening to reading Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amherst’s embassy in 1816, which was much more cavalierly treated than that of Lord Macartney in 1793— Many of the same formalities were indeed observed, but with Lord Amherst, the whole negotiation was confined to the discussion whether the Embassador would or would not perform the prostration of the Ko-Tou, and as soon as it was found that he would not he was turned off without being admitted to the presence of the Emperor— It is plain that the moment that pretension shall be broken down, China will be open to foreign commerce and foreign travel— The Chinese Mandarins maintained that Lord Macartney did perform the Ko-Tou before the Emperor Kien Long; and they told Lord Amherst that if he would perform the ceremony he might make what report of it to his Government he pleased!—
Memoranda—for 26. Congress 2. Session.  Petition— Pike Mary, widow of Simeon Pike slain at the battle of Bunker’s hill—

26. IV:30. Thursday—  Mr Ousely the gardener at the President’s house came this morning to confide to me his grievances and his apprehensions— Nolan, the Commissioner of the Public buildings employs a gardener at the Capitol where there is nothing to do, but to keep the grounds clean and gives him a Salary of 1200 dollars a year—a job for a partizan— The man’s name is Mar— While Ousely himself, an excellent gardener and man, who raises all the vegetables and much fruit for the Presidents house, is allowed only 450 dollars a year, and a workman to assist him less than six weeks of the time— Ousely thinks it probable that Mar will be dismissed, and that the two gardeners should be placed on an equal footing; and the Salary equally divided between them— Long morning visit from Coll. Thomas, but he had now nothing new to tell. I paid a morning visit to the President— Met in the large entry below coming out as I went in Mr Levi Woodbury, the Secretary of the Treasury, with a Lady whom he named as Mrs Hale of Boston— I found with the President, in his cabinet, his Son Abram and Mr Joel R. Poinsett, Secretary of War. Our conversation was altogether upon European Affairs, chiefly of France, which the President thinks in a dilemma, between external war, and internal revolution. My next call was upon Mr James K. Paulding, Secretary of the Navy, to whom I made the application in behalf of Thomas Welsh, for the appointment of Surgeon’s mate in the Navy. Mr Paulding said his name would be placed on the register, and that he would have to undergo an examination— I went thence to Mr T. B. Johnson’s and sat half an hour with him. He has had since we left the City last July a very severe paralytic attack, and his life hangs upon the most attenuated of Spider’s threads— The physicians who have attended him assure his Sisters that his mental faculties are not impaired, which is scarcely credible; but he has sufficiently the use of his limbs to walk about his chamber and to write his name— I gave him on my Son’s account and at his request a check for 50 dollars, of which he said he would acknowledge the receipt in a Letter to Charles— Thence on a visit to the General Post-Office, I requested of Mr John M. Niles the Postmaster General, a copy of the Petition upon which Luther Angier was removed from the Office of Postmaster at Medford— I had received a Letter from Mr John Angier, asking me to apply for this copy— Mr Niles shewed me the petition, signed by nine persons, but declined furnishing a copy of it, which he said was contrary to a long standing rule of the office— While I was out Mr Frye was here, and I received Evening visits from Mr Albion K. Parris, my next door neighbour and Tenant; with his father—from W. P. Elliot a Clerk in the Office of the Commissioner of Pensions; and from the Revd. Mr Hawley. Elliot shewed me a notification from the Commissioner of Pensions J. L Edwards that his services would be no longer needed after next February.

27. IV. Friday.  Cleared away, cold. Mr M’Cormick is a native of Ireland; a Clergyman of the Episcopal Church, and when I first came to Washington as a member of the Senate in 1803. was settled as Minister of a small, poor church at the Navy-Yard— On the 1st. of January 1818 I appointed him a Clerk in the Department of State; an Office which he yet holds, having been promoted from a Salary of 1000 to one of 1450 dollars a year. He remembers me, and at the commencement of a Session of Congress visits me when he can do it without danger.— Mr Harris is a young man, President of the Mercantile Library Association at Baltimore. He brought me a Letter from David Hoffman, earnestly urging me to deliver one of my Lectures, before that institution next Tuesday Evening; and I promised if no accident before that time should intervene to prevent me, that I would—and that in the event of such accident I would give notice of it to Mr Harris, if there should be time. Morning visit from Dr Thomas— I asked him what was the true condition of Mr T. B. Johnsons health and mind— He said he was hypochondriac and had no other disease— None for which a physician could prescribe— He was whimsical, and flighty, but not of unsound mind— I called on the Secretary of the Treasury at the Department, and conversed with him concerning the Letter I had received from Jesse Hoyt the Collector at New-York and my interview with him at the Custom house there relating to the Bill for suppressing frauds on the revenue, which was lost at the last Session of Congress. Mr Woodbury thought the Bill, which had first passed the house of more importance now, than the superfetation from the Senate.— He said he should be prepared to report upon a revisal of the Tariff, if Congress should call upon him for it; but he should not volunteer the service. I had received a Letter from Mr Thomas Loring of Hingham, about a Register for the Schooner Amistad, purchased at auction at New London, under a decree of the District Court, sold for Salvage.— Mr Woodbury said he had received a Letter on the same subject this day, and would have enquiry concerning it made: upon which I agreed to call again to-morrow I said something concerning the case of the Amistad Negroes, and that I proposed to see the Attorney General, respecting them— Miss Cutts came this afternoon and took tea here; and in the Evening came to escort her home— Mr Parris the Comptroller was also here with Mr Wood, the Minister of the Presbyterian church Among the Letters which I received this day was one from John P. Bigelow Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts enclosing my certificate of election as a member of the 27th. Congress, and a list of all the votes cast in the 12th. Congressional District at the Election—

28. IV. Saturday.  My old Piedmontese man servant Giusta, whom I picked up, at Amsterdam in June 1814. a stray deserter from Napoleon’s army in his disastrous Russian campaign, who served me faithfully till the 3d. of March 1829. when I left him as steward of the President’s house to my successor there, Andrew Jackson, called to see me this morning.— Antoine’s life with a little embroidery from the hand of an imaginative novelist, would make an amusing and instructive tale— He married at our house in 1818 an English girl who from our kitchen at Ealing came over with us to this country, and has been to him an excellent wife. Tis pity they have never had a child— They lived two or three years with President Jackson; but could not abide his negro slaves and his savage temper— They left him and kept five or six years a small oyster and coffee house, in which he amassed a fund sufficient for them to live comfortably on its income—he purchased a small lot and tenement upon which they live, and where like Diocletian he cultivates cabbages, and lettuce, and celery. He went home two years ago to visit his relations and was gone more than a year.— He found them poor and miserable, and his brother ruined by habits of intemperance— Good humoured and social, Antoine had acquired in this Country a habit of free speaking which on his return home soon brought him under the surveillance of the police— He came back and brought one of his nephews with him But he casts lingering looks towards the natale solum and intends to dispose of all his property here, and go back to spend his last days in the land of his birth.  Mrs Pinkney is the widow of the second William Pinkney, a lost Pleiad— She came to solicit my influence to obtain a subordinate Clerkship in the House of Representatives, for her eldest Son John Sperry, 18 years of age— A younger son, 15 years old is already a midshipman in the Navy as a constructive Tennessean by the adoption of Mr Foster late a Senator from that State— I called again on the Secretary of the Treasury. The comptroller had answered Mr Loring’s letter, and confirmed by implication the refusal of the Collector at New-London to issue papers for the purchaser of the Amistad. Mr Woodbury said that he would make the collector decide the question directly and send the decision to me on Monday. He said the interest on the Arkansas bonds for the Smithsonian fund, had been regularly and punctually paid— I called twice at the Office of the Attorney General, but he was not there— At the Bank of the Metropolis where I received a balance of 3. dollars 20 cents which has been lying there upwards of two years. At the U.S. branch Bank, Mr Richard Smith told me that he had concluded to act as Executor of Mrs Hay’s Will. My wife spent this Evening with her brother Mary with Mrs Talbot, and Mary-Louisa at a party at General Jesup’s.

29. IV. Sunday.  At the second Presbyterian Church in the morning I heard a Mr Moore, whose text was from John 11.38 [“]Jesus therefore, again groaning in himself cometh to the grave— It was a cave, and a stone lay upon it.” The first clause of the verse—the argument of the preacher was humanitarian— That Jesus was a perfect man subject to all the sinless infirmities of human nature— The argument of his divinity was not encountered; but was taken for granted— A much knottier point— That he lived and suffered and died as a man can hardly be questioned by any one who believes that he ever existed— His superhuman nature so often asserted by himself—his express declaration—before Abraham was I am—the very name by which God commanded Moses to call him— The affirmation of St. Paul that by him, God made the world, his continual assumption of the two characters, son of God and Son of Man compel me to believe that he was more than man— I cannot mythologize his miracles—and least of all that of his resurrection from the dead. His gospel is a standing miracle which I cannot controvert—his divinity is a mystery which I cannot believe, and which I see no necessity for believing; any more than the eternity of future punishments. I was not much pleased with Mr Moore’s discourse; which was full of dark and gloomy imagery, without urging any profitable doctrine or exciting any cheerful sentiment— The congregation is yet very thin— The seceders claim the church and I have an unanswered Letter from then demanding my concurrence with or acquiescence in their claim— But they hold their meetings as yet, at what is called the Medical College.— The secession as I understand was occasioned by the engagement of Mr Wood a New-England Congregationalist, as preacher in this presbyterian Church— After dinner at St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening service for the first Sunday in Advent, and a Mr Berry a native of the Island of Jamaica, educated at the University of Cambridge in England preached from Psalm 19.6. “His going forth is from the end of the heaven, and his circuit unto the ends of it, and there is nothing hid from the heat thereof.” The Sermon began with a superficial analysis of the two parts of this most beautiful Psalm, between which he did not appear to understand the admirable connection— There was no want of ingenuity or of handsome composition in the discourse; but what it was after I could not discover, unless it was to reprobate the practice of hanging up paintings on religious subjects in churches—a doctrine for which there might be some occasion in England but for which there can be none here.— The Evening service now begins here at half past 3— Mr. Berry did not finish till after Sunset, and he had much difficulty in reading the last pages of his Sermon— He just made out to announce four Stanzas of a hymn; but the choir could see to sing only two of them— Mrs Frye took tea here. My wife and Mary went home with her, and spent the Evening there—

30— VI:30. Monday.  Dr Toule, the husband of the Lady who some three years ago, painted my portrait, called on me this morning with a request that I would give her another sitting as she had been taken sick and left the picture unfinished before— I promised to visit her at her residence next Thursday before noon— Dr Todson came to say that he has a claim for compensation, for a translation of the Danish Tariff made by him for the Department of State, but for which the Secretary Mr Forsyth had no fund to pay him. He proposed to petition Congress for it, and asked my advice whether to present it, at the approaching Session, or to wait for the next Congress. I said he had better offer it now; not with an expectation of obtaining any thing at this short Session—but the claim may gain some advancement upon the business of the next Congress.— Dr Todson has been two years Consul of the United States at Altena, but found it would not give him bread— He needs some small office for subsistence, and has talents and learning which may be usefully employed. Mr Hawley came, and introduced Mr Berry, the gentleman, who assisted him in his official services yesterday— Mr Berry said he had heard me deliver the Lecture upon Faith at the Tabernacle in New-York, and he thought there were four thousand persons present— I doubt if the building will hold three thousand— Miss Cutts was also here; and Mr Henry the Member of the House of Representatives, from Beaver and Mercer Counties, Pennsylvania;—with Mrs. Henry; and their little daughter— I went to the Office of the Attorney General, Gilpin; then to his house, and again to his Office where at last I found him— The Commissioner of the Land-Office Whitcomb was with him. I spoke to him of the case of the Negroes of the Amistad, to come before the Supreme Court of the United States at their Session next January, on appeal, by the U.S. District Attorney from the decision of the District and Circuit U.S. Courts in Connecticut— Mr Gilpin had received a Letter from Mr Baldwin requesting that the case may be taken up, the first week of the Courts sitting, but thought there would be difficulty in taking it up out of its turn— I desired Mr Gilpin to submit to the consideration of the President the expedient of having the case dismissed by consent, without argument; for which I urged obvious reasons, and which he said would deserve serious consideration— I had called on the Secretary of State Forsyth; and had much conversation with him upon China, and New Zealand, and the North-eastern boundary— Mr Fendall was here this Evening; and Mr D. C. Harris from Baltimore, who comes to accompany me to that City to-morrow

1. IV. Tuesday.  I called this morning at the Franklin insurance Office, but found no one there— At the Bank of Washington and left my book to be balanced.— At a quarter past 11. Mr Harris came to my door with a hack and took me to the railway depot, and took tickets for us to Baltimore— At a quarter before 12 they started with not more than twelve passengers, and travelling slow; with many stoppages reached the depot at Baltimore a quarter before 3. P.M.— There I found MrHarris the President of the Mercantile Library Association, with a Hack, ready, in which, he accompanied me to Barnum’s hotel— Here I was ushered to the two apartments which I had repeatedly occupied when President of the United States; but never since; and the stateliness of which belong not to my present condition— The Association have apparently determined that the cost of my visit to Baltimore at their request shall be defrayed by themselves, and I have not thought it necessary to be punctilious in rejecting their purpose— I would have dined at the ordinary; but Mr Barnum insisted on having my dinner served in my parlour. Mr Harris dined with me. It so happened that I was quite unwell—suddenly taken, in the Cars, soon after leaving Washington, and had so totally lost my appetite that I could scarcely swallow any thing of the sumptuous dinner which was served. The day was frosty and raw; and I had taken a chill in the Cars— I was fearful I should not be able to perform my engagement of the Evening; and had the utmost difficulty to conceal from Mr Harris my discomposure.— I received and answered a second note of invitation to dine to-morrow, from Mr Robert Gilmer.— I had numerous visitors, among whom several old acquaintances, whose names and persons, to my great mortification had alike vanished from my memory.— I remembered Isaac Munroe, Editor of the Baltimore Patriot— Mr Barnum sat and chatted with me for an hour after dinner; and Mr Findley, heretofore Marshall of the District another.— The Lecture had been fixed for 8 O’Clock— At half past 7. Mr Harris and another Gentleman came and took me to Dr Duncan’s Church, which was so crowded that I had no small difficulty to get in— My chill had passed off, but left me with a hoarse and broken voice. Dr Duncan was in his pulpit, and announced to the auditory that my Lecture, was introductory to a course proposed to be given by the Mercantile Library Association— I spoke from a platform fronting the pulpit, and delivered the Lecture on Society and civilization— It was well received— The Stanzas and the close, applauded. All heard with deep attention— Sundry persons were introduced to me, and Mr Gilmer came to shake hands with me. Mrintroduced himself— Asked me if I had read Swedenborg’s treatise on conjugial love, and said he would send it to me— He said too, that he had heard my Lecture on Faith at the Tabernacle in New-York, and agreed with me in every thing except that belief depends upon the Will—and he spoke of some treatise by somebody upon the will. Mr Harris, the President of the Association—and Mrtook me back in the hack to Barnum’s, and sat half an hour with me in conversation. They were chiefly pleased with the two Stanza’s on connubial love.

1. IV. Tuesday.  I called this morning at the Franklin insurance Office, but found no one there— At the Bank of Washington and left my book to be balanced.— At a quarter past 11. Mr Harris came to my door with a hack and took me to the railway depot, and took tickets for us to Baltimore— At a quarter before 12 they started with not more than twelve passengers, and travelling slow; with many stoppages reached the depot at Baltimore a quarter before 3. P.M.— There I found MrHarris the President of the Mercantile Library Association, with a Hack, ready, in which, he accompanied me to Barnum’s hotel— Here I was ushered to the two apartments which I had repeatedly occupied when President of the United States; but never since; and the stateliness of which belong not to my present condition— The Association have apparently determined that the cost of my visit to Baltimore at their request shall be defrayed by themselves, and I have not thought it necessary to be punctilious in rejecting their purpose— I would have dined at the ordinary; but Mr Barnum insisted on having my dinner served in my parlour. Mrintroduced himself— Asked me if I had read Swedenborg’s treatise on conjugial love, and said he would send it to me— He said too, that he had heard my Lecture on Faith at the Tabernacle in New-York, and agreed with me in every thing except that belief depends upon the Will—and he spoke of some treatise by somebody upon the will. Mr Harris, the President of the Association—and Mrtook me back in the hack to Barnum’s, and sat half an hour with me in conversation. They were chiefly pleased with the two Stanza’s on connubial love.

2. V:10. Wednesday.  The precaution of taking pen, ink and paper with me has been unavoidable— I rose at 5. and wrote till 8. Breakfasted at the Ladies ordinary, where there were few boarders— Visits immediately after from Messrs. Ridgely and Griffith as a Committee from the Temperance Society, to request me to deliver an address to that association; which I was obliged to decline, as at present impracticable; and as certain to be so during the approaching Session of Congress— But after its close, I promised either to deliver such an address, or to give them notice that it will not be in my power. Mr D. C. Harris came also to enquire how I was this morning. I returned with a card the card visit of Mr Reverdy Johnson, and in person the card visit of Coll. B. C. Howard. Much conversation with him, upon the North-eastern boundary question, upon which he said he proposed to deliver a Lecture before the Mercantile Library Association— He shewed me Kitchin’s Atlas of Maps in which there are two published by Laurie and Whittle 12. May 1794 one of which marked the boundary as now claimed by the British Government, and the other as claimed by the U.S. he said he had supposed until he saw these maps that the present British claim was a recent pretension; and he could not now account for the fact that these two map were published by the same persons on the same day.— Returning from Coll. Howard’s I went to the column at the end of North Charles street erected to George Washington by the State of Maryland.— There is a cubic basement, within which is a man who receives 12 1/2 cents for the admission of a visitor, and furnishes him with a lantern to ascend the winding stairs between the outer and inner column— There are 28 steps of ascent to the top of the basement, and 200. thence to the top of the shaft and of the entablature over it— At every 25th. step the stepping stone is wider than the rest to afford a resting station—over the entablature is a cap, cylindrical and round top’d over which stands a colossal statue of Washington in a Roman toga, with a roll in his extended right hand meant for the constitution— There is also a Statue of him in a corner of the basement below, and a bust in a Niche, copied from that of Ceracchi— The whole is in elegant taste and the front of the column forms a beautiful object to the eye, at different distances throughout the whole length of Charles Street. After returning to Barnum’s, I met with Lieutt. Wayne, and had visits from Mr George H. Newman and his Son— Dined at 4. O’ Clock with Mr Robert Gilmor, and had a glance at his fine collection of pictures, and Greenough’s Statue of Medora company 9 and Mr Gilmor, a round table; excellent dinner delicious wines and a jovial company— After dinner Mr Granger came in— Mr Reverdy Johnson took me home with him to an oyster supper and just before midnight I returned to the Hotel.

3. VI. Thursday.  On returning to the Hotel last Night, I found on my table the names of Messrs. Mayer, Hoffman and Boyd visitors while I was out— Mr David Hoffman, and Mr Kerr, were two of the Electors of President, and Vice-President of the United States, for the State of Maryland— Yesterday was the day upon which the electors of the 26. States met at the Seats of their respective Governments, to vote for those two officers to serve for four years commencing on the 4th. of March 1841— The Electors for the State of Maryland met at Annapolis and gave ten votes, the number to which the State is entitled, for William Henry Harrison of Ohio as President, and John Tyler of Virginia as Vice-President— Mr Kerr and Mr Jenifer called this morning just as I was about leaving Barnum’s to return to Washington— Mr J. M. Harris came and introduced several of the Directors of the Mercantile Library Association, whose names I was unable to retain—except that of Mr James S. Waters who accompanied me on my return— On calling for my Bill at Barnum’s I was told it was paid— Mr Harris took me in a hack to the Railway depot— The train started at 9 A.M. and at half past 11. we alighted at Washington; and Mr Waters accompanied me in a hack to the door of my house— He dined with us at 3. and after dinner left us to go to Alexandria— Mr Meredith urged me very warmly to remain at Baltimore and dine with him this day; but I had already indulged myself too much with the day of entertainment, by Mr Gilmor and Mr Reverdy Johnson— The outward marks of respect which I have received on the delivery of these Lectures for the last five weeks, are too flattering, and more than my honest nature can endure— It augurs some deep humiliation awaiting to teach me in the last stage of my existence on earth, what I am, and the real estimation in which I am held by the very small portion of my fellow creatures who know or care any thing about me— I found on my table at home Letters calling me to new duties, and severe and trying labours, for which I ask for aid. A meek and quiet but genial spirit— I walked to the capitol hill, and gave a sitting of nearly an hour to Mrs Towle.— Her portrait of me painted in October 1837 is hideous. She says she was taken ill at that time—was unable to finish my portrait or any other, and has scarcely painted half a dozen since.— It were well if she knew that the word applicable to all her works is not paint, but daub.— The poor woman said she had met with domestic affliction since my former sittings, by losing a little boy her Son; a calamity in which I deeply sympathised with her— I promised her another sitting next Monday or Tuesday. I gave my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa, a silver Can cup, which I purchased for her yesterday, her birthday. She is twelve years old.

Mayer, Hoffman and Boyd visitors while I was out— Mr David Hoffman, and Mr Kerr, were two of the Electors of President, and Vice-President of the United States, for the State of Maryland— Yesterday was the day upon which the electors of the 26. I gave my Grand daughter Mary-Louisa, a silver Can cup, which I purchased for her yesterday, her birthday. She is twelve years old.

4. IV:30. Friday.  Morning visits from Coll. Henderson of the Marine Corps, and Mr Cazenove of Alexandria. Mutual gratulation at the downfall of the Jackson-Van Buren Administration is the universal theme of conversation— One can scarcely imagine the degree of detestation in which they are both held— No one knows what is to come— In four years from this time the successor may be equally detested. He is not the choice of three fourths of those who have elected him— His present popularity is all artificial— There is little confidence in his talents or his firmness— If he is not found time-serving, demagogical, unsteady and western-sectional, he will more than satisfy my present expectations.— Jackson’s Administration commenced with fairer prospects and an easier career before him, than had ever before been presented to any President of the United States— His personal popularity founded exclusively upon the battle of New-Orleans, drove him through his double-term and enabled him to palm upon this Nation the Sycophant, who declared it glory enough to have served under such a chief for his Successor. Both the men have been for twelve years the tools of Amos Kendall the ruling mind of their dominion— Their edifice has crumbled into ruin by the mere force of gravitation, and the wretchedness of their cement— But what is to come? No halcyon days— One set of unsound principles for another— One man in leading strings for another— Harrison comes in upon a hurricane. God grant he may not go out upon a reck!— Perhaps these gloomy reflections are chilled by the fall of snow, which began before noon, and continued through the day without storming. It confined me to the house till 5. P.M. when I went and dined with Mr Seaton the Mayor of the City— A diplomatic dinner, with Messrs Bacourt, Bodisco, Mareschal, Martini, Serruys, Hulsemann, Steckel, and one or two others.— Also Mr Gales,Bradley, Richard S. Coxe, Columbus Munro—Mrs Seaton, Miss Seaton and Miss Scott—not to forgetSmith the Register of the Treasury. After dinner Mr Coxe entertained me with an account of his antient relations with John C. Calhoun, and of Calhoun’s solicitude at the time of my election as President, lest I should be driven by those around me, into the absurd and detestable doctrine, as he then called it of State rights.— I have heard no person speak with so much bitterness of the expiring administration as Mr Coxe— There was a whist party in the Evening, but without taking part in it I came home before 9. I had wasted the day, in looking over the documents relating to the Amistad negro case, and Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amhersts Embassy to China.

5. V. Saturday.  Morning visit, from Mr Boyd, a young clergyman from Portland, Maine, who was last winter a candidate for the chaplaincy of the house, and comes doubtless with the same aspiration now— I called at the Department of State, but the Secretary, Forsyth was indisposed, at his house. I left with Mr Derrick, the clerk having charge of the Diplomatic bureau, a letter which I had received containing a vote, of the Massachusetts historical Society at their last October meeting, charging a Committee of 3 members of whom I am one, to ascertain if certain documents relating to the Northeastern boundary of the United States, borrowed from the historical Society half a century ago, by Egbert Benson, one of the Commissioners of the United States for ascertaining the St. Croix river, so denominated in the Treaties of Peace of 1782 and 1783. are not among the papers on file in the Department; and if they are, to reclaim them; as well as any other papers belonging to the Society which may be in the Department— Derrick promised to make the search— I left also with Mr Martin the Chief Clerk a copy of the call which I propose to move in the house for documents relating to the origin and present state of our relations with China, political and commercial. Mr Martin gave me a copy of the House Document of the House N. 119. of the last Session, called at the motion of Caleb Cushing on the 7th. of February last— I called next on the Secretary of the Treasury with a Letter from the first Comptroller’s Office, signed J. N. Burke acting Comptroller’s Office and assigning as a reason for the refusal of the Collector at New-London to issue American papers to the purchaser of the Schooner Amistad, sold by the U.S. Marshal under a decree of the judge of the U.S. District Court in Connecticut, that there was an appeal from the Decree of the judge, and that it had not been usual to issue papers upon an interlocutory or other than final decree. I requested that this opinion from the comptroller’s Office might be reconsidered; observing that the decree of the District Court operated in rem— That the sale by the Marshal under that decree was the act of the Law, not at all affecting the right of the party appealing from the decree of salvage, but done for the benefit of all the parties to save the perishable article for him to whom it should finally adjudged to belong— That the refusal of the papers would invalidate the sale by the Marshal and the decree of the judge, and give the purchaser a just claim of damages against the Government itself, whose officers in the two departments would thus counteract one another— If the decision of the Secretary should adhere to this view from the Comptroller’s office I should be under the necessity of commencing a correspondence with the District judge concerning his decree— Mr Woodbury said he would call on the Comptroller for a statement of the case; and take and report to me the opinion of the Attorney General, on the Law

6. VI. Sunday.—  Snow—  I called yesterday at the Office of the Attorney General Gilpin; but he was not there, nor expected to be there, for the day— I then came home and debarred from writing by the shivering cold of an atmosphere of attenuated snow wasted the remainder of the day in alternate desultory reading upon China, and dosing; with faculties absolutely torpid— Finished the cursory reading of Ellis’s journal of the proceedings of Lord Amherst’s embassy in 1816— Read sundry short Articles of Sir George T. Staunton’s Miscellaneous notices relating to China published in 1822 and skimmed over the Document 119. of the last Session of Congress— The Snow continued, with occasional intermissions, all day yesterday, all last Night and this day, the whole day long— I have no recollection of a snow storm of three days duration before— There has been however no gale, and very little drifting of the Snow. About 18 inches deep of snow upon a level has fallen. I rode to the Presbyterian Church and found it closed, and the doors blocked up with snow. I came home, and occupied the remainder of the day chiefly in reading. Dr George W. Doane, bishop of New-Jersey, was present at the delivery of my Lecture upon Faith, at the Tabernacle in New-York— Since my arrival here I have received from him a pamphlet entitled “looking unto Jesus” containing a Sermon preached by him at St. Mary’s church, Burlington New-Jersey on the occasion of the death of Revd, Benjamin Davis Winslow; his assistant as Rector of that Church— An address to the Congregation of that Church, before the Administration of the Communion, on Advent Sunday 1839. on the same subject; and sundry obituary notices of Mr Davis, who died on the 21st. of November 1839. of a consumption at the age of 24— Born at Boston in February 1815. a graduate of Harvard University in 1835 he perished almost in the blossom, but his virtues have been well commemorated in these tributes of his patron, relative and friend to his worth— His life was a bright example of religious faith and fervent zeal— His talents were highly respectable, and there are cited two or three of his poetical effusions in this pamphlet, at once melancholy and pleasing— I often think when reflecting upon the depravity of human Nature, what multitudes there are of persons unknown to fame, of blameless life and unsullied virtue in the world; and how unjust it is to pass sentence of universal condemnation upon mankind, without making allowance for all that is good among them.— In all Christian Countries, there is an immense account of practical virtue, always in operation though never made known to the world— I wrote a short Letter to Bishop Doane thanking him for the pamphlet; and then recurred again to the Books brought from the Library of Congress, relating to China— Among these, the Fan-qui in China, by C. Toogood Downing, published in 1838 is one of the most amusing— It is an account of the manners and customs—the condition of domestic life in that country, more particular than I have found elsewhere—in three duodecimo volumes— I read several chapters of it myself, and Mary Louisa read to us two chapters this Evening after tea— I attempted to write further in my Article upon China, but the snowy atmosphere chilled my fingers.

7. VI:30. Monday  2d. Session 26. Congress commences.  It was broad daylight when I rose— The sky had cleared away cold, and I lay abed shrinking from the task of pinching my feet with cold water, and of making a wood fire in a chilly chamber, which after all I was obliged to perform, having in the meantime lost the two best hours of the day for work. This day commenced the second Session of the 26th. Congress— The heavy fall of snow compelled me to ride to the Capitol and a quarter before 12. I took my seat, being that which Rice Garland transferred to me the morning after the close of the last Session. Precisely at Noon, the Speaker Robert M. T. Hunter took the chair and the names of the members were called over by States. 95 answered to the call and 7 new members were presented and sworn by the Speaker, among whom was Robert C. Winthrop from Boston who takes the place of Abbott Lawrence resigned— He and Governor Lincoln have been ever since last Friday afternoon at 3. O’Clock coming from Philadelphia, and reached this City only at 4. O’Clock this Morning.— The snow-storm has been unparalleled— The Speaker immediately adjourned the house at the motion of Lewis Williams. The Delegates from the Territories were not called, but Downing of Florida, and Dodge of Ioway were present and 6 members came in after the adjournment— In the Senate only 16. members appeared, and neither the Vice-President, R. M. Johnson, nor the President pro Tem, W. R. King was among them. I rode home— Miss Cutts shortly after came in; and then T. B. J. Frye, who dined with us— He was going to attend a meeting of the National Institute for the promotion of Science, of which he told me he had been elected a member, and before which his father told me a paper by him on the zoology and ornithology of this district, was the first ever read before the Society. Mr Gilpin the Attorney General, left a card, with word that he would call again. My neighbour Mr A. K. Parris called with Mr Chickering a Clergyman of Portland Maine, travelling South for his health and perhaps with a mission— He enquired if I had been acquainted with his grandfather, sometime Minister of the Congregational church at Dedham. I did not know him— He is proposing to go to Marseilles in France, where a number of Americans and English are about to open a Protestant Church, of which they have invited him to be the pastor.— He asked some questions about the opinion that I gave at New-York in the Lecture upon Faith at the Tabernacle; that Louis Philippe has no title to the crown of France— Mr Bisbee announced himself as an Agent for the American Association of Literature and Science, at New-York, of which he said I had at their last meeting been elected an honorary member— He enquired if I accepted this election, and I said I should be glad to receive a regular written communication of it— Mr Frye was here and mentioned to me a fresh difficulty with regard to the liberation of William S. Smith— My wife wrote about it to Mrs Smith.

8. V:30. Tuesday.  Sharp head-ache almost the whole night, and very little sleep. Rode to the Capitol— The Speaker took the Chair at Noon; and the roll was called over of members who had not answered— Fifty additional members now answered to their names— A Message was sent to the Senate, to inform them that a Quorum of the house were assembled, and ready to proceed to business; and an order passed for the appointment of a Committee, to be joined by a Committee on the part of the Senate, to wait on the President of the United States and inform him that a Quorum of both houses are assembled and ready to receive any communication that he may be pleased to make to them. Mr Taliaferro and Mr Cave Johnson were appointed the Committee on the part of the house. I gave notice of my purpose to offer to-morrow a Resolution that the standing role of the house, numbered 21. adopted on the 28th. of January last be rescinded— It is the rule that abolition petitions shall not be received or in any manner entertained by the house.— No other business was transacted— The Senate did not form a Quorum, five additional members only to those present yesterday having appeared one of whom was the President pro tem. W. R. King.— The house adjourned about half past 12. Of the members who came in this day John Sergeant, W. B. Calhoun, Millard Filmore and Daniel D. Barnard who travelled with his wife and two children, left Philadelphia on Saturday morning in the Cars, and at 9. O’Clock that evening found themselves 23 miles from Baltimore, in the middle of the road with the snow falling and the storm howling around them; and unable equally to proceed or to recede— There of eighty passengers in the train, thirty of whom were women, the greater number remained the whole night of Saturday; the whole day and Night of Sunday, and Monday till near noon; when fresh engines came and took them up, and brought them last night into Baltimore. A small part of their company found a refuge in two or three hovels, near the place where they were arrested, but fared worse than those who adhered to the Cars— These made themselves comfortable by shutting out the tempest, keeping up good fires, and foraging successfully round the neighbourhood, for a supply of provisions— Sergeant says there was in all this not much of hardship— The passengers from the South brought an account that Waddy Thompson just beyond Petersburg in Virginia, was knocked down between the two rails, and the whole train of five cars, engine and all passed over his body without hurting him much, or perhaps at all. He did not come on however in the cars— After the adjournment of the house, I walked over and gave a sitting of two hours, to Mrs Towle, during which once or twice I fell asleep— This infirmity of old age frequently happens to me, to mortify my pride, and to remind me how near I am to the caducity of the last Scene of all. I promised Mrs Towle to give her another sitting—if possible next Monday— I walked home. My wife and Mary-Louisa, are both indisposed and kept their chambers. I paid an evening visit to my neighbour Mr Parris, whose numerous family I found engaged in a Concert of church music which they suspended while I was there, and resumed when I left them. Mr Chickering and Mr Fillebrown were of the party—Mr Parris’s four daughters—his Son, and Son’s wife— Also Mrs Parris.

9. VI. Wednesday  On my way to the Capitol this morning, I called at the Bank of Washington; took my balanced book and drew 100 dollars in bills of other banks by check— A Quorum of both houses was this day formed— The joint committee waited upon the President, who informed them that he would send forthwith a Message to the two houses. It was accordingly received and read—ready printed for the Senate— Atherton of New Hampshire moved that the Message should be referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union—and that 15000 copies of it with the documents, and 5000 copies without the documents be printed for the use of the members of the house, which was carried— I had offered my resolution to rescind the 21st. standing rule of the house— Jenifer moved to lay it on the table Lewis Williams that it be postponed— I said I was willing to take the question immediately without debate— I offered the Resolution, at the earliest possible moment for two reasons—first because the commencement of the Session is the time for receiving petitions—and secondly because so far as the discharge of my duty was concerned I would not suffer that rule to stand one hour as the Law of the house— Linn Banks moved that it should be laid on the table— I said that if the house did not choose to take the vote directly on the resolution, I should prefer next the question of laying on the table, because it could then be called up at any time— I asked for the yeas and nays and they were 82 to 58—all the South, and Northern serviles voting in the affirmative— The house adjourned about 3.— I took out from the library of Congress, Barrow’s travels in China—as private Secretary of Lord Macartney. Van Braam’s account of the embassy from the Dutch East-India company to China in 1794 and 5. translated from the French of Moreau de Saint Mery; and Timkowski’s travels with the Russian Embassy to China in 1820 and 21. Walking homewards from the Capitol, Mr Burch took me up in a Sleigh; till I stopped at the Franklin insurance company’s office, and received a check on the Patriotic bank for a dividend—after which I walked home. My nephew William S. Smith was this day liberated after nearly two years of confinement and came with his wife to my house. She has been several months residing with her brother Mr Thomas B. Johnson— Miss Cutts spent the Evening here, and her father came and escorted her home. Mr Robert Greenhow, the Translator of the Department of State, came, and complained that he had been unjustly charged with making a false translation in the document N 185 of the house documents of the last Session in the case of the Africans captured in the Amistad— He shewed me the charges in the Letter of judge Jay, and said that judge Jay was mistaken in supposing the word negros to have been interpolated in the Spanish certificate; and that the word sound in the printed document was not in the manuscript translation made by him and transmitted to the house— Mr Greenhow, requested me to see that the matter should be understood by the house to exonerate him.

10. V:30 Thursday.  I went to the Capitol an hour before the meeting of the house this morning, calling at Lewis Johnson shop which is removed to East of Gadsby’s—where I left a Letter to him from John Otis— From the Clerk’s Office of the house I sent into the Senate chamber a Letter from Dr Joshua Bates to judge Haight— I examined the manuscript document of the last session N. 185. and upon comparing it, with the printed document, found as Mr Greenhow had stated to me last evening that in the manuscript the word Ladino is inserted in the translations of both the permits to ship the negroes, for which in the printed document the word sound is substituted— At the meeting of the house Stanly moved to reconsider the vote for printing 15000 copies of the President’s Message with the Documents—upon which the vote by yeas and nays was 89 to 90. I then moved that a select Committee of five members be appointed to ascertain and report to the house, whether the house document of the last Session N. 185 has been falsified; and if so, by whom the falsification was made; with liberty to send for person and papers— I stated the fact of the difference between the manuscript and the printed document—then read the note, on the false translation of the word ladino in the reprint of the document at New-York and the censure upon it in judge William Jay’s Letter of 20. October last to Lewis Tappan, published in the American and Foreign Anti-Slavery Reporter N. 8 and 9.— No answer was made to me, and no objection to adoption of the Resolution, but when the Speaker put the question, several voices in the negative were heard—a division was called and the vote stood 87 to 46. there were of course upwards of 40 who did not vote.— An order passed for the appointment of the standing Committees; and Tillinghast offered a very long resolution calling upon the Secretary of the Treasury for information respecting the execution of the sub treasury law; which after some discussion was rejected by the house. The annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury upon the finances was received—and referred to the Committee of Ways and Means and 5000 extra copies were ordered to be printed. A Message from the President was received recommending an immediate appropriation of 151352 dollars 39 cents for the Navy Pension fund to meet payments which will become due on the 1st. of January. Several other Resolutions were offered, and the house adjourned over to Monday— As I was returning home, I met in the Avenue Mr Greenhow, who enquired if I had examined the document N. 185 in manuscript— I told him that I had—and found it as he had said— And that I had offered a Resolution to ascertain by whom the fraud has been committed— And that I had taken care to exonerate him entirely from all blame in the matter— I met at my door a man named J. J. Smith who has a claim for an increase of pension as an old Soldier presented by Mr Naylor at the last Session, for which he solicited my aid, which he will have— A young man named Charles Abbot, came to request me to deliver a Lecture here, which I shall take into consideration. Mr Barnard sent me his Lecture on the Morals of Politics which I read to my wife.

11. VI:30. Friday  Mild and fair day. The Snow gradually melting away— I called this morning on my neighbour Mr Daniel D. Barnard, and returned the manuscript of his Lecture on the Morals of Politics— I had some conversation with him upon our political prospects concerning which I feel far more solicitude than hope— Barnard is one of the ablest men of the whig party. His principles generally are of the best; dashed with errors the more dangerous because honestly entertained, and rooted in a profound and vigorous mind. I paid morning visits to Mr Henry Clay lodging at Mrs Arguelles’s and to Mr Solomon Lincoln, at Brown’s hotel.— While I was at Mr Clays, numerous other visitors came in, among whom the Russian Minister Bodisco, whom Mr Clay bantered coarsely about his marriage last Spring, with a young girl at Georgetown, daughter of a clerk in one of the public offices named Williams. Bodisco took Clay’s greasy jokes very good humouredly, and with no small self complacency assured him that all was right— Clay said he had visited Mr Van Buren’s yesterday and had an hour’s conversation with him on the issue of the Presidential Election— Mr Clay further told us that before leaving home he had seen the President elect Harrison, and that he looked well, though somewhat shattered— At Mr Lincoln’s room I met Mr Webster, Governor Lincoln, and Robert C. Winthrop. I called at the Office of the Attorney General Gilpin who informed me that he had seen the President of the United States, concerning the case of the Amistad negroes, and he had concluded that the case could not be dismissed from the Supreme Court without an argument because the Spanish Minister insisted on the delivery up of the men as slaves to be sent to the Havana, as Slaves—and further that the motion to dismiss the case was made in the Circuit Court, and there refused— I said that the refusal of the Circuit Court to dismiss the cause seemed no reason for precluding the dismission of it from the Supreme Court, and that the Spanish Minister had not only not demanded the delivery of the men as Slaves, but had explicitly so demanded them as Assassins— He said there was a subsequent Letter from the Spanish Minister in April last insisting upon the delivery of the men as Slaves, upon the principles of certain Resolutions of the Senate, adopted at their last Session— I denied the right of the Spanish Minister to claim them as property—the pretended owners having claimed them—and not having appealed from the decision— Mr Giplin had also the papers from the Secretary of the Treasury respecting the purchase of the Schooner Amistad before him but did not appear to understand the question. Mr Solomon Lincoln, Mr Barnard and Mr Winthrop dined with us— My wife keeps her chamber. Mr Hallowell, and Mr Stabler were visitors from Alexandria, to solicit a Lecture.

12. V. Saturday.  Rain, great part of the day which confined me to the house. Mr Force and Mr Laurence came, as a Committee from the National Institution for the promotion of Science; and stated that they proposed to hold a Meeting of the Society on the first Monday, the 4th. of January next, when a discourse is to be delivered by Mr Poinsett— The Society are desirous of obtaining the use of the Hall of the House of Representatives that evening for that purpose—and wished me to offer the Resolution that it be granted; which I promised to do.— They said the Institution was likely to flourish, and that great interest was taken in it, by the people here— Mr Force left with me a memorandum of two books which I borrowed of him more than three years since, and which I have not yet returned.— The day was fully occupied and quickly passed away— I made out my list of the persons to whom the documents of which extra-copies are printed by order of the house, are to be sent— My rule of distribution is 1. One copy to each of the Editors of the Newspapers published at Plymouth (the Old Colony Memorial[)] Hingham Patriot and Quincy Patriot— The Boston Courier and Evening Gazette. 2 To my Son, and a few other personal friends. 3. To the Senators in the Legislature of Massachusetts from the Counties of Plymouth and Norfolk 4. To one representative from each of the 24 towns in the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— My portion of the extra documents, is seldom sufficient for the whole of this supply— Often for not half of them— My Son—the Newspaper Editors, and the County Senators are first served— The others are furnished according to the numbers of my allowance— I keep lists of the extra documents printed by order of the house at each Session, and of the names of the persons to whom I send them— I made out my lists for the present Session; and despatched by the mail 17 copies of the Presidents annual Message.— But the lists are imperfect till the meeting of the Massachusetts Legislatures shall ascertain the Senators for the Counties of Plymouth and Norfolk, and the Representatives from the 24 towns of the 12th. Congressional district— I thought it necessary to look into the case of the Amistad captives, to prepare for the argument before the Supreme Court in January; of which I dare scarcely to think— I read especially the Article in the American and foreign Anti-Slavery Reporter of 1. October 1840. entitled the Amistad case—p. 48–51. with deep anguish of heart, and a painful search of means to defeat and expose the abominable conspiracy executive and judicial of this Government against the lives of these wretched men— How shall the facts be brought out? How shall it be possible to comment upon them with becoming temper—with calmness—with moderation—with firmness—with address—to avoid being silenced, and to escape the imminent danger of giving the adversary the advantage in the argument, by over heated zeal. Of all the dangers before me, that of losing my self possession is the most formidable— I am yet unable to prepare the outline of the argument, which I must be ready to offer the second week in January. Let me not forget my duty.

13. VI. Sunday  A bright sky overhead; a mild but snow-chilled atmosphere to breathe, and a slushy carpet in the streets under foot was the circumstantial condition of this day; and emblematical of the social and political condition of the country.— I attended this morning at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Wood preach, from Hebrews 9.16. [“]For where a Testament is, there must also of necessity be the death of the testator 17. For a testament is of force after men are dead: otherwise it is of no strength at all while the testator liveth.” The argument of Mr Wood was, that the Gospel was the last Will and testament of Jesus Christ; but he did not carry out the idea suggested by his text, that the validity of this testament depends entirely upon the death of the testator— This may be essential to the orthodox doctrine of the atonement; but he did not dwell upon it. He gave a summary account of the life of Jesus Christ: in a somewhat singular manner and said he was until the age of thirty, professionally a mechanic— Of this I know not what evidence there is— Certainly none in the Gospels— Nor is the gospel any where denominated a Testament— He is said by Saint Paul to be the mediator of the New Covenant, and that is the Greek title of what we call the new Testament— The congregation was very small— After dinner I attended at St. John’s Church, where Mr Hawley read the Evening Service for the 3d. Sunday in Advent, reading only the second lesson, and preached from Ecclesiastes 9.1. [“]For all this I considered in my heart, even to declare all this, that the righteous, and the wise and their works, are in the hand of God”—there is a remnant of the verse that he did not read. I slumped through the Snow to get to the Church; and the frequency of the worshippers was on a par with the edification of the discourse— At home my attention was diverted from the Amistad Africans to Barrow’s travels in China, which absorbed me for the remainder of the day— Barrow was the private Secretary of Lord Macartney, and his book is a valuable supplement to that of Sir George Staunton; and they form altogether a marvelous account of that said Empire of China— A patriarchal despotism realized over 300 millions of population, and continuing from time immemorial.— A nation floating upon their rivers, and never navigating the Ocean— Polygamy, Bestiality, Infanticide, Idolatry, and brutal filthiness, commingled, with extreme politeness, and high accomplishments in many of the useful and elegant arts.— The extremes of civilization and of the savage state blended together in one condition of human existence are portrayed with vivid colouring in these narratives. Barrow was left at the Palace of Yuen Min Yuen while Lord Macartney went to Zhe hol, and his description of the Consternation of the Chinese household on learning the refusal of the Embassador to perform the Ko-tou sheds some additional light upon the account of Sir George Staunton—

14. VI. Monday.  Two Stone-cutters, Irishmen, named M’Closkey and Doyle came this morning to ask my assistance to obtain work for them on the new Treasury building, yet unfinished, but the last appropriation for which is exhausted— The great body of these workmen were discharged on the 1st. of September. These two and eight others were continued till the 1st. of this month, and then dismissed at a time when they could not obtain work elsewhere— They applied to the Executive Commissioners of the Public buildings, the Secretaries of the Treasury, War and the Navy.— The men offered to work without immediate pay, in reliance that Congress would make the necessary appropriation. The answer from the Secretary of the Commissioners is that they neither authorise nor prohibit the men from resuming their work, and that they must apply to the superintendant Nolan; who like corporal Trim could not save a man’s life without orders, and so the men and their families were left to starve— A sputtering Italian named Raggi came and jabbered half an hour in a jargon composed in about equal parts of French, Italian and English, with the same complaint. The Irishmen told me they had been to Governor Lincoln, but he told them that he would no longer serve on the Committee on the public buildings— At the house R. C. Winthrop, moved an amendment of the Journal of last Thursday to insert his ay on Stanly’s motion to reconsider the vote for printing 15000 copies of the Presidents Message with the Documents.— Joseph L. Williams made the same motion for himself— Petrikin objected—debate—yeas and nays 200 to 3.— The two additional votes, carried the motion to reconsider— More debate—final vote to print 10,000 copies with the documents.— Committees announced. As nearly as possible the same as at the last Session— Committee of Manufactures all the same. Petrikin Chairman of the Committee on the public buildings. Thompson of Kentucky announced the death of his predecessor Simon Anderson with a suitable panegyric, and Resolutions of condolence, and to wear crape— And Leet of Pennsylvania performed the same service for William S. Ramsey, a Patriot and sage, who at the last Session boasted that he had been one of the Harrisburg mob in 1838, and would be one again if need there should be. Instead of which he shot himself about two months ago, at a Tavern in Baltimore— He had just been re-elected to Congress; and as Leet was not ashamed to say, lived and died an honourable man— The Resolution to wear crape for him passed of course, and the house adjourned— I gave another sitting for my portrait to Mrs Towle, and when it was finished told her my objection to it was that it was too much like the original— I met there a young man named Bartlett, a graduate of Dartmouth College, and a pretty girl from Vermont—Miss Makepeace— Towle and his wife are New-Jerusalem Swedenborgians. It was near 5. p.m. when I got home to dinner— Missed the scientific evening meeting.

15. IV:30. Tuesday.  Calls at the Patriotic and Washington Banks, atshop, for a Cask of Sicily Madeira wine, and at Lewis Johnson’s shop, to deliver him a Letter, delayed me, and I found the house in Session, in Committee of the whole on the state of the Union upon the bill making a partial appropriation for the support of Government for 1840. That is, the bill to provide for the expenses of the two houses of Congress, and for the pay of their members— In ten minutes after I entered the house the Bill was reported by the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and passed— Nothing can equal the despatch with which these bills are driven through both houses— A message came from the Senate that they had elected Mr Cookman for their Chaplain— Mr Hand introduced a new naturalization bill and to repeal all the existing Laws on that subject— He moved its reference to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union.moved to refer it to the judiciary Committee. Question by yeas and nays on the Union lost 96 to 99. the second vote on which a sufficient number of the Kinderhoek time-servers have given way, to turn the majority— The Bill goes to the judiciary Committee.— Virgil D. Parris moved to proceed to the election of a chaplain and nominated Thomas C. Braxton, whose chief if not only recommendation is that he is a grandson of Carter Braxton, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence from Virginia— He was elected at the second vote. I voted twice for Doctor Bates, the Chaplain of the last Session. Mr Russell the chairman of the Committee of Claims moved a Resolution that they might be allowed a clerk, at a Salary of 4 dollars a day; to which William Cost Johnson, chairman of the Committee on the District of Columbia, moved an Amendment for a similar allowance to them—whenever they should need it— The amendment was rejected, but the Clerk for the Committee of Claims was after some debate carried by yeas and nays— Sundry communications were received from the executive departments— I offered a Resolution, calling upon the President for a communication of documents shewing the origin of any political relations existing between the Government of the United States and that of China— When a Consul of the United States at Canton, and whether he or any one since appointed has ever been received or recognized there in that capacity— The instant after my Resolution was read Cave Johnson started up and moved to adjourn—which was carried— The Speaker came to my Seat and told me that he should call the States to-morrow for Petitions.— As I was returning home I met Charles Abbot, who repeated the invitation to me to deliver a Lecture here in the course of the Winter, which I promised in March after the close of the Session of Congress— Evening visit from Lieutenant Armistead; residing now near Norfolk in Virginia on a long furlough, for ill health. Read A. Buffum’s Protectionist, and a Discourse on the Commission, by F. W. Emmons.

16. IV:30. Wednesday—  I found Mr Solomon Lincoln this morning at the door of Brown’s Hotel, and delivered him a Letter from Mr Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth, and a bill upon the Clerk of the House, for the Old Colony Memorial payable to Mr Lincoln— He rode with me to the Capitol; where at half past ten, in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, met the select Committee on the falsification of house document N. 185 of the last Session—Adams, M’Kay, Bernard, Medill Dennis, all present— Hugh A. Garland, the Clerk of the house, attended with the Manuscript Message and Document, received from the President, and a copy of the printed document was furnished to the Committee from the Clerk’s Office— I proposed that minutes should be kept of the proceedings of the Committee and Mr Medill took them down— The manuscript and printed Document were identified, and certified by the Clerk to whom I administered the Oath upon the Bible to make true answers to the questions which should be put to him concerning the case under the consideration of the Committee— The examination of the clerk, and minuting his answers, brought the time to the meeting of the house, and the Committee adjourned to Friday Morning 10. O’Clock. The Clerk was directed to notify Mr Rives, one of the Printers of the house, to attend the Committee Friday Morning, and to apprize him of the subject of the examination— I proposed to send for Mr Greenhow, but that was not decided— In the House, the States were called for Petitions, and went rapidly through— I presented 8. only one of which was excluded from being received by the rule—two for rescinding the rule were laid on the table at the motion of Linn Banks and the others were referred to the Committees— After the petition of O. Bacheler had been at my motion referred to the Committee of foreign Affairs I received a note from him, and he came to me, and enquired if I could not get it referred to a select Committee— I told him that if I had made the motion the only effect would have been a motion to lay it on the table which would certainly have been carried— Leonard Hammond, who has claims upon the Government for Light house building in Louisiana, called me out and exhibited his papers to me, and I promised to go with him to the Secretary of the Treasury at 10 to morrow Morning. Thompson of Mississippi offered a Resolution instructing the Committee to report forthwith a Bill to prohibit the taking of the testimony of coloured persons in the army and navy—but he was instantly hushed and withdrew his motion. J. W Davis moved a reconsideration of the vote of yesterday referring Hands naturalization Bill to the judiciary Committee. My call upon the President for documents relating to China, was adopted with an amendment proposed by Cushing and accepted by me; without opposition, Cave Johnson happening to be absent— J. Connell called this Evening but did not come in.

17. IV:30. Thursday  I had promised Mr Leonard Hammond, if he would call on me this morning at ten, to go with him to the Secretary of the Treasury, and he had promised to come, but did not— This person belongs to Rochester in my Congressional District and was recommended to me, by a Letter from the Revd. Dr Robbins of Mattapoisett, during the last Session of Congress— He was a contractor for building Lighthouses in Louisiana, and has some discussions, about his claims for payment, with the 5th. auditor of the Treasury, Pleasonton who has the charge of the Lighthouse establishment. I took to Mr A. K. Parris’s house the Bill for four years subscription to the Old Colony Memorial, for the 2d. Comptroller’s Office, which I had received last evening but one, and which was intended for Mr Solomon Lincoln— Mr. Parris was gone to his Office; but I called again in the Evening, and he promised to have the bill paid to-morrow— I walked to and from the house— J. W. Davis’s motion to reconsider the reference of Hand’s Bill to the judiciary Committee was postponed till to-morrow, the bill itself not being printed. The States were called again for Petitions and then for Resolutions.— Hunt offered a Resolution for an amendment to the Constitution to restrict the Office of President of the United States to one term of four years— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union— Randolph moved a resolution directing the clerk to pay the extruded New-Jersey Members the usual mileage and per diem from the commencement of the last Session to the 15th. of July.— Skirmish debate— Yeas and Nays. 118 for the Resolution to 67. Wise asks to be excused from voting—too late, and refuses to vote— Mr Poinsett came to the house, and requested to draw up a memorial for the National Institution for the promotion of Science to Congress, praying for an act of incorporation; which I agreed to do—but when I moved that the use of the Hall of the house be granted to the Institution for the delivery of a discourse before them by Mr Poinsett, Pickens started a formal objection against it and a snarling debate followed. The abolition bugbear took extensively with the Southern whigs; and the expense of lighting the chandelier with no small number of the yankees. The vote was taken by yeas and nays, and carried only by 88 to 84. It is to be on the evening of the 4th. of January— Mark A. Cooper asked leave to introduce a bill to repeal the law, allowing a Salary to the Chaplains of Congress. Reed called for the yeas and nays which were 21 to 140— But Mark was not easily disconcerted— He wanted to move for a Select Committee to consider the expediency of dispensing with Chaplains, but it was not allowed. Mark is a silly, self conceited fellow— Adjourned before 3— Returning from the Capitol, I stop’d at Brown’s hotel, and saw Mr Solomon Lincoln, who told me that he had concluded to go to Baltimore in the Cars at Noon to-morrow.— Mr Clay and Mr Webster have both opened the Campaign in the Senate.

18. V:30. Friday.  Mr J. Seaver a Clerk in the second Comptroller’s Office brought me this morning a check on the Bank of the Metropolis for 8 dollars, for which I receipted the Bill for four years subscription from 1836 to 1840—to the Old Colony Memorial— I drew a check for the same sum, and took it to Brown’s Hotel to give Mr Lincoln, with the Newspaper addressed to him which I had received from Jacob H. Loud, but which from inadvertence to the manuscript direction upon it had been thrown upon the heap of my castaway newspapers—of which I receive about a dozen every day.— Mr Lincoln was not at his lodgings, and at Noon he left the City in the Cars for Baltimore—leaving word with the Barkeeper at Brown’s that he would write to me— On reaching the Capitol at 10. I found that the magnificent Chandelier suspended in the hall of the house since the close of the last Session of Congress, and said to have cost six thousand dollars, had just broken down with a tremendous crash, and crushed several desks of the members in its fall. I attended the select committee on the falsification of House document N. 185— All the members present. John C. Rives, one of the Printers of the House andTrendholm the proof reader of the Globe Office were examined and sworn.— Rives swore that he knew nothing of the alteration till after my resolution was offered in the house— Trendholm testified that the alteration was made by his direction to the compositor, and his reasons for it were that he did not know the meaning of the word, Ladino and Ladina as applied to negro Slaves he supposed the meaning of it must be sound— He said it was usual in printing for the proofreader to correct manifest errors in the copy and he produced several other instances in which it had been done—one particularly in which some German manuscript writing had been ludicrously disfigured— This man said he was a native of France, educated in England; had been 16 years engaged in printing offices; eight of the years in this City— At Noon the Committee took a recess of half an hour, anticipating the adjournment of the house, within that time— In the house Mr Cookman opened the meeting with prayer. John W. Jones, presented from the Committee of Ways and Means, a pension appropriation Bill. I enquired if the appropriation for the navy pension fund recommended by a special message from the President was included in it— That Message was referred to the Committee of Naval Affairs.— Reed, a member of the Committee said, the Chairman, (Francis Thomas) was absent, and there had been no meeting of the Committee— I said I hoped the Committee would not wait for their Chairman— Evans got in a petition from Maine about the Colonial trade— And at W. Cost Johnson’s motion, the house at half past 12. adjourned over to Monday. The Committee on the document resumed, sat till near 3. and adjourned to Monday 10. A.M— Mr Hughes of a commercial house in New-York came to enquire if duties on Silks would be laid this Session— I knew not—

19. IV:30. Saturday  Our horses were sent this morning to the blacksmith’s to be sharp shod; one of them kicked a boy at the shop, and came near killing him— Dr Thomas was sent for and applied leaches to bleed him— In the evening the boy was better. I returned the visits of Baron Mareschal, and Chevalier Hulsemann Austrian Minister and Chargé d’Affaires or Secretary of Legation—neither of whom was at home. I called next on Mr Thomas B. Johnson, suffering under paralytic and hypocondriac disease, varying in symptoms from day to day— Mrs Smith is at his house, confined to her chamber with a severe cold and cough— Mr Johnson now lives in Mrs John Adams’s house on the President’s Square where we lived from December 1829 to December 1838 in winter— On leaving the house, I fell in with Ogden Hoffman, and walked with him till I went into the State Department Office.— Mr Greenhow was not there— But I examined the copy of the Spanish permits for the shipment of the Amistad blacks at the Havana, transmitted by the District Attorney Holabird from the Court record at New Haven, and from which the copy transmitted with the President’s Message to the House of Representatives was made— The copy sent to the house was exactly conformable to the copy at the Department— I desired that Mr Greenhow might be notified to attend the Committee next Monday morning at 10. and to bring this copy from the court record with him— There were a mass of papers in preparation to answer the call for papers relating to our political relations with China; and the record of the Commission of Samuel Shaw as Consul at Canton, of which I requested that a copy might be sent to the house— I saw Mr Derrick who said he had not found any of the papers belonging to the Massachusetts historical Society, alledged to have been borrowed by Mr Egbert Benson; but he had found some belonging to Harvard University borrowed by Mr Albert Gallatin— I requested him to return me the Resolution of the Massachusetts historical Society, and a written answer to my enquiry. Mr Van Ness was with Mr Forsyth for about an hour, while I was waiting with the Clerks one of whom gave me a printed copy of a pamphlet called a brief review of some of the Points in the case of the L’Amistad and the principles involved— I had much conversation with Mr Forsyth, on this case and found him smarting under the scourge of judge William Jay’s comments on his conduct— But inflexibly determined to pursue the appeal to the Supreme Court.— He said he disapproved of Mr Greenhow’s troubling me about this matter— Would it were over— Mr. Pope paid us a morning visit, and in the Evening Mr Joseph S. Wilson came with a Letter as President of the Union Literary and debating Society of Washington City, requesting me to deliver a Lecture before them.

20. V:30. Sunday  I attended public worship this morning in the Hall of the House of Representatives, and heard Mr Cookman preach from 1. Timothy 3.16—“And without controversy, great is the mystery of godliness. God was manifest in the flesh, justified in the Spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory.” A Christmas discourse; on the Godhead of Jesus Christ.
