And he read the first chapter of the gospel of John— The delivery of Mr Cookman is vehement and impassioned to excess— It is highly popular, and I am of those who relish that style of speaking, which many persons of cooler temper and calmer judgment disapprove. He began his sermon this day thus—“Says the objector to the Christian Religion, and to the holy scriptures, I cannot believe this system; for there is too much of the marvellous too many miracles, too many mysteries in it; I cannot reconcile it to my understanding.[”]— Then he replied, if the objection of mystery could be a sufficient ground for disbelief a man can believe nothing— The simplest operations of nature, the growth of a blade of grass from the seed, the course of the Sun round the heavens are mysteries as far beyond the comprehension of the human mind, as any of the miracles recorded in the Scriptures.— He then divided his subject into the six particular properties, which constitute in their combination, the greatness of the mystery of godliness, and commented upon each of them in turn: and in expounding each of the properties he introduced the texts of Scripture which explain or confirm them— The effort was to demonstrate the divinity of Christ—certainly countenanced by numerous texts, taken according to the Letter; but all susceptible of a spiritual sense or requiring a different translation from that of Jamess Doctors.— There was nothing new in the argument or in the authorities cited by Mr Cookman—nothing that produced a new impression upon my mind— After the service I returned the visit of Mr Hunter the Speaker; an amiable good hearted, weak headed young man, prematurely hoisted into a place for which he is not fit; precisely for his Virginian quiddities.— I sat and conversed an hour with him but could make absolutely nothing of him— Another hour I passed with Mr Daniel Webster. The chief characteristic of whose conversation was reserve— It is now announced in the Newspapers that he is to be Secretary of State— This afternoon I attended at St. John’s Church half an hour belated— Mr Hawley read the Evening prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent, and a stranger preached from John 5:40. And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life. Miss Cutts was in our pew— My evening was consumed in partly reading Dr William E. Channing’s new pamphlet upon emancipation—and in poring over the classical effusions of the infancy and caducity of the Marquess of Wellesley, sent me with a kind Letter by Mr John M’Tavish.

21. VI:30. Monday.  The Winter Solstice— Conjunction of the Moon, Jupiter and Mercury observed at dawn of day. I hastened to the Capitol, as I found three quarters of an hour before the time, and employed them in writing a short Letter to Dr Palfrey. At 10. the Committee on the falsified Documents N. 185 met and examined upon Oath Thomas S. Geddes the compositor at the printing Office of Blair and Rives, and upon affirmation Robert Greenhow, the translator at the Department of State— Geddes swore to the best of his recollection, that he set the types according to the manuscript, and that the word sound was substituted for Ladino, and Ladina, by the direction of the proofreader, marked on the proof— Greenhow brought with him the original manuscript of his translation, and the document received at the Department of State from the District Attorney in Connecticut Holabird, containing the copy of the Record of the District Court, and in it the copy of the two permits to ship the negroes, in one of which are the words negros Ladinos, and in the other the words negras ladinas— Greenhow said there was no possible sense in which the word sound was a correct translation of the words Ladino or Ladina— The examination of witnesses was closed; but there was no definitive action of the Committee, the House being already in Session— It was 20 minutes past 12. when I went down, and French the sub-clerk was reading the vote of yeas and nays upon John W. Davis’s motion to reconsider the reference of Hand’s naturalization Bill to the Judiciary Committee— I was too late to vote. The reconsideration was refused 90 to 93. The States were then (after a desultory debate about the authority by which the Clerk of the house paid between 11 and 1200 dollars to Charles J. Ingersoll for witnesses on the trial between him and Charles Naylor of the contested election at the last Session of Congress, which was finally laid asleep by reference to thee Committee of accounts) called through for petitions— There were very few, but multitudes of the members succeeded in slipping in Resolutions and Bills, by general consent— This consumed the time so that when the nominal call for Petitions was gone through, it was near 3. O’Clock, and before the call for Resolutions could be announced a motion to adjourn was made and carried— I offered a petition from Elisha Huntington, and 186 others for an amendment of the naturalization Laws, so as to admit coloured foreigners to the right of holding real estate and voting—referred to the judiciary Committee— I notified the members of the Committee of Manufactures to attend a meeting to-morrow Morning; except Dromgoole who is sick, and Worthington who is at home Evening writing till near Midnight—on the Amistad captives—

22. VI. Tuesday  Mahlon Day is a Quaker settled in the City of New-York and accompanied Joseph John Gurney in his religious tour to the West Indies in the Winter of 1839–40. He came this morning with two young men whom he introduced to me, I believe by the name of Robinson, and he gave me a printed copy of Gurney’s Letters to Henry Clay of Kentucky describing a Winter in the West Indies. I had received two days ago a pamphlet upon emancipation by Dr William E. Channing, which is a running commentary upon this work of Gurney— I had a morning visit also from Stephen C. Phillips of Salem, whom I invited to dine with us on Christmas day, but he said he should obliged to leave the City to be home by next Saturday— He gave me some information concerning China, and promised more from a young man named King of the house of Oliphant at Canton—the same I suppose whom I met on the 10th. of last Month at dinner on the 10th. of last Month at Mr Abbott Lawrence’s in Boston, at dinner— Meeting of the Committee of manufactures at 11. this morning— Present Adams, Slade, Tillinghast, Mitchell, John Davis of Pennsylvania, and Eastman— Absent Nisbet whom I had notified yesterday—Dromgoole who is sick, and Worthington; who goes home weekly on Saturdays, and has not yet returned.— I read several petitions referred by the house to the Committee, and two Letters to members of the house, which they had put into my hands.— There was a desultory conversation, whether the Committee should call up and report again the bill for suppressing frauds in the collection of the revenue, which was lost at the last Session with the votes of two thirds of both houses in its favour— The Committee came to no conclusion, but adjourned to next Tuesday Morning at 11— In the House there was an answer of Garland the Clerk to the enquiry about the payment of money to C. J. Ingersoll for witnesses— Answer referred to the Committee on Accounts— Rives called up the Report of the Committee of Elections made at the last Session upon the election of Charles Naylor, and moved for its consideration to-morrow. After debate he varied his motion, so as to take it up on the first Tuesday in January which was carried— The States were called for petitions, but very few were presented— Few Reports of Committees. F. Thomas reported a bill concerning the Navy Pension fund. I asked if it was an appropriation; he said it was, and that he should call it up at an early day. Sundry Resolutions were discussed, till one offered by Mr Barnard who moved an adjournment— Carried. Evening visits from Mr Reed and Mr Taliaferro— And Bernard M’Closkey came to request me to speak to the Committee on the Public buildings, for the Stone-cutters—

23. V. Wednesday.  I went this morning to the house, expecting to take little or no part in the business of the day— But the States were called over for Petitions; of which there were not a dozen presented— One of them was by Francis James the Pennsylvania Quaker— William Cost Johnson objected to its reception under the gag rule— It was sent to the Speaker who looked into it and declared it within the rule— James insisted that it was not and the reading of it was called for and refused— Someone moved to lay the motion of reception on the table, which was carried by yeas and nays 99 to 53 When the State of Massachusetts was called, I said I had no petition to present, but asked leave to offer my Resolution of Call upon the Postmaster General, for a list of Post masters removed since the 3d. of March 1829— The Resolution was received, but at M’Kay’s motion was ordered to lie over one day under the rule— The Committees were called for reports— John W. Jones from the Ways and Means reported the Navy and Indian annuity Appropriation Bills.— When the Committee of Manufactures was called, I said I had no report to make, but a motion that the bill N. 100 of the house of the last Session, as it was when the Session closed should be referred to the Committee— And now came an explosion totally unexpected by me— Pickens came out with a gunpowder blast against the bill— The Speaker said my motion was not in order— Stanly moved to suspend the rule, to enable me to make the motion, which brought down Wise with a broadside upon him, which he returned double shotted— The rules were suspended by a vote of 131 to 45.— Wise then moved that the reference should be to the Committee of Ways and Means, and made another Speech— Pickens called for the reading of the title of the Bill which was done— Wise called for the reading of the whole bill, which was begun; and he then modified his motion to the reading all after the 16th. Section, which was done— He insisted that the subject belonged to the Committee of Ways and Means; and Tillinghast replied to him— Horace Everett all the time in a low almost inaudible voice repeating question—question— Morgan moved the previous question, which wise moved to lay on the table, but withdrew his motion. It was carried, and the vote to refer to the Committee of Manufactures was carried 109 to 50— Adjourned just before 3. But the New-Hampshire, Maine and New-York serviles flinched at the last, and voted against the reference— Wise moved instructions to the Committee to strike out, after the 16th. Section, all the remainder of the Bill; but withdrew the motion. Dr John M. Thomas was here this Evening; and also Mr William Jagger, the volunteer politician and pamphleteer from Suffolk County, Long-Island who kept me in conversation upwards of two hours— The consequence of which was that I lost the whole Evening for writing.

24. IV.15 Thursday  I was roused just after four O’Clock this morning by a violent knocking at the front door of the house by a man with two chimney sweeper boys whom I let in to sweep the kitchen chimney. It was a little earlier than my usual rising hour, and I did not return to bed. At half past ten I met the Committee on the falsification of document N. 185— Present Adams, M’Kay, Medill, and belated Barnard— Dennis was not in the house yesterday so that I could not notify him of the meeting this morning— I suppose he has gone home to keep Christmas. Benjamin R. French, now Chief Clerk under Hugh A. Garland, of the house and Brooke M Berry, one of the copying clerks, were sworn and examined concerning a small slip of paper, attached to the 87th. page of the written document, and containing merely the names given in Spanish upon that page of the manuscript, anglicised— They testified that it was a loose paper received with the manuscript document as returned from the printers— French attached it by a wafer to the manuscript page— Trendholm the proof reader of the printing Office had acknowledged that the loose paper was in his hand-writing, but did not recollect why he had written it— Mr. Barnard came in after the examination of French and Berry was over.— There was conversation as to the principles on which the Report should be drawn up— M’Kay and Medill appeared averse to any expression of censure upon the practice either of the Printing Office or of the Department of State— M’Kay requested me to state the principles on which I thought the report should be prepared— I said I would state the fact of falsification, and that it was done by the proof reader of the printing Office—to express disapprobation of the altering of documents at the printers, without authority and especially on matters so material—to state also the interpolation of the word negros in the copies and translations of the permit to Ruiz, and the omission of the name of Francisco, from the copy of the translated permit in the manuscript from the Department of State— All this M’Kay and Medill thought was not within the Commission— And I asked how the printing-office, and the Department would stand with a report of the falsification, and the name of the falsifier. Trendholm the proof reader— Medill thought the reference to the testimony would be sufficient— M’Kay was more wary— After much discussion, he proposed that I should draw up a report according to my own views and lay it before the Committee; to which I agreed— In the house the day was consumed upon a Memorial from the Legislature of the State of Illinois and a motion of Reynolds to refer it to the Committee of Public Lands with Instructions to report a Bill to graduate the price of the public lands down to nothing— This started the Land robbery passion, and Reynolds, Pickens, W. Cost Johnson, and Hubbard of Alabama, kept it up, till near 3. when immediately after a refusal to adjourn by yeas and naysthe house did adjourn over to Monday without them— Frank Thomas chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs came to me in his own way to tell me that he was going to call up immediately his bill concerning the navy pension fund; which he said could not take five minutes to pass, and asked whether I had any particular enquiry to make about it— I found he knew nothing about his own bill and set him upon his enquiries— Mr John Connell spent the Evening here.

25. VI. Friday. Christmas.  Having heard last Sunday morning at the Capitol a very orthodox Christmas Sermon, and having this day great need of my time, I dispensed with attendance at Church, and returned visits to Govr. Lincoln, and his fellow lodgers at Miss Corcoran’s and found them in potations of egg-nog.— and to Mr and Mrs Henderson of Mississippi; Mr. and Mrs Winthrop, and Mr and Miss Saltonstall, at Mrs Mount’s—Pennsylvania avenue— While I was there General Scott came in with James Monroe as visitors. I met in the Street Mr Dawson of Georgia, whom I was intending to visit, and who had just called at my house while I was out.— Shortly before dinner, I had visits from Mr John Davis, our Senator, and Governor elect of Massachusetts, with Thomas W. Williams a member of the house from Connecticut— We have heretofore been accustomed to entertain a family party at dinner on Christmas days; but the condition of the family on the last and two or three preceding years has deprived us of this pleasure, and of the exercise of almost all acts of hospitality— At this time, my wife has been these ten days keeping her chamber— Mr T. B. Johnson and Mrs Smith are confined to theirs— The situation of Mr Frye’s family is irksome—we could not all meet; but I invited a few members of the house, and Mr Connell, the nine names first on the margin and they dined with me. Charles Ogle had promised to come, but did not. We had only men at table—the Ladies preferring to dine together. The day went off pleasantly, but I had no time, either to prepare for the argument before the Supreme Court, so soon to overtake me—or to draw up the Report on the falsification of the document N. 185, or to examine the condition of the Navy pension fund, for the debate, which I intend if possible to raise upon that appropriation Bill— I did however find a few of the most important documents of the last Session relating to the Navy pension fund and to the system of investing public monies and trust funds in stocks of the States, which I consider equivalent to assuming so much of State debts. In the search for the first authority to make investments in stocks of the States, I must have recourse to the Journals and Documents of both houses, the Register of debates, and the Laws for several past Sessions. In the course of this pursuit, I trace the investments in Stocks of the States to Silas Wright in May 1836. and that carries me back to the annual report of the Secretary of the Treasury in December 1835.

26. VI. Saturday.  I returned this morning the visit of our Senator and Governor elect John Davis, and that of Mr William C. Dawson, who was not at his lodgings; but I met in the entry Mr Habersham, who lodges at the same house, and sat half an hour with him. While I was there Mrs and Miss Croghan came into visit Mrs Dawson, and she was called down— She thanked me for the present which I sent her of my mother’s Letters.— Mr George Bancroft Collector of the port of Boston is here, and left his card a few days since at my house. I enquired of Mr Davis who married his Sister where he lodged, and he said at Fuller’s; and that Mrs Bancroft was with him. I called there; but he was out, and I left a Card— This man is such a rabid democrat, and such a sycophantic double dealer, that I am tempted to spurn him as a swindler— But perhaps cold civility is the wisest course to pursue with them— Mr Hammond came after dinner with a complaint that Stephen Pleasanton the fith auditor, and superintendent of light-houses, had finally refused to pay him according to his contract, and the award of competent arbitrators, appointed by Prieus the late Collector of New-Orleans and himself by Pleasonton’s own direction for building two Light houses in Louisiana. Pleasonton now refuses to pay him any part of his claim, unless he will make a deduction of 4000 dollars from 14000. the amount of his demand sustained by his vouchers, and give a receipt in full.— Mr Hammond wanted my advice what to do: and said he had also consulted with Mr John Reed, and wished to advise with him again.— I advised him to ask Mr Reed if an Application to the Circuit Court of the District for a Mandamus, would not be his best remedy. I believed it would, and if Mr Reed should concur in that opinion he must apply to some lawyer, say W. S. Cox, to take out a Mandamus.— After him came Mr John Connell with a memorial to Congress from Stephen Blight for the heirs of Robert Fulton, which he requested me to present on Monday to the house. It is an old claim; a Bill for the allowance and payment of which passed the houseyears ago, but was arrested in the Senate, and left the claim pending. Blight married a daughter of Fulton— He was rich but has failed; and Fulton’s family are destitute— Mr Connell is one of the Directors of the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States going out of Office; and from his reluctant and hesitating answers to my questions, disclosed the dismal condition of that institution, and a very suspicious aspect of debts due to it both by its former President N. Biddle, and its late Cashier Cowperthwait— Connell says he believes the Capital of the Bank is yet equal to 25 Millions. It should be 35. But the whole of its debt to the United States is paid.

27. VI. Sunday  Attended morning worship at the Capitol, where Mr Braxton the Chaplain from the House of Representatives preached, but delivered his text in so low a tone of voice that I did not hear it; nor could I infer what it was from the Sermon. The preacher, when elected, was announced to be, of the Baptist denomination, and he appeared this day to be of the orthodox creed—for he said that the necessity of being born again, though an old-fashioned doctrine was nevertheless true. His manner of delivery is graceful, and his personal appearance neat and gentlemanly. His style of writing and speaking is temperate and decent but hardly grave enough— His devotion not cold—nor very warm—his arguments and quotations from Scripture traditionary.— There were several members of the Baptist congregation of this City, seated in front of the Speaker’s chair who sung two hymns given out by him, and also Watts’s 100th. Psalm by a signal from him— After the morning service, I visited Mr Granger, at Gadsby’s, and saw him and his daughter. He had been to keep Christmas at Baltimore—dined at Mr Meredith’s with a large party—then at tea with a family party of forty at Mr Gilmor’s and afterwards at a family party of forty two at Mr Gilmor’s sisters Mrs Donnell’s— I visited also at Hyatt’s, and found Mr Taliaferro and Mr T. W. Williams with seven other gentlemen there; and constituting their mess— Miss Cutts dined with us, and after dinner At St. John’s Church, Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the Sunday after Christmas, and preached from John 14.2. “In my father’s house are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you.”— A searching North-west prevailed, growing colder through the day. Mr Hammond was here this Evening; and said Mr John Reed had requested him to tell me, that he would come to-morrow morning at 10. O’Clock, and go with me to Mr Pleasonton, the fifth Auditor to remonstrate with him against the conditions which he insists upon exacting from Mr Hammond for the settlement of his account—requiring a deduction of more than four thousand dollars, from a sum of about 14000. awarded to Mr Hammond by two arbitrators chosen according to Pleasonton’s own direction, one by the Collector at New-Orleans, and the other by Mr Hammond, and yet compelling Mr Hammond to give a receipt in full of all demands— I promised to go with Mr Reed, who, he says thinks that a Mandamus in this case would not lie— I must distrust my opinions upon points of law— In attempting to resume this evening the preparation for the case of the Amistad captives, I meet immediately the questions what right Lieutenant Gedney had to seize them on the shore of New-York, or the vessel on the high Seas— I can find no such right; and yet I foresee too clearly that I shall either not be allowed to make the question or that it will be suppressed without even being answered— Oh! how shall I do justice to this case, and to these men?

28. VI. Monday.  Mr Reed called at 10 O’Clock this morning, and I went with him first to the Office of Stephen Pleasonton fifth Auditor of the Treasury to remonstrate against his arbitrary attempt to cut down by a deduction of more than 4000 dollars the account of Mr Hammond—without allowing him even the right of petitioning Congress for allowance of the deduction— Pleasonton refusing to abide by the award of arbitrators, appointed by his own direction, had referred the Bill to some dependent of his own office who reduced it ad libitum and then reported to the Secretary of the Treasury the reduced bill, to be paid upon Hammond’s signing a receipt in full of all demands. Mr Woodbury directs another petty retrenchment, and orders the bill to be paid accordingly. I insisted that the whole bill ought to be paid according to the award of the referees, but Mr Reed only demanded what Hammond himself had brought his mind to consent to; that is that he should take the amount of the reduced Bill, reserving the right to petition Congress for the remainder— Pleasonton shuffled about this, till at last said he was willing, but the Secretary of the Treasury had directed otherwise— We then went to the Secretary himself, who told us that he had not examination of the case at-all; and that he had directed one small charge which he thought inadmissible to be struck out in all other respects had merely confirmed Pleasonton’s report and particuly in requiring a receipt in full of all demands from Hammond. That he had no objection to Hammond’s reserving the right to petition Congress, and would so direct if Pleasonton would write him a line advising it— We next returned to Pleasonton who shuffled again insisting that he had not recommended the exaction of the receipt in full, till at last he went and fetched the copy of his letter to the Secretary, and there it was in so many words— I almost lost my temper, and as Mr Hammond last evening had requested me to do spoke to him very plain— Reed teazed him to write the Letter to the Secretary which he had promised, and to which Woodbury had promised to conform, leaving to Hammond the right to Petition Congress, but he preferred making another trial to compromise and settle with Hammond himself—to which we agreed; but I told him if he did not agree with Hammond, it should go before Congress, for I would introduce it there— At the house, Thomas, Chairman of the Committee of Naval Affairs, called up the Bill appropriating upwards of 151000 dollars to pay the Navy pensions to be due on the first of next Month— The house went into Committee of the whole on the State of the Union— M’Kay in the Chair— The Speaker first called me to the Chair; but I asked him to excuse me; as I intended to address the Committee on the Bill. I did so, and opened a debate not soon to close— The Bill was reported to the House— Charles Shepard moved a second section, repealing the Navy Pension Act of 3. March 1837. which was carried by yeas and nays 81 to 70. and the bill passed.— Mr Wilcocks was here this Evening—

29. VI. Tuesday—  Mr Devlin a Clerk in Mr Pleasonton’s Office came this morning with a number of papers to explain to me his reasons for insisting on many deductions from Mr Hammond’s account, and to shew me the various estimates of different persons to whom he had referred them; all which he had already done yesterday— I told him that I had heard all this yesterday, and could not possibly judge of the correctness of estimates so widely differing from each other for the same thing— But that I had understood that Mr Pleasonton and Mr Hammond were to have agreed together and settled the account between them— He said that was what they proposed to do this day; but Mr Pleasonton was apprehensive that I might mention the subject in the house— I assured him I should not do this unless it should turn out that Mr Pleasonton and Mr Hammond finally disagreed about the settlement— At half past ten I attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures— Present Adams, Nisbet, Tillinghast, Slade, Mitchell and Davis; absent Dromgoole, Worthington and Eastman— I brought the Bill for suppressing frauds on the revenue immediately before the Committee; and the report in the New-York Herald of the Meeting of the New-York Merchants, and the Speech of the Scotchman Robert Jaffray against the Bill— I read also Bennett’s remarks in the Herald upon the debate in the house of last Wednesday, and on the Letter then read in the house from Robert Jaffray to James Monroe— Bennett fiercely on the accuracy of the report, and defies Jaffray to his teeth.— Nisbet said that Bennett’s New-York Herald was utterly unworthy of credit, and he would not believe any charge contained in it against any man— Other members of the Committee were not so incredulous— They thought Mr Jaffray’s Letter a very equivocal denial— After some discussion upon the Bill Mr Slade moved that the Chairman be directed to report the House Bill of the last Session N. 100. as amended by the Senate without the Sections added by the Senate— This after some opposition from Nisbet was agreed to by the Committee and the question was postponed to the next Tuesday at half past ten, whether the Senate Bill should also be reported— When I entered the house I found them debating a motion by Giddings of Ohio, to reconsider the Section of the Navy pension appropriation Bill, repealing the Act of 3. March 1837—moved yesterday by Charles Shepard and carried— And the Bill actually so passed— This debate continued about an hour, and I took part in it— Shepard rose and began to reply when a message from the Senate announced the death of Felix Grundy, a member of that body from Tennessee—whereupon A. V. Brown pronounced the regular Eulogy upon him, and moved the crape-veiled Resolutions, and the immediate adjournment of the house—adopted of course— I went to the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures—drew up a short report on the falsified document, and assorted the papers for publication— At 4. p.m. I went to Mrs Hewitt’s and dined with Messrs. Daniel Webster and Edward Curtis. Mrs Webster, her niece Miss Le Roy, and Mrs Curtis—Governors Davis and Lincoln Saltonstall and Cushing were there— Home at 8. P.M.

30. VI. Wednesday  Two Ladies whose names have escaped me, called this morning with a subscription paper, for a one dollar annual contribution for the poor of the foundery methodist church— They took the dollar as a donation.— A Mr Rudolph, came and informed me that he was from Boston— That he was poor, and had come and brought his family with him to get a place— He believed the Commissioner of public buildings had one to bestow, and he would thank me for a Letter of recommendation to that Officer— I told him I was not in that habit of recommending any person for Officer; and especially that I could not recommend any person with whom I had no acquaintance— I went to the Capitol an hour before the meeting of the house, and spent it in preparing the Bill for the more effectual collection of the revenue to be reported to the house; and I gave it with the draught of a report on the falsified document, to Mr Berry of the Clerk’s Office to be copied— At the meeting of the house, I asked leave to present the four Resolutions in relation to investments of public monies in the stocks of the States and the sales of such Stocks which I had prepared at the last Session of Congress, but which the house then refused to receive— No objection was now made to receiving them, and the Speaker was about taking the question upon their adoption when Cave Johnson objected and they were laid-over; with an order that they be printed— Samson Mason asked leave to introduce a Resolution of enquiry concerning the cost of certain Indian schools stipulated by Treaties—but Cave Johnson stopped that, as being out of order; insisting that Charles Shepard had the floor on the motion to reconsider the Section of the navy pension appropriation act which repeals the Act of 3. March 1837— Accordingly Shepard proceeded for about an hour, in a venomous, sophistical and unprincipled speech, in which he vented a long gathering burden of spleen against me, for which I had in readiness, a castigation which I shall not be allowed to administer; for after Shepard finished, several other members discussed and discoursed upon the act of 3. March 1837. almost without touching upon its real merits, till 3. O’Clock when Jameson of Missouri moved the previous Question; which cuts off my right of reply.— A motion was then made and carried to adjourn— Brockway has got up a subscription to print my Speech of Monday in a pamphlet— I called at the Office of the National Intelligencer and took from Mr Seaton a couple of copies of this day’s paper in which the Speech is reported by Wheeler—to revise it, which I was yet not able to do this Evening— Mr Seaton gave me a budget of Letters which he has received from Christopher Hughes at Stockholm, with injunction to communicate them to me— John Baer the buckeye blacksmith, and his brother James were here.

31. VI. Thursday.  I had yesterday notified the members of the Committee on the falsified document, to meet this morning to consider the report that I had prepared to be presented to the house. Mr Dennis is gone home to keep the Christmas holidays, and Mr Barnard forgot my notification, so that M’Kay and Medill were my only associates at the meeting— In the discussion at the last Meeting upon the principles on which the report should be drawn up, I had proposed to touch upon the other mutilation of the document charged by judge Jay—upon the practice of allowing proof readers to depart from their copy, in the printing of public documents, upon the omission of one of the names of the 49 negroes in the translation of the Passport for the Ladinos of Ruiz, in the document from the Department of State, whence I inferred that it had been transmitted from the Department without being collated—to all which M’Kay and Medill had objected; and said it was not within the authority of the Committee; that they were charged only to report facts; and that all these circumstances to which I alluded might be very proper for a speech, and not for a report— I told them then what the consequence of their tight lacing would be; but I prepared the report according to their measure, simply stating the fact of falsification—and by whom it was committed—referring to the testimony, without one word of comment. It did not suit them— They wanted to acquit the proof reader of all bad intention and the house printers of all responsibility—the administration of all knowledge or participation in the wrong— I said if the report must give opinions, I could not forbear to pass censure upon all those parties— It came to be 12. O’Clock— They did not know whether to agree to the report or not. They would consult together and let me know.— M’Kay took the testimony which he afterwards returned to me in the house: but postponed telling me whether they would agree to my report or not— In the house numerous Bills from the Senate were twice read and referred—and Two Messages from the President, one of them the answer to my call for documents relating to China— I reported from the Committee of Manufactures for the more effectual collection of the revenue. Pickens attempted to prevent it from getting in; but failed— Referred to the Committee of the whole on the State of the Union.— I asked Jamieson to withdraw his motion for the previous question to enable me to reply to Charles Shepard— Jamieson refused— I appealed to the Justice of the house in vain— They sustained the previous question, and refused to reconsider.— A Letter form Rives, one from the house printers complained that the Clerk had given much of the house printing and binding to Langtree— After debate referred to a Select committee of 5.— States called through for Petitions. Debate on the burning of the Caroline. Attree’s Letter to me read— Monroe Adjourned after 3. over to Monday. Call at the Intelligencer Office. Seaton.
